§ 143.07 - SPECIAL OR PRIVATE POLICE OFFICERS, BOND AND FEE. 
The city manager is authorized to commission such special or private police officers and private detectives as deemed necessary, all to serve without compensation from the city. 
Such private or special police officers and private detectives shall give a bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) to the satisfaction of the city manager and shall pay an annual fee in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). They shall act under the direction and control of the police chief and such rules and regulations as the city manager shall from time to time provide. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.08 - ESTABLISHMENT OF AN UPPER ARLINGTON RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE. 
The city may create within the department of public safety a reserve and an auxiliary police force, the members of which shall be appointed by the city manager. Membership in, or appointment to, the reserve or auxiliary police force, shall not confer employee status upon any person for any reason; and members of the reserve and auxiliary police force are not subject to C.O. ch. 149, the rules and regulations of the Upper Arlington Municipal Civil Service Commission or to any provisions of the laws of the State of Ohio pertaining to civil service. 
The objective of the reserve and auxiliary police force shall be to assist the police chief and all regular officers in the performance of police work within the jurisdictional limits of Upper Arlington. 
(A)  Reserve force: Members of the reserve force shall have all police powers, but shall perform only such duties as assigned to them by the police chief and shall act only when in uniform as prescribed by the police chief. 
(1)  Reserve officers are subject to the same general orders, special orders, personnel orders, memorandum, training bulletins, rules of conduct and directives applicable to other officers as well as the standards imposed by C.O. § 143.08. 
(a)  They shall be under the general control of the police chief or his/her designee who shall report to the police chief regarding their activities and training. 
(2)  Reserve officers shall be defined as those individuals certified by the Ohio Peace Officers Training Council (OPOTC). 
(3)  Reserve officers will be commissioned persons. They will consist of civilian volunteers who will serve a minimum of eight (8) hours per month without compensation. 
(4)  Uniforms worn by reserve officers shall be the same as those worn by full-time officers. The police division will supply all necessary uniform parts and the service weapon. 
(B)  Auxiliary force: Members of the auxiliary force shall be uniformed in a manner distinct from regular officers and shall be unarmed. Members of the auxiliary police force shall have no arrest powers and shall perform only such duties as assigned to them by the police chief and shall act only when in uniform as prescribed by the police chief. 
(1)  The primary duty of the auxiliary officer is to provide additional manpower for special assignments and activities where a full-time or reserve officer is not required. Auxiliary officers may ride in police vehicles to provide for additional coverage when needed. 
(2)  Auxiliary officers are subject to the same general orders, special orders, personnel orders, memorandum, training bulletins, rules of conduct and directives applicable to other officers as well as the standards imposed by C.O. § 143.08. 
(a)  Auxiliary officers shall be under the general control of the police chief or his designee who shall report to the police chief regarding their activities and training. 
(3)  Auxiliary officers will be commissioned persons. They will consist of civilian volunteers who will serve a minimum of eight (8) hours per month without compensation. 
(C)  The strength of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force shall not exceed the authorized strength of the police division as authorized in accordance with C.O. § 143.04. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.09 - QUALIFICATIONS AND TERMS OF RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE OFFICERS. 
(A)  Members of both the reserve and auxiliary police force shall be between their 21st and 50th birthdays at the date of initial appointment. Members may be reappointed beyond their 50th birthday upon presentation of evidence of satisfactory physical condition acceptable to the city manager. 
(B)  Reserve and auxiliary officer selection criteria will be similar to that used for full-time officers with the exception that mandatory written tests are not required. 
(C)  Candidates will go before a board of review and will have a thorough background investigation prior to any appointment. 
(D)  The city manager may terminate any reserve or auxiliary appointment at any time. 
(E)  Members may resign their appointments at any time. 
(F)  Reserve and auxiliary officers shall retire from active status no later than the last day of the month in which such reserve or auxiliary officer reaches his/her seventieth (70th) birthday. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.10 - DUTIES OF POLICE CHIEF AND CITY MANAGER REGARDING RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCES. 
The police chief shall be the commanding officer of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force subject to the approval of the city manager and shall have sole control of the assignments, training, stationing, utilization, and direction of its members. 
Such members shall obey the chain of command of the police division, the general orders and operating procedures of the police division, the rules and regulations of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force and shall be subject to the orders of all regular appointed police officers of this city. 
The police chief, with the approval of the city manager, shall prescribe rules and regulations for the conduct and control of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force. The rules shall prescribe, but not be limited to: 
(A)  Application and appointment procedures. 
(B)  Residency, medical, educational, psychological and moral character standards. 
(C)  Training requirements. 
(D)  Probationary status upon initial appointment. 
(E)  Uniform, insignia and equipment. 
(F)  Disciplinary procedures. 
(G)  Termination procedures. 
(H)  Required participation and tours of duty. 
(I)  The establishment and Charter of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Association. 
(J)  Any other rules necessary for the proper control and operation of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.11 - BONDING AND LIABILITY INSURANCE COVERAGE REGARDING RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE MEMBERS. 
(A)  The city manager shall insure that the members of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force are extended the benefits of the Workers' Compensation Act available to the members of any organization, association or group of persons whose services are desired by the city, but whose members are not employees of the City as provided for by ORC § 4123.01 by means of a contract for such benefits with the Industrial Commission of Ohio as therein provided for, or as authorized by Ordinance No. 35-55, and any contracts entered into pursuant to such authorization. 
(B)  The city manager shall purchase liability insurance for any class of members of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force, equal to that provided to full-time officers performing like functions. 
(C)  Members of the Upper Arlington Reserve and Auxiliary Police Force are to be bonded with the same coverage afforded to full-time officers providing like functions. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.12 - COMPENSATION FOR RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE. 
All services performed by reserve and auxiliary police officers shall be on a voluntary basis and without pay. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.13 - PURPOSE, LIABILITY OF CITY REGARDING RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCES. 
The provisions of C.O. §§ 143.08 to 143.15 are declared to be an exercise by the city of its police powers for the protection of public peace, health, property, safety and general welfare, and neither the city nor any agent or representative of the city, nor any individual, firm, partnership or corporation, who in good faith executes any executive order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of C.O. §§ 143.08 to 143.15 shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to person or property as a result of such action. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.14 - EXECUTIVE ORDERS FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCES. 
The city manager is authorized and directed to promulgate such executive orders, rules and regulations as, in his/her discretion, are either necessary or desirable in the administration of the reserve and auxiliary police force. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.15 - CONFLICT WITH OTHER LAWS REGARDING RESERVE AND AUXILIARY POLICE FORCES. 
The provisions of chapter 143 regarding reserve and auxiliary police forces shall not be construed as intended by council to be in conflict with any collective bargaining agreement, federal or state statute or with any lawful regulation promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.16 - COMPOSITION/SERVICES OF FIRE DIVISION. 
The fire division shall consist of the fire chief and such other officers and employees as may be authorized by the city manager. The fire division shall be responsible for the firefighting, fire prevention, fire service and emergency medical service activities of the city, as may be authorized by the city manager. 
The fire chief shall be appointed by the city manager from the fire division, or shall have had other training and experience in firefighting, fire prevention, and emergency management. 
The fire chief shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. Upon termination of his/her service as fire chief, he/she shall, if appointed from the fire division, revert to his/her status in the classified civil service, provided, however, that if his/her service as fire chief is terminated because of impairment from habitual alcohol and/or drug use, or any misconduct involving moral turpitude or instances of misconduct as outlined in the personnel rules, he/she shall be subject to disciplinary action in his/her classified civil service status in the same manner as if such misconduct had been committed while he/she was serving in such status. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.17 - POWERS OF FIRE CHIEF/MANAGEMENT RIGHTS. 
(A)  General powers: The fire chief shall have exclusive control of the stationing and transfer of all firefighters and other employees in the fire division, under such general rules and regulations as the city manager prescribes. The fire chief shall have the right to suspend any of the officers or employees in the division and under his/her management and control, for incompetence, gross neglect of duty, gross immorality, impairment from habitual alcohol and/or drug use, failure to obey orders given to him/her by proper authority or for any other reasonable and just cause. Upon such suspension, the chief, forthwith, in writing shall certify such fact, together with the cause for such suspension, to the city manager, who within five (5) days from the receipt thereof, shall proceed to inquire into the cause of such suspension and render judgment therein, which judgment, if the charge be sustained, may be either suspension, reduction in rank or dismissal from the division. The city manager, in any such investigation, shall have the same powers to administer oaths and to secure the attendance of witnesses and the production of books and papers as are conferred upon the mayor by statute. 
(B)  Management rights: The city retains its rights, regardless of the frequency of exercise, to operate and manage its affairs in each and every respect, unless otherwise expressly provided in the collective bargaining agreement between the City of Upper Arlington and the International Association of Firefighters Local 1521. The rights reserved to the sole discretion of the City shall include, but not be limited, to the right: 
(1)  To direct the work of firefighters. 
(2)  To determine the mission of the fire division. 
(3)  To determine the size and composition of the work force. 
(4)  To suspend, discipline, or discharge firefighters for just cause. 
(5)  To relieve firefighters from duty because of lack of work or lack of funds. 
(6)  To take actions as may be necessary to carry out the mission of the fire division in emergencies. 
(7)  To hire, schedule, promote, demote, transfer, and assign firefighters. 
(8)  To recruit, select, and determine the qualifications and characteristics of new hires. 
(9)  To schedule or not schedule overtime as required in the manner most advantageous to the requirements of efficient governmental operations. 
(10)  To train or retrain firefighters as appropriate. 
(11)  To set standards for service to be offered to the public. 
(12)  To establish, modify, combine, or abolish job positions and classifications. 
(13)  To create, modify, or delete divisional rules and regulations; except as such changes may conflict with the collective bargaining agreement. 
(C)  Control of apparatus at fire: Police powers: At all fires, the ranking fire officer at the scene shall have the sole control and command over all the fire apparatus, and of employees of the fire division and shall give such orders and adopt such measures as he/she shall deem necessary for the extinguishing of the fire, protection of persons and property and the preservation of order for which purpose he shall have all the powers of a city police officer. 
(D)  Fire marshal: The chief of the fire division shall be the fire marshal of the city, and shall be in charge of the enforcement of the fire prevention code and other ordinances and laws relative to the prevention and control of fires and the investigation of causes of fires, suspected arson and similar crimes. He/she may detail one (1) or more members of the fire division to assist in the performance of said duties, who shall, while so detailed, be known as deputy fire marshals. The fire marshal and deputy fire marshals shall have all the powers of police officers in the police division. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.18 - ESTABLISHMENT OF A COMMUNITY EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAM (CERT). 
There may be created within the department of public safety a community emergency response team (CERT), the members of which shall be appointed by the city manager. 
Membership in, or appointment to CERT shall not confer employee status upon any person for any reason; and members of CERT are not subject to C.O. ch. 149, the rules and regulations of the Upper Arlington Municipal Civil Service Commission or to any provisions of the laws of the State of Ohio pertaining to civil service. 
Establishment of a community emergency response team (CERT) shall not prevent the fire chief and/or the city manager from seeking outside emergency assistance or utilizing mutual aid agreements previously established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.19 - QUALIFICATIONS AND TERMS OF CERT MEMBERS. 
(A)  Members of CERT shall be between their 21 st and 50 th birthdays at the date of initial appointment. Members may be reappointed beyond their 50 th birthday upon presentation of evidence of satisfactory physical condition acceptable to the city manager. 
(B)  CERT selection criteria will be similar to that used for full-time firefighters or employees with the exception that mandatory written tests are not required. 
(C)  Candidates will go before a board of review and will have a thorough background investigation prior to any appointment. 
(D)  The city manager may terminate any CERT appointment at any time. 
(E)  Members of CERT may resign their appointments at any time. 
(F)  Members of CERT shall retire from active status no later than the last day of the month in which such CERT member reaches his/her seventieth (70 th ) birthday. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.20 - DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF AND CITY MANAGER REGARDING CERT MEMBERS. 
The fire chief shall be the commanding officer of the community emergency response team (CERT) subject to the approval of the city manager and shall have control of the assignments, training, stationing, utilization, and the direction of work of such Team. 
The community emergency response team (CERT) shall be subject to call upon the order of the fire chief, and at all times when they are called upon to perform duties, to assist the fire division, they shall observe the rules, regulations and traditions of the regularly constituted fire division. CERT members shall obey the chain of command of the fire division and shall take orders from all regularly appointed officers thereof, including the rank of firefighter. 
The fire chief, with the approval of the city manager, shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the conduct and control of CERT. The rules shall prescribe, but not be limited to: 
(A)  Application and appointment procedures; 
(B)  Residency, medical, educational, psychological and moral character standards; 
(C)  Training requirements; 
(D)  Probationary status upon initial appointment; 
(E)  Uniform, insignia and equipment; 
(F)  Disciplinary procedures; 
(G)  Termination procedures; 
(H)  Required participation and tours of duty; 
(I)  The establishment and charter of the community emergency response team (CERT); and 
(J)  Any other rules necessary for the proper control and operation of CERT. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.21 - UNIFORMS FOR CERT MEMBERS. 
The city manager is authorized to prescribe the type of uniform or part thereof and insignia which shall be worn by members of CERT. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.22 - COMPENSATION FOR CERT MEMBERS. 
All services performed by the CERT shall be on a voluntary basis and without pay. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.23 - BONDING AND LIABILITY INSURANCE COVERAGE REGARDING CERT MEMBERS. 
(A)  The city manager shall insure that the members of CERT are extended the benefits of the Workers' Compensation Act available to the members of any organization, association or group of persons whose services are desired by the city, but whose members are not employees of the city as provided for by ORC § 4123.01 by means of a contract for such benefits with the Industrial Commission of Ohio as therein provided for, or as authorized by Ordinance No. 35-55, and any contracts entered into pursuant to such authorization. 
(B)  The city manager shall purchase liability insurance for any class of members of CERT, equal to that provided to full-time officers performing like functions. 
(C)  Members of CERT are to be bonded with the same coverage afforded to full-time officers providing like functions. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.24 - PURPOSE, LIABILITY OF CITY REGARDING CERT MEMBERS. 
The provisions of C.O. §§ 143.18 to 143.26 are declared to be an exercise by the city of its police powers for the protection of public peace, health, property, safety and general welfare, and neither the city nor any agent or representative of the city, nor any individual, firm, partnership or corporation, who in good faith executes any executive order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of C.O. §§ 143.18 to 143.26 shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to person or property as a result of such action. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.25 - EXECUTIVE ORDERS FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF CERT. 
The city manager is authorized and directed to promulgate such executive orders, rules and regulations as, in his/her discretion, are either necessary or desirable in the administration of CERT. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.26 - CONFLICT WITH OTHER LAWS REGARDING CERT. 
The provisions of chapter 143 regarding the community emergency response team shall not be construed as intended by council to be in conflict with any collective bargaining agreement, federal or state statute or with any lawful regulation promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.27 - ESTABLISHMENT OF A DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. 
The city may create, within the department of public safety, a division of emergency management to be established for the purpose of providing assistance to the people against enemy action and other disasters. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009; amended 3/16/11 Ord. No. 115-2010) 
§ 143.28 - COMPOSITION OF THE EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT DIVISION. 
If activated, the division of emergency management shall consist of a director and deputy director of emergency management and such other officers and employees as may be authorized by the city manager. 
Pursuant to C.O. § 143.01, the police or fire chief may, if so appointed by the city manager, serve as the director or deputy director of the division of emergency management. 
Such officers and employees as authorized by the city manager need not be current city officers or employees nor shall they be required to be residents of the city. 
Membership in, or appointment to the division of emergency management shall not confer employee status upon any person for any reason; and members of the division are not subject to C.O. ch. 149, the rules and regulations of the Upper Arlington Municipal Civil Service Commission or to any provisions of the laws of the State of Ohio pertaining to civil service. 
Membership in, or appointment to the division of emergency management shall not prevent the director and/or city manager from seeking outside emergency assistance or utilizing mutual aid agreements previously established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.29 - QUALIFICATIONS AND TERMS OF THE DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. 
(A)  Members of the division of emergency management shall be between their 21 st and 50 th birthdays at the date of initial appointment. Members may be reappointed beyond their 50 th birthday upon presentation of evidence of satisfactory physical condition acceptable to the city manager. 
(B)  Selection criteria will be similar to that used for full-time police and/or fire division officers or employees with the exception that mandatory written tests are not required. 
(C)  Candidates will go before a board of review and will have a thorough background investigation prior to any appointment. 
(D)  The city manager may terminate any division of emergency management appointment at any time. 
(E)  Members of the division of emergency management may resign their appointments at any time. 
(F)  Members of the division of emergency management shall retire from active status no later than the last day of the month in which such division member reaches his/her seventieth (70 th ) birthday. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.30 - DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR AND MEMBERS OF THE DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. 
The director shall be the commanding officer of the division of emergency management subject to the approval of the city manager and shall have control of the assignments, training, stationing, utilization, and the direction of work of such division. 
The division of emergency management shall be subject to call upon the order of the director, and at all times when they are called upon to perform duties to assist the city. They shall observe the rules, regulations and traditions of the regularly constituted police and fire divisions. division members shall obey the chain of command of the fire and/or police division and shall take orders from all regularly appointed officers thereof. 
The director, with the approval of the city manager, shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the conduct and control of the division of emergency management. The rules shall prescribe, but not be limited to: 
(A)  Application and appointment procedures; 
(B)  Residency, medical, education, psychological and moral character standards; 
(C)  Training requirements; 
(D)  Probationary status upon initial appointment; 
(E)  Uniform, insignia and equipment; 
(F)  Disciplinary procedures; 
(G)  Termination procedures; 
(H)  Required participation and tours of duty; 
(I)  The establishment and charter of the division of emergency management; and 
(J)  Any other rules necessary for the proper control and operation of the division. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.31 - UNIFORMS FOR DIVISION MEMBERS. 
The city manager is authorized to prescribe the type of uniform or part thereof and insignia which shall be worn by members of the division of emergency management. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.32 - COMPENSATION FOR DIVISION MEMBERS. 
All services performed by the division of emergency management shall be on a voluntary basis and without pay. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.33 - BONDING AND LIABILITY INSURANCE COVERAGE FOR THE DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT MEMBERS. 
(A)  The city manager shall insure that the members of the division of emergency management are extended the benefits of the Workers' Compensation Act available to the members of any organization, association or group of persons whose services are desired by the city, but whose members are not employees of the city as provided for by ORC § 4123.01 by means of a contract for such benefits with the Industrial Commission of Ohio as therein provided for, or as authorized by Ordinance No. 35-55, and any contracts entered into pursuant to such authorization. 
(B)  The city manager shall purchase liability insurance for any class of members of the division of emergency management, equal to that provided to full-time officers performing like functions. 
(C)  Members of the division of emergency management are to be bonded with the same coverage afforded to full-time officers providing like functions. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.34 - PURPOSE, LIABILITY OF CITY REGARDING DIVISION MEMBERS. 
The provisions of C.O. §§ 143.27 to 143.35 are declared to be an exercise by the city of its police powers for the protection of public peace, health, property, safety and general welfare, and neither the city nor any agent or representative of the city, nor any individual, firm, partnership or corporation, who is good faith executes any executive order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of C.O. §§ 143.27 to 143.35 shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to person or property as a result of such action. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.35 - EXECUTIVE ORDERS FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE DIVISION. 
The city manager is authorized and directed to promulgate such executive orders, rules and regulations as, in his/her discretion, are either necessary or desirable in the administration of the division of emergency management. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.36 - CONFLICT WITH OTHER LAWS REGARDING THE DIVISION. 
The provisions of chapter 143 shall not be construed as intended by council to be in conflict with any collective bargaining agreement, federal or state statute or with any lawful regulation promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.37 - POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR AND DEPUTY DIRECTOR OF THE DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT. 
The director of division of emergency management shall be the executive head of the division and, under the supervision and control of the city manager, shall have and exercise all powers and duties incident to the operation, regulation and government of such division, except as otherwise provided by charter or ordinance. The deputy director of division of emergency management is authorized to act for and in place of the director during any period of vacancy in the office of the director and during any absence or disability of the director. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
§ 143.38 - RESPONSE TO EMERGENCY CALLS FROM OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS. 
The city manager is authorized to establish rules and regulations for the response for manpower and equipment of the police and fire divisions and of other divisions, if required, to emergency calls from other political subdivisions in the Central Ohio area. Such regulations may include, without limitation, the determination of the source and type of calls to be answered, the amount of administrative personnel to implement such regulations and to order responses to such calls and such other matters as may be desirable and proper in connection therewith. 
(A)  There shall be no liability or responsibility on the part of this city, if a request for assistance is denied, or if the response is delayed or inadequate or for other circumstances arising in connection with the furnishing of such assistance. 
(B)  The question of compensation to this city for the furnishing of such assistance to a political subdivision with which no contract exists shall be determined by negotiation after the rendering of assistance, if the extent thereof, in the opinion of the city manager, justifies such compensation. 
(C)  All personnel of this city, including members of the police and fire divisions, responding to such calls for assistance shall be considered as acting within the scope of their employment while enroute to, and from, and while acting within the territory of the requesting political subdivisions, and shall be entitled to all benefits of fire and police pension funds, Workers' Compensation, or otherwise, to which they would be entitled, if acting within this city. 
(D)  The adoption of this ordinance shall not be deemed to limit the authority of members of the safety department to continue presently accepted practices of serving outside the city limits, as in the attempted apprehension of persons suspected of the commission of crimes within this city, the making of investigations or otherwise. 
(E)  The city manager is directed to undertake to make arrangements with other political subdivisions with which formal mutual aid contracts do not exist, for the adoption of reciprocal policies similar to those expressed in this ordinance for the extension of emergency assistance to this city. 
(F)  The city manager is further authorized to execute agreements on behalf of the city with other political subdivisions in Franklin County, for mutual aid for additional fire protection, which agreements shall provide for the interchange of service of fire departments and the use of fire fighting apparatus and other emergency equipment and personnel, pursuant to the provisions of ORC §§ 505.44, 9.60 and 2744.02. Such agreements shall comply with the provisions of C.O. §§ 143.37 and shall be subject to the approval of the city attorney as to form and legality. 
(Ord. No. 117-2009) 
CHAPTER 145. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICE 

§ 145.01 - ESTABLISHMENT. 
There is created a department of public service which shall be administered by the city manager, who shall have and exercise all authority and powers conferred upon a director of public service by law. 
§ 145.02 - DIVISIONS WITHIN DEPARTMENT. 
    The following divisions are created within the department of public service: 
(A)  Engineering division. 
(B)  Public works division. 
(Ord. No. 115-2010, 3-16-2011; Ord. No. 39-2015, § 2, 6-22-2015 ; Ord. No. 75-2015, § 1, 11-23-2015 ) 
§ 145.03 - ADMINISTRATION. 
The director of public services, under the general supervision and control of the city manager, shall develop administrative procedures and regulations to carry out the responsibilities conferred upon the department of public service. 
(Ord. No. 115-2010, 3-16-2011) 
CHAPTER 147. - BOARD OF HEALTH 

§ 147.01 - ESTABLISHMENT. 
(A)  The City of Upper Arlington shall be a city health district. The Upper Arlington Board of Health is created for the city and shall be composed of five (5) members. 
(B)  If the city has not contracted for health services pursuant to ORC ch. 3709, then the Upper Arlington Board shall administer the city health district and have all the powers and duties conferred by statute. The board of health shall be composed of four (4) members appointed by the president of council and confirmed by city council and one (1) member appointed by the health district licensing council established under ORC § 3709.41. The term of office of the members shall be five (5) years from the date of appointment, except that of those first appointed one shall serve five (5) years, one for four (4) years, one for three (3) years, one for two (2) years, and one for one (1) year, and thereafter one shall be appointed each year. The members shall be compensated pursuant to ORC § 3709.05. 
(C)  If the city has contracted for health services pursuant to ORC ch. 3709, then the board of health shall act in an advisory capacity to the council and to the entity providing such health services. The board of health shall be composed of five (5) members appointed by the president of council and confirmed by council, to serve without compensation. The president of council, by virtue of his/her office, shall be president of the board. 
(D)  Any and all references in the City Code to the board of health shall mean the entity actually performing the duties required of a board of health of a city health district pursuant to ORC § 3709.05. 
CHAPTER 149. - CIVIL SERVICE 

§ 149.01 - CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION; APPOINTMENT, TERM, REMOVAL. 
Council shall appoint three (3) electors of the city as civil service commissioners, who shall be residents of the city and/or the Upper Arlington School District at the time of appointment and for the duration of their term of service. The members of the existing civil service commission shall continue in office for the terms for which they were appointed. Thereafter, members of the civil service commission shall be appointed to serve for a term of four (4) years and shall expire on the last day of February. Appointments shall commence on the date the appointment is approved by council or such other date provided by council. Any member appointed to fill a vacancy occurring prior to the expiration of the term shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of said term. 
Council may at any time remove any commissioner from office if and when he/she no longer meets the residency requirement. 
Council may at any time remove any commissioner for inefficiency, neglect of duty, incompetence or malfeasance in office, having first given to such commissioner a copy of the charges against him/her and an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel in his/her own defense. 
(Ord. No. 8-2013) 
§ 149.02 - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES. 
The commission shall designate one of its members as president, shall appoint a secretary and such other officers and employees as it may determine to be necessary and as council may approve. 
§ 149.03 - CLASSIFICATION. 
The civil service of the city is hereby divided into the unclassified and the classified service. 
(A)  The unclassified service shall include: 
(1)  All officers elected by the people; 
(2)  All officers and employees appointed by council, and all members of boards and commissions appointed by the president of council or by council; 
(3)  Each director of a department, and the deputies and/or assistants of the department head. Assistants includes, but is not limited to, management assistants; 
(4)  Appointed officials; 
(5)  One (1) secretary/administrative assistant for each of the following: 
(a)  The city manager, 
(b)  The city clerk, 
(c)  The city attorney, 
(d)  Each department of municipal government, 
(e)  Each division within a department, and 
(f)  Each board or commission appointed by council, or by the president of council with council's approval. 
(6)  The chief building inspector and building inspectors; 
(7)  All positions appointed by the city attorney; 
(8)  Community affairs director and community affairs coordinator; 
(9)  The payroll administrator; 
(10)  The deputies and assistants of elected or principal executive officers holding a fiduciary relation to such principals; and 
(11)  All part-time employees and all persons who receive interim, temporary, or intermittent appointments. 
(B)  The classified service shall comprise all positions not specifically included by this ordinance in the unclassified service. There shall be in the classified service two (2) classes, to be known as the competitive class and the noncompetitive class: 
(1)  The competitive class shall include all positions and employments for which it is practicable to determine the merit and fitness of applicants by competitive examinations. 
(2)  The noncompetitive class shall consist of all positions requiring peculiar and exceptional qualifications of a scientific, managerial, professional or educational character and unskilled positions for which it is impracticable to give competitive examinations, as may be determined by the rules of the commission. 
(C)  The civil service commission shall prescribe such reasonable requirements as they shall deem necessary as to age, sex, citizenship, physical condition, educational background and moral character for all candidates, eligibles and employees in the classified service. They shall conduct such examinations as they may deem necessary in order to determine that such requirements are met and maintained. 
§ 149.04 - RULES. 
The commission shall prescribe, amend and enforce the civil service rules and keep its proceedings and records of its examinations concerning the enforcement and effect of the civil service provisions and the rules thereunder. If there is a conflict between the civil service rules and ORC ch. 124, the rules shall supersede chapter 124; provided, that the rules may not supersede the City Charter or the Upper Arlington Codified Ordinances. The commission shall make an annual report to council. The rules shall provide for but are not limited to any requirements mandated by ORC ch. 124. 
§ 149.05 - PROBATIONARY APPOINTMENTS. 
(A)  All original and promotional appointments shall be for a probationary period of one (1) year. 
(B)  The one-year probationary period for original appointments of police officers shall begin on the date of appointment or the date of certification pursuant to ORC § 109.77, whichever occurs later. 
(C)  The commission may extend the probationary period for up to one hundred eighty (180) additional days upon the request of the appointing authority for good cause, unless otherwise provided in any applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
(D)  No appointment or promotion shall be deemed finally made until the employee has satisfactorily served his probationary period. 
All original and promotional appointments shall be for a probationary period one (1) year; except as to original appointments or promotion in the police and fire divisions. The probationary period shall be one (1) year for firefighters and one (1) year from the date of certification or promotion for police officers, pursuant to ORC § 109.77. The commission may extend the probationary period for up to one hundred eighty (180) additional days upon the request of the appointing authority for good cause. 
No appointment or promotion shall be deemed finally made until the employee has satisfactorily served his probationary period. 
( Ord. No. 62-2014, § 1, 11-24-2014 ) 
§ 149.06 - APPEALS. 
Any employee of the city in the classified service, other than a probationary employee, who is suspended, discharged or reduced in rank or compensation for disciplinary reasons, may appeal, in writing, from such disciplinary decision to the civil service commission within ten (10) days from and after the date of such decision or order. In such event, the commission shall forthwith notify the official issuing the disciplinary decision for the suspension, discharge or reduction in rank or compensation. The official, shall forthwith transmit to the commission a copy of the charges and proceedings supporting the disciplinary decision. The commission shall hear such appeal within thirty (30) days from and after the filing of the same with the commission and may affirm, disaffirm or modify the action of such officer. 
§ 149.07 - EXAMINATIONS. 
All examinations shall be practical and impartial and shall relate to those matters which will fairly test the relative capacity of the persons examined to discharge the duties of the position for which appointment is sought. Such examinations shall pertain to local departmental practices. The commission shall consult with department and division heads to obtain information needed for preparation of examinations. 
§ 149.08 - APPOINTMENTS. 
(A)  When a position in the competitive classified service is to be filled, the appointing authority shall notify the commission or its secretary of that fact. The commission or secretary shall certify to the appointing authority the names of all candidates on the eligible list for the class or grade to which such position belongs. Except as provided for exceptional appointments authorized by ORC § 124.30 and promotional appointments, the appointing authority shall appoint one (1) of the top ten (10) names on the eligible list or in the top twenty-five percent (25%) of the eligible list, whichever is greater. Where more than one position is to be filled, the commission may certify additional names as necessary to carry out the purposes of this section. When fewer than ten (10) names are certified to an appointing authority for an original appointment, appointment from the list shall not be mandatory. 
(B)  In the case of promotion, the commission or secretary shall certify to the appointing authority the names of the three (3) candidates standing highest on the eligible list for the class or grade to which such position belongs. The appointing authority shall appoint one (1) of the three (3) persons to such position. 
(C)  The commission may also adopt rules allowing for the removal from the list of a person who has been certified to the appointing authority more than three (3) times and has not been selected. 
(D)  (1)  In case of an emergency, an appointing authority may make an appointment without regard to this chapter or ORC §§ 124.01 through 124.64, but in no case to continue longer that one hundred twenty (120) days, and in no case shall successive appointments be made. The commission may except such appointments from the application of its rules. 
(2)  Where the services to be rendered by an appointee are for a temporary period, not to exceed six (6) months, and the need of such service is important and urgent, the appointing authority may select for such temporary service any person on the proper list of those eligible for permanent appointment. 
(3)  Where the services to be rendered by an employee are for seasonal employment, the appointing authority may, but is not required to, select from among persons honorably separated from the previous season. Alternatively, or in addition, the appointing authority may select from among applicants who apply for seasonal employment during an application period established by the appointing authority. Seasonal appointments are temporary appointments. 
(E)  The commission may also provide in its rules for interim and intermittent appointments, and for the suspension of competitive examinations the ORC §§ 124.01 through 124.64 for the reasons and under the circumstances set forth in ORC § 124.30(A)(2). 
(Ord. No. 8-2013) 
§ 149.10 - PAYROLLS CERTIFIED. 
It shall be unlawful for the treasurer or other public disbursing officer to pay any salary or compensation for service to any person holding a position in the classified service unless the payroll or account for such salary or compensation shall bear the certificate of the commission that the persons named therein have been appointed or employed in accordance with the provisions of this ordinance and of the rules established thereunder. 
Where estimates, payrolls, or accounts are prepared by electronic data processing equipment, the commission may develop methods for controlling the input or verifying the output of such equipment to ensure compliance with the Upper Arlington Codified Ordinances governing civil service, any provisions of ORC ch. 124 made applicable by the rules of the commission, and the rules of the commission adopted thereunder. 
§ 149.11 - INVESTIGATIONS AND HEARING. 
In any investigation or hearing conducted by the commission it shall have the power to subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses and the production of books and papers pertinent to the investigation and to administer oaths to such witnesses. 
§ 149.12 - POLITICAL BELIEFS. 
No person in the classified service or seeking admission thereto shall be appointed, reduced, laid off, discharged or in any way favored or discriminated against because of his political opinions or affiliations. 
§ 149.13 - POLITICAL ACTIVITY. 
All persons in the civil service are subject to the provisions of C.O. ch. 105. 
§ 149.14 - PAYMENT FOR APPOINTMENT OR PROMOTION. 
No applicant for appointment or promotion in the classified service shall, directly or indirectly, pay or promise to pay any money or other valuable thing, nor shall he ask or receive any recommendation or assistance from any person upon the consideration of any political service to be rendered, for or on account of his appointment or promotion, or proposed appointment or promotion. 
§ 149.15 - ABUSE OF POLITICAL INFLUENCE. 
No person who holds any public office, or who has been nominated for or seeks a nomination, election or appointment to any public office shall use or promise to use, either directly or indirectly, any official authority or influence in order to secure or aid any person in securing for himself or another any office or employment in the classified service, or any promotion or increase of salary therein, as a reward for political influence or service, or for service in behalf of any candidate. No person shall, by means of threats or coercion, induce or seek to induce anyone in the classified service to resign his position or to waive his right to certification, appointment or promotion. 
§ 149.16 - FRAUDS IN EXAMINATIONS. 
No person or officer shall, by himself, or in cooperation with one (1) or more persons, willfully or corruptly deceive or obstruct any person in his right to be examined for admission to the service of the city or the city school district; or falsely or corruptly mark, grade or report upon the examination or proper standing of any person examined for appointment in the civil service, or aid in so doing; or willfully or corruptly make any false representation as to the results of such examination or concerning the person so examined; or willfully or corruptly furnish to any person special or secret information for the purpose of either improving or injuring the prospects or chances of any person so examined or to be examined or to be appointed, employed or promoted; or willfully impersonate any other person or permit or aid any other person to impersonate him in connection with any examination or registration, application or appointment, or request to be examined or registered; or make known or assist in making known to any applicant for examination, any question to be asked on such examination; or willfully violate any of the provisions of this chapter. 
§ 149.17 - VIOLATION OF ORDINANCE OR RULE. 
After a rule has been duly established by the civil service commission, pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, no person shall make an appointment to office or select a person for employment contrary to such rule, or willfully refuse or neglect to comply with or to conform to the provisions of this chapter. If any person who is convicted of violating this section holds any public office or place of public employment, such office or position shall, by virtue of such conviction, be rendered vacant. 
§ 149.18 - GENERAL LAWS INAPPLICABLE. 
The general laws of Ohio, except the constitution, shall not apply to the civil service of this city, except to the extent that they may be made applicable by ordinance or by rule of the civil service commission duly adopted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
§ 149.99 - PENALTY. 
(A)  Whoever violates C.O. §§ 149.12, 149.13, 149.14, 149.15 and 149.17 is guilty of a civil service violation, a misdemeanor of the first degree. The court shall impose a mandatory fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which shall not be suspended. 
(B)  In addition to any criminal penalty, any person in the civil service who violates this chapter or C.O. ch. 105 shall also be subject to disciplinary action which may include termination. 
CHAPTER 151. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

§ 151.01 - ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP. 
There is hereby established a city parks and recreation advisory board, consisting of the seven members appointed by the president of council and confirmed by council . The city manager and the parks and recreation department director shall serve as ex-officio members of the advisory board. 
( Ord. No. 14-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 151.02 - TERMS OF OFFICE. 
(A)  The seven (7) members shall be appointed for, four-year terms ending on the last day of September of the term's final year. The terms will be staggered so that three (3) members will be appointed every-other odd-numbered year, and four (4) members will be appointed every-other even-numbered year. City council may shorten or lengthen a particular term at the time of appointment to maintain this staggered rotation. The director may request the president of council renew an appointment for additional terms. Appointments for the purpose of filling vacancies occurring otherwise than by expiration of terms shall be made for the unexpired term by the president of council and confirmed by council. All board members shall be residents of the City of Upper Arlington. 
(B)  Vacancies, absence from three (3) consecutive regular meetings shall operate to vacate the term of the member, unless such absence is authorized or excused by vote of the board and approved by the city manager. Any term thus vacated, or vacated by resignation, shall be filled by appointment of the president of council, subject to confirmation by the council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 23-2014; Ord. No. 14-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 151.03 - ORGANIZATION AND PROCEDURE. 
(A)  The parks and recreation advisory board shall elect its own chairperson and establish its own rules of organization and procedure for the conduct of its meetings. The rules shall not conflict with the City Charter, this chapter, the rules of council, or state law and shall be generally in accordance with Roberts Rules of Order. All Rules shall be submitted to the city clerk and kept on file. 
(B)  The board shall meet at the call of the chairperson, the director of parks and recreation, the city manager, or council. The city clerk shall appoint a person to record board minutes. The board may invite from time to time members of the public including those representing department related committees to speak on various topics. 
(C)  Recommendations by the board may be provided to council, the city manager, or the parks and recreation director. 
( Ord. No. 14-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 151.04 - DUTIES. 
The parks and recreation advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity to the director, city manager or city council. The purpose of the board is to provide input and discuss park, recreational, and cultural arts services and facilities. The board shall also serve as ambassadors for the city by soliciting input from the community and by educating our citizens and facility users regarding the services provided by the department. If so directed by the director or city council, the board shall receive public input and consider matters pertaining to acquisition, development, improvement and management of parks, parkstrips and other city property. The board may also receive input on matters pertaining to recreational programs and facilities in the community, the need for improvement and extension thereof, the need and feasibility of additional recreation facilities and methods of financing the same. It shall also facilitate, as necessary, updates or reports from the chairperson or designee of each of the boards, commissions or councils related to the parks and recreation department. The board shall perform such other duties relative to the department and programs as delegated by city council or the director. 
( Ord. No. 14-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
CHAPTER 152. - UPPER ARLINGTON CULTURAL ARTS COMMISSION 

§ 152.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
(A)  The terms cultural arts and arts, as used herein include but are not necessarily limited to music, literature, the theater, including motion pictures, the dance, painting, sculpture, photography, architecture, graphics and fabric design. 
(B)  Commission means the Upper Arlington Cultural Arts Commission created by this chapter of the Codified Ordinances. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 152.02 - ESTABLISHMENT AND MEMBERSHIP. 
(A)  Establishment: There is hereby established and created the Upper Arlington Cultural Arts Commission. 
(B)  Membership: The commission shall consist of the following members: 
(1)  Seven (7) regular members appointed by the president of council, subject to approval of council, for three-year terms. City council may shorten or lengthen a particular term at the time of appointment to maintain a staggered rotation so that not more than three members' terms expire in the same year. All commission members shall be residents of the City of Upper Arlington. 
(2)  Liaison consultants may be invited by the chairperson of the commission and approved by the director of parks and recreation and city. Any public agency or organization or private association whose membership is open to the general public may nominate one of their members to represent their organization and attend the commission meetings when invited. Student liaison consultants representing any public school shall be nominated by the board of education or designee. Any person nominated, as above, may be invited as liaison consultants by the chairperson of the commission and approved by the director of parks and recreation and the city manager. In addition, the chairperson may invite any individual, in an individual capacity, to address the commission based on their expertise in the area of cultural arts. Liaison consultants and invitees do not have voting rights and serve at the pleasure of the director of parks and recreation and city manager. 
(3)  The director of parks and recreation may serve as executive secretary, appointed by, and serving at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(C)  Terms: 
(1)  Terms shall commence the first day of June, and expire the last day of May. 
(2)  Vacancies, absence from three (3) consecutive regular meetings shall operate to vacate the term of the member, unless such absence is authorized or excused by vote of the commission and approved by the executive secretary. Any term thus vacated, or vacated by resignation, shall be filled by appointment by the president of council, subject to approval of council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 152.03 - PURPOSE, DUTIES, AND OBJECTIVES. 
(A)  The purpose of the commission is to foster and encourage the development and preservation of the arts in this community. 
(B)  The duties and objectives of the commission shall include the following: 
(1)  To preserve the art resources of the community and to share them with the entire community. 
(2)  To develop awareness and appreciation of the arts in persons of all ages. 
(3)  To encourage and support emerging arts organizations which give promise of fulfilling the needs of residents of this community for exposure to and participation in cultural arts activities. 
(4)  To promote and support professional artists. Professional artist means a person who devoted a major portion of his/her time to practicing, performing or teaching any of the arts. 
(5)  To provide an atmosphere where artist and audience can work together to preserve the citizens' cultural heritage while discovering their artistic potential. 
(6)  In carrying out its stated objectives, the commission shall not be restricted to the geographical limits of this city, but may cooperate with other groups serving the Mid-Ohio area in any aspect of the cultural arts which is approved by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 152.04 - EXECUTIVE SECRETARY-DUTIES AND POWERS. 
(A)  The executive secretary shall implement the policies and programs of the commission by the development of cultural arts programs and the allocation and utilization of resources, at his/her discretion, made available to the commission from any source whatsoever, to ensure that the interests of the community and the City of Upper Arlington are safeguarded. 
(B)  The executive secretary shall be empowered to act in the name of the commission between regular meetings of the commission. He/she shall report any such actions to the commission at its next regular meeting. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 152.05 - ARTS MANAGER. 
The arts manager shall assist the commission with the duties outlined in C.O. § 152.03 and shall perform other duties as the executive secretary may prescribe. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 152.06 - ORGANIZATION AND PROCEDURE. 
(A)  Regulations: The commission shall establish its own rules of organization and procedure for the conduct of its business. The rules shall not conflict with the provisions of the City Charter, this chapter, the Rules of Council, or state law and shall be generally in accordance with the Rules of Council and Roberts Rules of Order. All rules shall be submitted to the city clerk and kept on file. 
(B)  Meetings: The commission shall meet monthly, unless otherwise directed by a majority vote of the commission, and shall give public notice of its meetings. The director of parks and recreation may cancel a meeting at any time and provide adequate notice to the commission of the cancellation. 
(C)  Organization: The commission shall elect officers as prescribed in the by-laws at its regularly scheduled meeting in June of each calendar year, with the terms to commence in July. 
(D)  Voting and quorum: The voting members of the commission shall be the regular members of the commission as provided in C.O. § 152.02(B)(1). Four (4) regular members shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of any business to come before the commission. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 152.07 - ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT. 
    The city manager may provide administrative support to the commission in the performance of its functions to the extent that resources are available. 
( Ord. No. 13-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
CHAPTER 153. - PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT 

§ 153.01 - ESTABLISHMENT. 
There is created a department of parks and recreation, which shall be administered by the director of parks and recreation, under the general supervision and control of the city manager. The director of parks and recreation shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the city manager. Subject to the supervision and control of the city manager, the director shall be the executive head of the several divisions of the department of parks and recreation. 
§ 153.02 - USE OF MUNICIPAL TENNIS COURTS. 
(A)  Regulations: The city manager shall be authorized to adopt such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary or desirable for the operation of the tennis courts and the tennis program to include establishment of fees, which rules shall be on file in the department of parks and recreation. 
CHAPTER 154. - MEDICAL ADVISORY BOARD 

§ 154.01 - CREATION OF MEDICAL ADVISORY BOARD. 
(A)  There is hereby established the Upper Arlington Medical Advisory Board, the function of which shall be to provide on-going professional supervision, training and support of the city's emergency para-medical program, which program is one of the functions of the fire division. Said board shall consist of seven (7) members, who shall be appointed by the president of council, subject to the approval of the council, for four (4) year terms, except as otherwise provided herein. At least two-thirds (?) of the membership of said board shall be physicians licensed to practice in the State of Ohio. Members who are not physicians shall be persons who are qualified and active in areas directly related to the practice of medicine, such as hospital administration or the development and operation of life supportive medical equipment. All board members shall be residents of the City of Upper Arlington. 
(B)  Terms shall commence the first day of February, and expire the last day of January. City council may shorten or lengthen a particular term at the time of appointment to maintain a staggered rotation so that not more than three members' terms expire in the same year. 
(C)  Vacancies, absence from three (3) consecutive regular meetings shall operate to vacate the term of the member, unless such absence is authorized or excused by vote of the board and approved by the city manager. Any term thus vacated, or vacated by resignation, shall be filled by appointment of the president of council, subject to the approval of the council for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
( Ord. No. 12-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
§ 154.02 - ORGANIZATION AND PROCEDURE. 
(A)  The medical advisory board shall annually elect a chairman, a vice chairman and such other officers as it shall consider necessary. It shall establish its own rules of organization and procedure for the conduct of its business. The rules shall not conflict with the provisions of the City Charter, this chapter, the rules of council, or state law and shall be generally in accordance with Roberts Rules of Order. All rules shall be submitted to the city clerk and kept on file. The board shall meet on such dates as may, from time to time, be determined by it. 
(B)  The city manager shall upon request of the board, appoint a secretary to serve the board, shall provide such facilities for the meetings and activities of the board as may be available, shall offer to the board the services of members of his staff and other employees of the city who may be of assistance to the board, to the extent that such personnel are available, and shall in all other respects cooperate with the board in the performance of its functions to the extent that the same are not inconsistent with his other duties. 
(C)  Members of the board shall serve without compensation, but shall be entitled to reimbursement for actual, reasonable expenses incurred in connection with their official duties upon the approval of the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 12-2016, § 1, 3-14-2016 ) 
CHAPTER 155. - PERSONNEL CODE 

§ 155.01. - DEFINITIONS. 
(A)  Anniversary date. For non-bargaining unit employees, anniversary date shall be January 1 st unless otherwise determined by the city manager. 
(B)  Applicant. A person requesting consideration for employment in a class in the classified service or unclassified service. 
(C)  Appointing authority. The officer (meaning, for purposes of defining "appointing authority," the city manager, city clerk, or city attorney as provided elsewhere in the City Charter or Upper Arlington Codified Ordinances), commission, board or body having the power of appointment to, or removal from a position in the classified service and unclassified service. 
(D)  Class or (classification). A group of positions with the same descriptive title having similar duties and responsibilities and requiring similar qualifications which can be distinguished from other groups of positions (e.g., administrative assistant). There may be only one position in a particular class (e.g., police chief). 
(E)  Class series. As adopted by the civil service commission, two (2) or more classes which are similar as to type of work but which differ as to degree of responsibility, difficulty, complexity, skill and/or technical knowledge and which have been arranged in a ladder of steps in a normal line of promotion. 
(F)  Classified service positions. Positions in the service of the city subject to examination and not specifically excluded and placed in unclassified service. 
(G)  Continuous service. The length of service as a full-time employee uninterrupted by resignation, retirement, discharge for cause or any other separation from city employment. Military leave, leave resulting from injury in the line of duty, leave for approved disability coverage, authorized leave without pay or administrative leave without pay for periods of six (6) weeks or less are not considered separation from city service. 
(H)  Department. Any department, office, commission, board or other body as defined under the City Charter or Upper Arlington Codified Ordinances. 
(I)  Eligible. A person who has satisfactorily met all qualifications and requirements for employment in the job class for which the person has made application and whose name should appear on an eligible list. 
(J)  Full-time employee. An employee that is scheduled to work not less than forty (40) hours per seven (7) consecutive calendar days. 
(K)  Health care provider. A licensed doctor of medicine or osteopathy or other person providing health services who is licensed or certified under federal or state law or any other person determined by the Secretary of Labor to be capable of providing health care services. 
(L)  Immediate family. Parents, parents-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, spouse, children, brothers, sisters, grandparents unless otherwise specified. 
(M)  Permanent part-time employee. Any employee working less than forty (40) hours per week and having been hired with the intention of working on an ongoing basis until an appropriate reason for termination of employment arises. 
(N)  Position. Any office, employment or job calling for the performance of certain duties and the exercise of certain responsibilities by one (1) individual. A position may be vacant or occupied (part-time or full-time) and it may be designated regular, part-time, seasonal, etc. 
(O)  Resignation. Voluntary separation from employment. 
(P)  Retirement. An employee separation from city service that is not by resignation, layoff, or discharge, where the separating employee's application for retirement benefits has been approved by the retirement system and the separating employee will receive payment of retirement benefits in accordance with an approved retirement immediately upon separation from city employment. Retirement shall not mean someone who is eligible but has not formally filed for retirement and has not been approved to receive retirement benefits. 
(Q)  Seasonal/temporary employee. Any employee hired to work forty (40) hours or less per week (or more than forty (40) hours, if the need arises) for a specified short term or interim period of time. 
(R)  Senior executive. Those individuals who are department heads and/or positions designated by the city manager. 
(S)  Shared position. A shared position exists only if one (1) full-time position is authorized and more than one (1) person shares the position's responsibilities providing that the hours do not exceed forty (40) in any one (1) week. 
(T)  Workday. A regularly scheduled working time assigned by a supervisor or manager. 
(U)  Workweek. A regularly recurring period of seven (7), twenty-four (24) hour days consisting of five (5) workdays of eight (8) hours per day and two (2) days off or four (4) days of ten (10) hours per day and three (3) days off except in the case of firefighters where they may work twenty-four (24) hours every seventy-two (72) hours. 
(Ord. No. 118-2009; Ord. No. 6-2012; Ord. No. 7-2013) 
§ 155.02 - COMPENSATION. 
(A)  The compensation plan is designed as a fair and equitable method for payment of employees in the city with a target market rate of 103%, inclusive of any public employees retirement system (PERS) pickup. The plan shall establish a basic salary schedule as approved by the city council. The salary schedule shall include minimum and maximum rates of pay for all positions included in the classification plan. In addition to the basic salary schedule, the compensation plan consists of two (2) components. These two (2) components, market adjustments and performance award, shall be used to determine the employee compensation. 
(1)  Market adjustment: The market adjustment is the component that is used to insure that the salary schedule is adjusted equally across-the-board to reflect changes in the wage index. Three (3) considerations, not all inclusive, dictate whether or not a wage adjustment will be administered: changes in union contract positions which cause salary compression with positions not covered by the contract, changes in the wage index based upon the Bureau of Labor Statistics wage index for state and local governments (BLS wage index) and the budgetary constraints of the city. Each year city council may vote on wage adjustment(s) to the salary schedule; a percentage increase will be applied to the salary ranges as determined by council. City council may utilize the BLS wage index to determine any wage adjustment (s) to the salary schedule. 
(2)  Performance award: The performance award component is designed to reward job performance, therefore, serving as an incentive system. Base salary increases and bonuses are awarded to employees whose performance is evaluated as consistently competent, satisfactory and/or exceed expectations. The performance appraisal is essential to the effective utilization of this component. The merit system is based upon the principle that satisfactory, or above, performance should be rewarded because such performance is a greater contribution to the city than unsatisfactory. The performance award is strictly used to monetarily reward satisfactory or above satisfactory performance. 
(B)  Employees shall be paid a salary or wage based on the salary range for their position as set forth in the salary schedule adopted by city council. Salary increases from the performance award component shall be effective beginning in the payroll period that includes the employee's anniversary date. The resulting salary shall not exceed the maximum rate for the position. New employees shall not be entitled to a salary increase from the performance award component unless they have been employed by the city for at least six (6) months. 
(C)  Permanent part-time employment: The same principles, which apply to the compensation plan for full-time regular employees shall determine salary procedures for permanent part-time employees. 
(D)  It shall be the responsibility of the appointing authority to implement the performance appraisal process by conducting or having conducted, an appraisal of performance. 
(E)  The pay schedule of all employees, except city council members, shall be on a bi-weekly basis. The pay schedule of city council members shall be on a monthly basis. 
(F)  The entry level of pay for all positions shall be recommended to the appointing authority or determined by the appointing authority at the amount necessary to employ that applicant with the best overall set of qualifications, as determined by the employment process. 
(G)  Employees shall be compensated for overtime, as follows: 
(1)  Employees working a forty-hour work week, at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) times their regular hourly rate. 
(2)  All overtime compensation shall be by cash payment unless the employee elects to receive compensatory time off in accordance with this section. An eligible full-time employee, prior to performing overtime, may elect to receive compensatory time in lieu of the cash payment. For seasonal and part-time employees, the city expressly reserves its right to require compensation of overtime by cash payment in the manner provided in C.O. § 155.02(G)(1). No one should coerce or pressure the employee to receive compensatory time instead of the cash payment. Such compensatory time shall not exceed a total accumulation over two hundred forty (240) hours. Any overtime compensation earned in excess of the two hundred forty-hour limitation or earned during the month of December shall be by cash payment. The use of compensatory time shall be approved in advance by the department head or designee. All compensatory time that has not been used by December 1 st of each year shall be paid by cash payment at the rate of pay in effect in the first December pay period unless otherwise approved by the appointing authority. An employee may be permitted to carry over compensatory time to the following year upon approval by the appointing authority. 
(H)  Reinstated employees: A reinstated employee shall be paid at a salary rate within the approved salary range for the position in which the employee is reinstated. The salary level in the range will be related to, but not limited to, such factors as performance, experience and length of previous service in the jurisdiction and shall be set by the city manager. 
(I)  Temporary work at a higher classification: An employee assigned temporarily to a position of higher classification shall be compensated at the minimum of that class or seven percent (7%) above the employee's present rate, whichever is higher, for all hours worked at the higher classification, provided a minimum of sixteen (16) consecutive hours are worked in the higher class. 
(J)  The city manager shall maintain a performance bonus program not to exceed .0066 of non-union wages as an incentive for highly meritorious service. The performance bonus may include, but is not limited to, a certificate of appreciation to a cash payment. 
(K)  The city manager shall maintain a discretionary fund to be used for acts of appreciation to employee teams, not to exceed .001 of total wages. 
(L)  The city manager shall have the authority to make salary adjustments within the established ranges, exclusive of the collective bargaining agreements, for good cause shown and to ensure that the goal of a fair and equitable compensation system is properly administered. 
(Ord. No. 6-2012; Ord. No. 6-2012, 2-13-2012; Ord. No. 54-2013) 
§ 155.03 - HOLIDAYS. 
(A)  The following days are declared paid holidays from which the full-time employees will be excused from work at the regular rate of pay: 
New Year's Day: January 1 
Martin Luther King Day: Third Monday in January 
President's Day: Third Monday in February 
Memorial Day: Last Monday in May 
Independence Day: July 4 
Labor Day: First Monday in September 
Veteran's Day: November 11 
Thanksgiving Day: Fourth Thursday in November 
Christmas Day: December 25 
(B)  When any holiday listed above falls on Saturday, the preceding work day shall be considered the holiday. When the holiday falls on a Sunday, the following work day shall be considered the holiday. 
(C)  In order for an employee to be entitled to a holiday, he must have actually worked on the day before and the day after the holiday unless utilizing permissible leave time such as vacation, sick leave (see sick leave policy), bereavement leave, jury duty or personal day. 
(D)  When any holiday listed above falls while an employee is on approved vacation time, such holiday shall not be charged against vacation leave. 
(E)  In the event the federal and state governments shall designate a day of the week for any of the holidays specified above, then said day shall be observed in accordance with said designation. 
(F)  Each full-time employee who is required to work on a day designated as a holiday shall, in addition to receiving eight (8) hours pay for the holiday, be paid at the rate of one and one-half (11/2) times his hourly rate of pay for all hours worked on the holiday. 
(G)  If an employee's work schedule is other than Monday through Friday, he shall be entitled to holiday pay for holidays observed on his day off regardless of the day of the week on which they are observed. 
(H)  Each full-time employee working four (4) workdays of ten (10) hours per day shall be paid eight (8) hours pay for a holiday. The employee has the option of supplementing the remaining two (2) hours with personal leave, vacation leave or compensatory time. Leave without pay will be charged, if the employee chooses not to supplement the remaining two (2) hours, or if no time is available to supplement the two (2) hours. 
§ 155.04 - PERSONAL LEAVE. 
(A)  Each full-time employee shall be credited with forty (40) hours of personal leave each year. An employee, after approval by his supervisor, may use personal leave, for absence due to mandatory court appearances, legal or business matters, family emergencies, unusual family obligations, medical appointments, weddings, religious holidays or any other matter of a personal nature. 
(B)  When personal leave is used, it shall be deducted from the unused balance in increments of one (1) hour. 
(C)  A newly appointed full-time employee shall receive personal leave based on the following schedule: 
Hire Month Number of Personal Leave Hours in First Calendar Year January, February 40 hours March, April 32 hours May, June 24 hours July, August 16 hours September, October 8 hours November, December 0 hours  
(D)  Any unused personal leave remaining after the last payroll period of the same fiscal year or when an employee terminates his/her employment shall lapse. 
§ 155.05 - VACATION TIME. 
(A)  Each full-time employee plans shall accrue vacation based on the following schedule: 
(1)  Full-time employees hired before January 1, 2011. 
(a)  At the rate of 3.077 hours per pay period after one (1) year of continuous service for an annual rate of eighty (80) hours. 
(b)  At the rate of 4.615 hours per pay period after five (5) years of continuous service for an annual rate of one hundred twenty (120) hours. 
(c)  At the rate of 5.385 hours per pay period after ten (10) years of continuous service for an annual rate of one hundred forty (140) hours. 
(d)  At the rate of 6.154 hours per pay period after thirteen (13) years of continuous service for an annual rate of one hundred sixty (160) hours. 
(e)  At the rate of an additional 0.308 hours per pay period for each additional three (3) years of continuous service for an annual rate of an additional eight (8) hours. 
(2)  Full-time employees hired after January 1, 2011. 
(a)  At the rate of 3.077 hours per pay period after one (1) year of continuous service for an annual rate of eighty (80) hours. 
(b)  At the rate of 4.615 hours per pay period after five (5) years of continuous service for an annual rate of one hundred twenty (120) hours. 
(B)  Vacations shall be at full pay at the current salary rate. 
(C)  All full-time employees shall begin accrual of vacation upon completion of two (2) full weeks of regular work. The accrual balance will appear to the credit of the employee, but will not be available for use as approved vacation leave until the employee has served for a period of thirteen (13) pay periods, unless otherwise approved by the appointing authority. Upon completion of the thirteenth (13th) pay period, the employee is eligible to utilize the accrued vacation balance. 
(D)  Each full-time employee shall be permitted an annual standard maximum carryover of three (3) times the employee's annual vacation accrual rate.
