(A)  The city manager is authorized to dispose of surplus personal property through auction, sealed bids, Internet auction, or, in the case of surplus or non-surplus personal property, by sale for a fixed price. An item of non-surplus property may only be sold for a fixed price if it is of minimal value as defined in C.O. § 223.02. 
(B)  Auctions or sealed bids shall be conducted after advertisement for not less than two (2) or more than four (4) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the municipal corporation. 
(C)  Internet auctions shall be conducted after notice has been posted in the municipal services center and on the city's website. Internet auctions may be conducted either by the city on its website or by an Internet auction service. The purchasing administrator may establish the minimum price and any other terms and conditions that will be accepted for each specific item. Each item of property will be posted on the Internet for a minimum of ten (10) days, including Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. If an Internet auction service is used, the fee or commission for such service shall not exceed ten percent (10%) of the sale proceeds. 
(D)  Property scheduled for auction, sealed bids, or Internet auction shall be sold to the highest and best bidder. The purchasing administrator is authorized to determine the highest and best bidder and to reject any and all bids. 
(E)  The city manager and the director of finance may establish the price demanded for personal property to be disposed of by sale for a fixed price. Such price shall be the property's estimated market price, as determined by the city manager and director of finance. 
(Ord. No. 50-2013; Ord. No. 5-2017 , § 5, 2-13-2017) 
§ 223.04 - DONATIONS OF PERSONAL PROPERTY. 
(A)  The city manager is authorized to dispose of surplus personal property having an estimated fair market value of less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) by donating the item to an appropriate entity in accordance with this section. 
(B)  The city manager may donate the item to the Upper Arlington City School District. 
(C)  If the Upper Arlington School District is not interested in the item, the city manager may donate the item to another governmental body or to a non-profit charitable organization. 
(D)  The city manager may require the entity receiving the donation to pay a reduced purchase price and/or the costs associated with the delivery of the item. 
§ 223.05 - OTHER DISPOSITIONS OF PERSONAL PROPERTY. 
    The city manager is authorized to dispose of surplus personal property: 
(A)  By refuse collection when the item has minimal value; 
(B)  By destruction upon the determination of the city manager and the city attorney that the property needs to be destroyed for public safety reasons; 
(C)  By trade for goods or services of like value when such trade is determined by the city manager to be in the best interest of the city; 
(D)  By trade-in for credit at the time of the city's purchase of new or replacement property; 
(E)  By sale for a fixed price to the general public. The city manager may dispose of both surplus personal property, and non-surplus personal property that is of minimal value, as defined in C.O. § 223.02, by selling it for a fixed price determined as provided in C.O. § 223.03(E); and/or 
(F)  By recycling, when the item is damaged, obsolete and/or non-functional personal property, including, but not limited, to informational technology items and mobile devices, provided the item has minimal value. 
(Ord. No. 50-2013; Ord. No. 49-2018 , § 2, 6-25-2018) 
§ 223.06 - REQUIREMENTS FOR SALE OF REAL PROPERTY. 
(A)  Any sale, transfer, or other conveyance of a real property interest shall require a determination by the city manager that the real property interest is surplus property. 
(B)  Except as provided in C.O. § 223.07, the city manager shall obtain an independent appraisal and a survey prior to the sale, transfer, or other conveyance of a real property interest. 
(C)  Except as provided in C.O. § 223.07, the sale, transfer, or other conveyance of a real property interest shall require the approval of a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of city council. The ordinance shall describe the real property interest to be conveyed and any interests to be retained by the city. The ordinance may also describe any easements or other interests to be granted by the city to any person that is lawfully occupying the rights-of-way or owns property abutting the rights-of-way. 
(D)  Any contract, deed, lease, easement, right of entry, or other conveyance instrument shall be approved to form by the city attorney and executed on behalf of the city by the city manager. 
§ 223.07 - EXCEPTIONS. 
(A)  The city manager may sell, transfer, or otherwise convey the following real property interests without obtaining an independent appraisal or city council approval: 
(1)  A permanent or temporary non-exclusive utility easement in the real property interest. 
(2)  A lease of the Real Property Interest for a term of eighteen (18) months or less. 
(3)  A temporary construction easement or right of entry in the real property interest for less than one (1) year. 
(4)  A real property interest involving less than 0.05 acres. 
(5)  A real property interest that has an estimated fair market value of less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) as certified by the finance director. 
(B)  City council may by ordinance waive any of the requirements of this chapter or provide additional requirements for the sale, transfer, or other conveyance of a particular real property interest. 
(Ord. No. 83-2013) 
§ 223.08 - SALE OF REAL PROPERTY TO ABUTTING OWNERS. 
(A)  The real property interest may be offered for sale to the abutting owners at its fair market value as determined by the appraisal. If there is more than one abutting owner, the real property interest shall be offered for sale to all abutting owners by competitive bid. The minimum bid shall be not less than one hundred percent (100%) of the fair market value of the real property interest. If none of the abutting owners submits a bid equal to or greater than the fair market value of the real property interest, the real property interest may be offered for sale to the general public by competitive sealed bid or by public auction. 
(B)  The city reserves the right to reject all bids in the event the city manager determines that no bids submitted are acceptable. 
§ 223.09 - SALE OF REAL PROPERTY TO GENERAL PUBLIC. 
(A)  The real property interest may be offered for sale to the general public by competitive bid or by public auction. The sale of the real property interest shall be advertised once a week for a period of two (2) weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the municipal corporation. The minimum bid for the first time a real property interest is offered to the general public shall be not less than ninety percent (90%) of its fair market value. 
(B)  A real property interest that is not sold the first time it is offered to the general public may be offered for sale to the general public at a second competitive bid or public auction without further action of the city council. The sale of the real property interest shall be advertised once a week for a period of two (2) weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the municipal corporation. The city manager may waive the minimum bid requirement for the second time a real property interest is offered for sale to the general public by competitive bid or public auction. 
(C)  The city reserves the right to reject all bids in the event the city manager determines that no bids submitted are acceptable. 
§ 223.10 - OBLIGATIONS OF BUYER OF REAL PROPERTY. 
(A)  In addition to payment of the purchase price, the city manager may require the highest bidder to reimburse the city for some or all of the city's costs associated with the sale of the real property interest, including but not limited to the appraiser and surveyor fees, advertising costs, auctioneer fees, real estate commissions, title insurance fees, transfer fees, document preparation costs, taxes and closing costs. 
(B)  The highest bidder shall not be exempt from compliance with the city's Unified Development Code, Building Codes or any other applicable federal, state or local law. 
§ 223.11 - TERMINATION OF PUBLIC RIGHTS IN REAL PROPERTY. 
City council may by ordinance terminate the public rights in a particular real property interest upon the conveyance of the real property interest pursuant to this chapter or C.O. ch. 933. 
§ 223.12 - VACATION OF REAL PROPERTY. 
(A)  The vacation of a real property interest pursuant to ORC § 723.04 or 723.05 shall require a determination by city council that the real property interest is no longer needed by the city for use as a right-of-way and that the sale of the real property interest is unlikely to yield a sufficient purchase price to cover the city's anticipated costs of sale. The ordinance approving the vacation of the real property interest shall describe the real property interest to be vacated and any interests to be retained by the city. The ordinance may also describe any easements or other interests to be granted by the city to anyone lawfully occupying the rights-of-way or owning property abutting the rights-of-way. 
(B)  The vacation of a real property interest pursuant to ORC § 723.09 shall require a determination by the court of common pleas that the real property interest is no longer needed by the city for use as a right-of-way and that the sale of the real property interest is unlikely to yield a sufficient purchase price to cover the city's anticipated costs of sale. The order approving the vacation of the real property interest shall describe the real property interest to be vacated and any interests to be retained by the city. The order may also describe any easements or other interests to be granted to providers having facilities in the rights-of-way or to property owners abutting the rights-of-way. 
(C)  The sale, transfer, or other conveyance of a Real Property Interest pursuant to this chapter or C.O. ch. 933 shall not be considered a vacation of the real property interest for any purpose. 
§ 223.13 - ADVERSE POSSESSION. 
(A)  No person shall acquire any interest in a real property interest by means of the adverse possession of the real property interest. 
(B)  No person shall acquire any interest in a real property interest by means of the provisions of ORC § 2305.05. 
(C)  Except as expressly provided in this chapter, no person shall acquire any interest in a real property interest without the approval of a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of city council. 
§ 223.14 - ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. 
(A)  Proceeds from the sale of surplus personal property shall be deposited in the city fund that was used to purchase the personal property. If the source of funds for the purchase is unknown or the fund no longer exists, the proceeds shall be deposited in the general fund. 
(B)  Proceeds from the sale of lost, stolen, unclaimed or seized property in the possession of the police division and disposed of at city auction shall be deposited in the general fund. The city manager may designate a portion of the proceeds from each sale of property disposed of pursuant to this section to be paid to Crime Stoppers, Inc. to be used exclusively for the payment of citizen rewards. 
(C)  Proceeds from the sale or disposition of all other personal property shall be deposited in the general fund. 
(D)  Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, the proceeds of the sale of a real property interest shall be deposited into the city's general fund without restriction on future use. 
CHAPTER 225. - CITY FUNDS 

§ 225.01 - UPPER ARLINGTON SWIMMING POOL FUND. 
All revenues derived from the Upper Arlington Swimming Pools shall be credited to the Upper Arlington Swimming Pool Fund, which is hereby established. Said fund shall be used for the payment of the cost of management, maintenance and repair of said pools. 
Expenditures from said fund are subject to appropriation by city council and shall be made only for the furtherance of the Upper Arlington Swimming Pools. 
§ 225.02 - LIFELONG LEARNING AND LEISURE FUND. 
All revenues derived from programs associated with life long learning/leisure activities shall be credited to the lifelong learning and leisure fund, which is hereby established. Said fund shall be used for the payment of the cost of management and general operations of said program. 
Expenditures from said Fund are subject to appropriation by city council and shall be made only for the furtherance of the continuing education program. 
§ 225.03 - ENFORCEMENT EDUCATION FUND. 
A portion of revenues derived from fines received from operating a motor vehicle while intoxicated (OMVI) convictions shall be credited to the enforcement education fund which is hereby established. The enforcement education fund shall be used to pay the costs incurred in both enforcing and informing the public of the laws governing operation of a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. 
Expenditures from said fund are subject to appropriation by city council and shall be made only for the furtherance of educating/ informing the public of aforesaid laws. 
§ 225.04 - CIVIL SERVICE FUND. 
The civil service fund is hereby established and shall be used for the payment of the cost of management and general operations of the civil service commission. 
Expenditures from said fund are subject to appropriation by city council and shall be made only in support of services provided by the civil service commission. 
§ 225.05 - FORMERLY BOARD OF HEALTH FUND. 
§ 225.06 - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT FUND. 
The economic development fund is hereby established and shall be used for stimulating investment in Upper Arlington by providing incentives and maintaining an attractive economic climate for business retention and expansion and new business recruitment. 
§ 225.07 - TAX INCENTIVE REVIEW FUND. 
The tax incentive review fund is hereby established to receive deposits of fees required when agreements are entered into under ORC § 3735, relative to regulations governing the metropolitan housing authority. 
Expenditures from said fund are exclusive for the purpose of complying with ORC § 3735.672 and for the purpose of performing the duties of the tax incentive review board. 
§ 225.08 - DISCRETIONARY FUND. 
The appointing authority shall maintain a discretionary fund to provide and sometimes to present such items to include food, amenities and token gifts, on occasion(s) as deemed appropriate for employee work functions, boards, commissions and community endeavors. Expenditures of such funds may include, but are not limited to, non-alcoholic beverages, meals, office refreshments, paper products, gift cards, amenities, meritorious service awards, certificates, plaques, resolutions and other similar items. 
§ 225.09 - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES FUND. 
The emergency medical services (EMS) fund is hereby established. All revenue derived from EMS billings shall be credited to this fund. Said fund shall be used for the payment of the operation of the EMS program as well as other operating and capital needs of the fire division. 
§ 225.10 - COMMUNITY FIBER OPTIC FUND. 
The community fiber optic fund is hereby established. All proceeds from grants, loans and general fund advances and any future revenue from lease payments shall be credited to this fund. Said fund shall be used for the payment of the installation and maintenance and repairs of the fiber optic network as well as the payments for the loan. 
( Ord. No. 77-2015, § 1, 11-9-2015 ) 
CHAPTER 227. - COLLECTION OF REVENUES 

§ 227.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
For purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them: 
    Charges: means all revenues accruing to the city, including but not limited to taxes, permits, license, fees, charges, special assessments, fines, costs, penalties, and interest. 
§ 227.02 - RESPONSIBILITIES. 
(A)  The finance director is responsible for the collection of all charges. 
(B)  The departments of the city that are the reason for a particular charge accruing to the city shall provide the finance director with timely information and assistance in the collection of such charge. 
(C)  The finance director may request the assistance of the city attorney to file the appropriate civil complaint in a court of law or take other reasonable legal action to collect unpaid charges. 
(D)  The finance director is authorized to impose additional charges to recover the city's time and expenses incurred in the collection of charges remaining unpaid after the due date. 
(E)  The finance director is authorized to waive penalties and interest, compromise the amount of the charges, and accept waiver of statutes of limitations when the probable cost of collection exceeds the amount due or it is in the best interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 40-2009) 
§ 227.03 - PENALTIES AND INTEREST. 
(A)  Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, all charges remaining unpaid for more than thirty days (30) after they become due shall bear interest at the rate of one percent (1%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by law, whichever is lower. The interest shall accrue daily until all unpaid revenues and interest have been paid in full. The person responsible for the charges shall be responsible for payment of the interest. 
(B)  Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, a penalty of ten percent (10%) of the unpaid amount due the city shall be imposed if the amount remains unpaid for more than thirty (30) days. The penalty shall increase to twenty-five percent (25%) of the unpaid amount due the city if the amount remains unpaid for more than twelve (12) months. This penalty shall be in addition to any interest imposed by subsection (A) or any other applicable interest provisions. The person responsible for the charges shall be responsible for payment of the penalty. 
(Ord. No. 40-2009) 
§ 227.04 - CHARGES ASSESSED TO PROPERTY. 
(A)  All charges relating to a service rendered or made available to a specific parcel of real property, including but not limited to, charges for solid waste collection under C.O. ch. 935, charges for stormwater drainage under C.O. ch. 937, charges for neighborhood lighting under C.O. ch. 939, charges for cutting weeds and grasses or for removing rubbish, garbage or improperly stored items under C.O. ch. 1401, are assessed against the property to which the service was rendered or made available and shall become a lien against said property, collectible the same as other liens and taxes. Transfer of ownership of such property shall not relieve the property of responsibility for charges assessed against the property. 
(B)  The fact that such charges were billed in the name of a tenant, lessee or other person or party occupying the property shall not relieve the property or the owner of the property for liability for such charges. After a tenant, lessee or other person or party occupying the property is delinquent in the payment of such charges for a period of sixty (60) days, the finance director shall notify the owner of the property of the delinquency by forwarding a statement by ordinary U.S. mail to the tax mailing address of the owner of the property as listed on the Franklin County Auditor's website, and/or to the address of the property. Thirty (30) days after said notification to the owner of the property, the delinquency for the charges shall be certified as provided in subsection (C). 
(C)  If such charges have not been paid within ninety (90) days after they are due and payable, then the finance director may, in addition to any other methods of collection, certify said charges, together with the interest and penalties allowed by law, to the Franklin County Auditor to be placed on the tax list and duplicate for the specific parcel of real property. 
§ 227.05 - RIGHTS OF PURCHASER. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not bar or prejudice the rights a purchaser may have against the prior owner of property for reimbursement of any charges, as provided herein, incurred prior to the transfer of title to the property, or any other rights that a purchaser may have against the prior owner of the property, subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-2008) 
Part 3 - TRAFFIC CODE 
CHAPTER 301. - DEFINITIONS 

§ 301.01 - DEFINITIONS (A-C). 
The following words and phrases when used in this traffic code or any traffic ordinance of the city shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this chapter unless otherwise stated. 
    Agricultural tractor: means every self-propelling vehicle designed or used for drawing other vehicles or wheeled machinery, but having no provision for carrying loads independently of such other vehicles, and used for agricultural purposes. 
    Alley: means a street or highway intended to provide access to the rear or side of lots or buildings in the city and is intended for the purpose of through vehicular traffic, and includes any street or highway that has been declared an alley by council or the city manager or designee. 
    Arterial street: means any United States or state numbered route, controlled access highway, or other major radial or circumferential street or highway within the city designated by council or the city manager or designee as part of a major arterial system of streets. 
    Articulated passenger bus type vehicle: means a vehicle with three (3) axles supporting two (2) connected passenger compartments that are connected by a joint that allows the bus to bend when making turns. 
    Assembled: means, in regard to motor vehicles, capable of being driven. 
    Automobile transporter: means any vehicle combination designed and used expressly for the transport of assembled motor vehicles. 
    Axle: means one (1) or more load-carrying wheels mounted in a single transverse vertical plane. 
    B-train assembly: means any rigid frame extension that is attached to the rear frame of one (1) semitrailer and provides a fifth wheel connection point for a second semitrailer. 
    Bicycle: means every device, other than a tricycle designed solely for use as a play vehicle by a child, that is propelled solely by human power upon which any person may ride, and that has two (2) tandem wheels, or one (1) wheel in front and two (2) wheels in the rear, or two (2) wheels in the front and one (1) wheel in the rear, any of which is more than fourteen (14) inches in diameter. 
    Boat transporter: means any vehicle combination, including a straight truck towing a trailer typically using a ball and socket connection, designed and used specifically for the transport of boat hulls and boats, whether the hulls or boats are assembled or partially disassembled to facilitate transportation. 
    Bus: means any motor vehicle having motor power designed and used for carrying more than nine (9) passengers and used for the transportation of persons other than a ridesharing arrangement, and every motor vehicle, automobile for hire, or funeral car, other than a taxicab or motor vehicle used in a ridesharing arrangement, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Business district: means the territory fronting upon a street or highway, including the street or highway, between successive intersections where fifty percent (50%) or more of the frontage between such successive intersections is in use for business, or where fifty percent (50%) or more of the frontage for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is in use for business, and the character of such territory is indicated by official traffic control devices. 
    Cancel or cancellation: means the annulment or termination by the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles of a driver's license, commercial driver's license, temporary instruction permit, probationary license or nonresident operating privilege because it was obtained unlawfully, issued in error, altered or willfully destroyed, or because the holder no longer is entitled to the license, permit, or privilege. 
    Certified ignition interlock device: means a device approved by the Ohio Director of Public Safety that connects a breath analyzer to a motor vehicle's ignition system, that is constantly available to monitor the concentration by weight of alcohol in the breath of any person attempting to start that motor vehicle by using its ignition system, and that deters starting the motor vehicle by use of its ignition system unless the person attempting to start the vehicle provides an appropriate breath sample for the device and the device determines that the concentration by weight of alcohol in the person's breath is below a preset level. 
    Child day-care center and type a family day-care home: have the same meaning as in ORC § 5104.01. 
    Collector street: means a street connecting local streets with arterial streets. 
    Commercial car: means any motor vehicle having motor power designed and used for carrying merchandise or freight, or used as a commercial tractor. 
    Commercial tractor: means every motor vehicle having motor power designed or used for drawing other vehicles and not constructed as to carry any load thereon, or designed or used for drawing other vehicles while carrying a portion of such other vehicles, or the load thereon, or both. 
    Construction zone: means that lane or portion of street or highway open to vehicular traffic and adjacent to a lane, berm or shoulder of a street or highway within which lane, berm or shoulder construction, reconstruction, resurfacing or other work of a repair or maintenance nature, including public utility work or work that requires portions of the street or highway to be closed, is being conducted. 
    Continuous alcohol monitoring: means the ability to automatically test and periodically transmit alcohol consumption levels and tamper attempts at least every hour, regardless of the location of the person who is being monitored. 
    Controlled-access highway: means every street or highway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right or access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such street or highway. 
    Controlled substance and marijuana: have the same meaning as in ORC § 3719.01. 
    Crosswalk: means any of the following: 
(A)  That part of a roadway or alley at an intersection ordinarily included within the real or projected prolongation of property lines and curb lines, or in the absence of curbs, the edges of the traversable roadway or alley; 
(B)  If the Upper Arlington City Manager or designee authorizes curb ramps which are outside the crosswalk established by subsection (A) but within fifteen (15) feet of that crosswalk, the crosswalk shall be extended to encompass the pathway between two (2) opposed ramps; 
(C)  Any portion of a roadway or alley, whether at an intersection or elsewhere, distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface; and 
(D)  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, there shall not be a crosswalk where local authorities have placed signs indicating no crossing. 
(Ord. No. 92-2009; Ord. No. 33-2012; Ord. No. 59-2012; Ord. No. 8-2016, § 1, 2-22-2016 ) 
§ 301.02 - DEFINITIONS (D-H). 
    The following words and phrases when used in this traffic code or any traffic ordinance of the city shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this chapter unless otherwise stated. 
    Drive: means any person who drives or operates a motor vehicle upon any street, highway or private property. 
    Driver: means every person who drives, operates, or is in actual physical control of a vehicle, trackless trolley or streetcar. 
    Drug abuse offense, cocaine, and L.S.D.: have the same meanings as in ORC § 2925.01. 
    Drug of abuse: has the same meaning as in ORC § 3719.011 and ORC § 4506.01. 
    Electronic scooter is a vehicle consisting of a two-wheeled device with handlebars and a floorboard that is designed to be stood upon while riding, and is powered by an electric motor. 
    Electronic wireless communications device: includes any of the following: 
(A)  A wireless telephone; 
(B)  A text-messaging device; 
(C)  A personal digital assistant; 
(D)  A computer, including a laptop computer and a computer tablet; 
(E)  Any other substantially similar wireless device that is designed or used to communicate text. 
    Emergency vehicle: means emergency vehicles of municipal, township or county departments or public utility corporations when identified as such as required by law, the Ohio Director of Public Safety, or local authorities, and motor vehicles when commandeered by a law enforcement officer. 
    Equivalent offense: means any of the following: 
(A)  A violation of a municipal ordinance, law of this state, law of another state, or law of the United States that is substantially similar or equivalent; 
(B)  A violation of a former law of this state that is substantially similar or equivalent. 
    Explosives: means any chemical compound or mechanical mixture that is intended for the purpose of producing an explosion, that contains any oxidizing and combustible units or other ingredients in such proportions, quantities or packing that an ignition by fire, by friction by concussion, by percussion or by a detonator of any part of the compound or mixture may cause such a sudden generation of highly heated gases that the resultant gaseous pressures are capable of producing destructive effects on contiguous objects, or of destroying life or limb. 
Manufactured articles shall not be held to be explosives when the individual units contain explosives in such limited quantities of such nature, or in such packing, that it is impossible to procure a simultaneous or a destructive explosion of such units, to the injury of life, limb or property by fire, by friction, by concussion, percussion, or by a detonator, such as fixed ammunition for small arms, firecrackers or safety fuse matches. 
    Flammable liquid: means any liquid which has a flash point of 70° Fahrenheit, or less, as determined by a tagliabue or equivalent closed cup test device. 
    Fronting: means facing a street or highway without regard to the placement of the school building and may include one (1) or more sides of the school property. 
    Funeral escort vehicle: means any motor vehicle, including funeral hearse, while used to facilitate the movement of a funeral procession. 
    Gross weight: means the weight of a vehicle plus the weight of any load thereon. 
    Handicapped parking space or disability parking spaces: means clearly marked parking spaces on public or private streets, parking lots and parking garages designated for the exclusive use of a handicapped designated vehicle and denoted in accordance with the requirements of ORC § 4511.60(E) and ORC § 3781.111(C). 
    Handicapped designated vehicle: means a motor vehicle that displays either (1) a parking card issued under ORC § 4503.44 or (2) a special license plate issued under ORC § 4503.44 and is being operated by or for the transport of a handicapped person. When a motor vehicle displays a temporary parking pass, disabled veteran plate, permanent parking card from the appropriate state agency, or special license plate, that is being operated by or transporting a disabled or handicapped person, the motor vehicle shall have the decal or parking card clearly displayed on the left dashboard or in the left front windshield of enclosed vehicles so that the parking privilege information is on the front side of the card and is readily readable from outside the windshield. 
    Handicapped person: means any person who has lost the use of one (1) or both legs or one (1) or both arms, who is blind, deaf, or so severely handicapped as to be unable to move without the aid of crutches or a wheelchair, or whose mobility is restricted by a permanent cardiovascular, pulmonary, or other handicapping condition. 
    Highway or laned street: means a street or highway, the roadway of which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    House arrest: means a period of confinement of an offender that is in the offender's home or in other premises specified by the sentencing court or by the parole board pursuant to ORC § 2967.28 and during which all of the following apply: 
(1)  The offender is required to remain in the offender's home or other specified premises for the specified period of confinement, except for periods of time during which the offender is at the offender's place of employment or at other premises as authorized by the sentencing court or by the parole board. 
(2)  The offender is required to report periodically to a person designated by the court or parole board. 
(3)  The offender is subject to any other restrictions and requirements that may be imposed by the sentencing court or by the parole board. 
(Ord. No. 92-2009; Ord. No. 9-2012; Ord. No. 72-2018 , § 2, 10-8-2018) 
§ 301.03 - DEFINITIONS (I-N). 
The following words and phrases when used in this traffic code or any traffic ordinance of the city shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this chapter unless otherwise stated. 
    Immobilizing or disabling device: means a device approved by the Ohio Director of Public Safety that may be ordered by a court to be used by an offender as a condition of limited driving privileges. This includes an ignition interlock device, and any prototype device that is used according to protocols designed to ensure efficient and effective monitoring of limited driving privileges granted by a court to an offender. 
    Intersection: means: 
(A)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines; or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) streets or highways which join one another at, or approximately at right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets or highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
(B)  Where a street or highway includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided street or highway by an intersecting street or highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. If an intersecting street or highway also includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of two (2) roadways of such street or highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
(C)  The junction of an alley with a street or highway, or with another alley, shall not constitute an intersection. 
    Jail: has the same meaning as in ORC § 2929.01. 
    Law enforcement officer: means every officer or police officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic, or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Local authorities: means every county, municipal and other local board or body having authority to adopt police regulations under the Constitution and laws of this state. 
    Local street: means an urban street whose primary function is to provide access to residences, businesses or other abutting properties. 
    Manufacturer and dealer: all persons and firms that are regularly engaged in the business of manufacturing, selling, displaying, offering for sale, or dealing in motor vehicles, at an established place of business that is used exclusively for the purpose of manufacturing, selling, displaying, offering for sale, or dealing in motor vehicles. A place of business that is used for manufacturing, selling, displaying, offering for sale, or dealing in motor vehicles shall be deemed to be used exclusively for those purposes even though snowmobiles or all-purpose vehicles are sold or displayed for sale thereat, even though farm machinery is sold or displayed for sale thereat, or even though repair, accessory, gasoline and oil, storage, parts, service, or paint departments are maintained thereat, or, in any county having a population of less than seventy-five thousand (75,000) at the last federal census, even though a department in a place of business is used to dismantle, salvage, or rebuild motor vehicles by means of used parts, if such departments are operated for the purpose of furthering and assisting in the business of manufacturing, selling, displaying, offering for sale, or dealing in motor vehicles. Places of business or departments in a place of business used to dismantle, salvage, or rebuild motor vehicles by means of using used parts are not considered as being maintained for the purpose of assisting or furthering the manufacturing, selling, displaying, and offering for sale or dealing in motor vehicles. 
    Maximum axle load: means the gross weight of vehicle and load imposed by any axle upon the road surface. 
    Maximum wheel load: means the proportionate gross weight of vehicle and load imposed by any wheel upon the road surface. 
    Median: means a continuous traffic control island usually in the center of a street or highway provided to separate traffic on adjacent roadways. 
    Motor vehicle: means any vehicle propelled or drawn by power other than muscular power or power collected from overhead electric trolley wires, except motorized bicycles, road rollers, traction engines, power shovels, power cranes and other equipment used in construction work and not designed for or employed in general highway transportation, hole-digging machinery, well drilling machinery, ditch digging machinery, farm machinery, trailers used to transport agricultural produce or agricultural production materials between a local place of storage or supply and the farm when drawn or towed on a public street or highway at a speed of twenty-five (25) miles per hour, or less, threshing machinery, hay baling machinery, corn sheller, hammermill and agricultural tractors and machinery used in the production of horticultural, floricultural, agricultural and vegetable products, and trailers designed and used exclusively to transport a boat between a place of storage and a marina when drawn or towed on a street or highway for a distance of no more than ten (10) miles at a speed of twenty-five (25) miles per hour or less. 
    Motorcycle: means every motor vehicle other than a tractor having a saddle for the use of the operator and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, including, but not limited to, motor vehicles known as motor-driven cycle, motor scooter or motorcycle without regard to weight or brake horsepower. Motorcycle does not include stand-up electric scooters. 
    Motorized bicycle: means any vehicle having either two (2) tandem wheels or one (1) wheel in the front and two (2) wheels in the rear, that is capable of being pedaled and is equipped with a helper motor of not more than fifty (50) cubic centimeters piston displacement which produces no more than one (1) brake horsepower and is capable of propelling the vehicle at a speed of no greater than twenty (20) miles per hour on a level surface. 
    Moving violation: means any violation of any statute or ordinance that regulates the operation of vehicles, streetcars, or trackless trolleys on a highway or street. Moving violation does not include a violation of ORC § 4513.263 or a substantially equivalent municipal ordinance, a violation of any statute or ordinance regulating pedestrians or the parking of vehicles, vehicle size or load limitations, vehicle fitness requirements, or vehicle registration. 
    Municipal OVI Ordinance and Municipal OVI Offense: have the same meanings as in ORC § 4511.181. 
    Non-commercial motor vehicle: means any motor vehicle, including a farm truck as defined in ORC § 4503.04, designed by the manufacturer to carry a load of no more than three-quarters (3/4) of a ton and used exclusively for purposes other than engaging in business for profit. 
(Ord. No. 59-2012; Ord. No. 72-2018 , § 3, 10-8-2018) 
§ 301.04 - DEFINITIONS (O-R). 
    The following words and phrases when used in this traffic code or any traffic ordinance of the city shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this chapter unless otherwise stated. 
    Official time standard: whenever certain hours are named herein they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in this city. 
    Operate: means to cause or have caused movement of a vehicle, streetcar or trackless trolley. 
    Operator: means every person who drives, operates, or is in actual physical control of a vehicle, trackless trolley or streetcar. 
    Owner: means any person or firm, other than a manufacturer or dealer, that has title to a motor vehicle, except that, in ORC §§ 4505.01 to 4505.19, "owner" includes in addition manufacturers and dealers. 
    Park/Parking: means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading or in compliance with directions of a law enforcement officer or traffic control device. 
    Passenger car: means any motor vehicle designed and used for carrying not more than nine (9) persons, including any motor vehicle designed and used for carrying not more than fifteen (15) persons in a ride sharing arrangement. 
    Pedestrian: means any natural person afoot. 
    Person: means every natural person, firm, partnership, association, corporation or other entity. 
    Person with a disability that limits or impairs the ability to walk: means any person who, as determined by a health care provider, meets any of the following criteria: 
(A)  Cannot walk two hundred (200) feet without stopping to rest; 
(B)  Cannot walk without the use of, or assistance from, a brace, cane, crutch, another person, prosthetic device, wheelchair, or other assistive device; 
(C)  Is restricted by a lung disease to such an extent that the person's forced (respiratory) expiratory volume for one (1) second, when measured by spirometry, is less than one (1) liter, or the arterial oxygen tension is less than sixty (60) millimeters of mercury on room air at rest; 
(D)  Uses portable oxygen; 
(E)  Has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional limitations are classified in severity as class III or class IV according to standards set by the American Heart Association; 
(F)  Is severely limited in the ability to walk due to an arthritic, neurological, or orthopedic condition; 
(G)  Is blind. 
    Physical control: means being in the driver's position of the front seat of a vehicle or in the driver's position of a streetcar or trackless trolley and having possession of the vehicle's, streetcar's or trackless trolley's ignition key or other ignition device. 
    Pole trailer: means every trailer or semi-trailer attached to the towing vehicle by means of a reach, pole or by being boomed or otherwise secured to the towing vehicle, and ordinarily used for transporting long or irregularly shaped loads such as poles, pipes or structural members capable, generally, or sustaining themselves as beams between the supporting connections. 
    Police officer: means every officer or law enforcement officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic, or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway: means every way or place in private ownership used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner but not by other persons. 
    Probationary driver's license or probationary license: means the license issued to any person between sixteen and eighteen years of age to operate a motor vehicle. 
    Prototype device: means any testing device to monitor limited driving privileges that has not yet been approved or disapproved by the Ohio Director of Public Safety. 
    Public grounds: means open, improved or unimproved lands owned, leased or controlled by the City of Upper Arlington, whether or not the same have been designated as parks or playgrounds, or those areas of private property that are open to the general public for vehicular and pedestrian travel. 
    Public safety vehicle: means any of the following: 
(A)  Ambulances, including private ambulance companies under contract to a municipal corporation, township or county, and private ambulances and non-transport vehicles bearing license plates issued under ORC § 4503.49. 
(B)  Motor vehicles and bicycles used by public law enforcement officers or other persons sworn to enforce the criminal and traffic laws of the state. 
(C)  Any motor vehicle when properly identified as required by the Ohio Director of Public Safety, when used in response to fire emergency calls or to provide emergency medical service to ill or injured persons, and when operated by a duly qualified person who is a member of a volunteer rescue service or a volunteer fire department, and who is on duty pursuant to the rules or directives of that service. The Ohio State Fire Marshal shall be designated the Ohio Director of Public Safety as the certifying agency for all public safety vehicles described in this section. 
(D)  Vehicles used by fire departments, including motor vehicles when used by volunteer firefighters responding to emergency calls in the fire department service when identified as required by the Ohio Director of Public Safety. 
Any vehicle used to transport or provide emergency medical service to an ill or injured person, when certified as a public safety vehicle, shall be considered a public safety vehicle when transporting an ill or injured person to a hospital regardless of whether such vehicle has already passed a hospital. 
(E)  Vehicles used by the commercial motor vehicle safety enforcement unit for the enforcement of orders and rules of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio as specified in ORC § 5503.34. 
    Railroad, railroad train and railroad sign or signal: Railroad means a carrier of persons or property operating upon rails placed principally on a private right-of-way. Railroad train means a stream or internal combustion engine or an electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated by a railroad. Railroad sign or signal means any sign, signal or device erected by authority of a public body or official or by a railroad and intended to give notice of the presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train. 
    Residence district: means the territory, not comprising a business district, fronting on a street or highway, including the street or highway, where, for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more, the frontage is improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
    Ridesharing arrangement: means the transportation of persons in a motor vehicle where such transportation is incidental to another purpose of a volunteer driver and includes ridesharing arrangements known as car pools, van pools and bus pools. 
    Right-of-way: means either of the following, as the context requires: 
(1)  The right of a vehicle or pedestrian to proceed uninterruptedly in a lawful manner in the direction in which it or the individual is moving in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching from a different direction into its or the individual's path. 
(2)  A general term denoting land, property or the interest therein, usually in the configuration of a strip, acquired for or devoted to transportation purposes. When used in this context, right-of-way includes the roadway, shoulders or berm, ditch and slopes extending to the right-of-way limits under the control of the State or local authority. 
    Road service vehicle: means wreckers, utility repair vehicles, and state, county, and municipal service vehicles equipped with visual signals by means of flashing, rotating, or oscillating lights. 
    Roadway: means that portion of a street or highway improved, designated or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, except the berm or shoulder. If a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term roadway means any such roadway separately, but not all such roadways collectively. 
    Rural mail delivery vehicle: means every vehicle used to deliver United States mail on a rural mail delivery route. 
(Ord. No. 92-2009; Ord. No. 42-2015, § 1, 6-22-2015 ) 
§ 301.05 - DEFINITIONS (S-Z). 
The following words and phrases when used in this traffic code or any traffic ordinance of the city shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this chapter unless otherwise stated: 
    Saddlemount vehicle transporter combination: means any combination of vehicles in which a straight truck or commercial tractor tows one (1) or more straight trucks or commercial tractors, each connected by a saddle to the frame or fifth wheel of the straight truck or commercial tractor in front of it. Such a combination may include a fullmount, in which a smaller vehicle is mounted completely on the frame of either the first or last straight truck or commercial tractor in the saddlemount combination. 
    Safety zone: means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and so protected or marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times. 
    School: means any school chartered under ORC § 3301.16 and any non-chartered school that during the preceding year filed with the Ohio Department of Education in compliance with rule 3301-35-08 of the Ohio Administrative Code, a copy of the school's report for the parents of the pupil certifying that the school meets Ohio minimum standards for non-chartered, non tax supported schools and presents evidence of this filing to the city from which it is requesting the establishment of a school zone and as further defined in ORC § 2925.01. 
An offense is "committed in the vicinity of a school" if the offender commits the offense on school premises, in a school building, or within one thousand (1,000) feet of the boundaries of any school premises. 
    School building: means any building in which any of the instruction, extracurricular activities, or training provided by a school is conducted, whether or not any instruction, extracurricular activities, or training provided by the school is being conducted in the school building at the time a criminal offense is committed. 
    School bus: means every bus designed for carrying more than nine (9) passengers which is owned by a public, private or governmental agency or institution of learning and operated for the transportation of children to or from a school session or a school function or owned by a private person and operated for compensation for the transportation of children to or from a school session or a school function; provided school bus does not include a bus operated by a municipally owned transportation system, a mass transit company operating exclusively within the territorial limits of a municipal corporation, or within such limits and the territorial limits of municipal corporations immediately contiguous to such municipal corporation, or a common passenger carrier certified by the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio unless such bus is devoted exclusively to the transportation of children to and from a school session or a school function and school bus does not include a van or bus used by a licensed child day-care center or type A family day-care home to transport children from the child day-care center or type A family day-care home to a school if the van or bus does not have more than fifteen (15) children in the van or bus at any time. 
    School premises: means either of the following: 
(1)  The parcel of real property on which any school is situated, whether or not any instruction, extracurricular activities, or training provided by the school is being conducted on the premises at the time a criminal offense is committed; 
(2)  Any other parcel of real property that is owned or leased by a board of education of a school or the governing body of a school for which the state board of education prescribes minimum standards under ORC § 3301.07 and on which some of the instruction, extracurricular activities, or training of the school is conducted, whether or not any instruction, extracurricular activities, or training provided by the school is being conducted on the parcel of real property at the time a criminal offense is committed. 
    School zone: means that portion of a street or highway passing a school fronting upon the street or highway that is encompassed by projecting the school property lines to the fronting street or highway, and also includes that portion of the state highway. The distances described in this definition shall not exceed three hundred (300) feet per approach per direction and are bounded by whichever of the following distances or combinations thereof that the Ohio Director of Public Service approves as most appropriate: 
(a)  The distance encompassed by projecting the school building lines normal to the fronting highway and extending a distance of three hundred (300) feet on each approach direction; 
(b)  The distance encompassed by projecting the school property lines intersecting the fronting highway and extending a distance of three hundred (300) feet on each approach direction; 
(c)  The distance encompassed by the special marking of the pavements for a principal school crosswalk plus a distance of three hundred (300) feet on each approach direction of the highway. 
    Semi trailer: means every vehicle designed or used for carrying persons or property with another and separate motor vehicle so that in operation a part of its own weight or that of its load, or both, rests upon and is carried by another vehicle. 
    Sidewalk: means that portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Special license plates and removable windshield placard: means any license plates or removable windshield placard or temporary removable windshield placard issued under ORC § 4503.41 or 4503.44, and also mean any substantially similar license plates or removable windshield placard or temporary removable windshield placard issued by a state, district, country, or sovereignty. 
    Standing: means any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not. 
    State highway: means a highway under the jurisdiction of the Ohio Department of Transportation. 
    State route: means every highway, which is designed with an official state route number and so marked. 
    Stinger-steered automobile transporter: means any automobile transporter configured as a semitrailer combination in which the fifth wheel is located on a drop frame located behind and below the rearmost axle of the power unit. 
    Stinger-steered boat transporter: means a boat transporter configured as a semitrailer combination in which the fifth wheel is located on a drop frame located behind and below the rearmost axle of the power unit. 
    Street racing: means the operation of two (2) or more vehicles from a point approximately side by side at accelerating speeds in a competitive attempt to out-distance each other or the operation of one (1) or more vehicles over a common selected course, from approximately the same point to the same point, wherein timing is made of the participating vehicles involving competitive accelerations or speeds. 
    Streetcar: means a car, other than a railroad train, for transporting persons or property, operated upon rails principally within a street or highway. 
    Stop (when required): means a complete cessation of movement. 
    Stop intersection: means any intersection at one (1) or more entrances of which stop signs are erected. 
    Stop or stopping (when prohibited): means any cessation of movement except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a law enforcement officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Street or highway: means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way open to the use of the public as a thoroughfare for the purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Suspend or suspension: means the permanent or temporary withdrawal, by action of a court or the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles, of a driver's license, commercial driver's license, temporary instruction permit, probationary license, or nonresident operating privilege for the period of the suspension or the permanent or temporary withdrawal of the privilege to obtain a license, permit, or privilege of that type for the period of the suspension. 
    Through highway: means every street or highway or portion thereof, as defined in C.O. § 335.03. 
    Trackless trolley: means every car that collects its power from overhead electric trolley wires and that is not operated upon rails or tracks. 
    Traffic: means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars, trackless trolleys, and other devices, either singularly or together, while using any highway for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic control devices: means all signs, signals, markings and devices placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic, including signs denoting names of streets and highways. 
    Traffic control signal: means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop, to proceed, to change direction or not to change direction. 
    Trailer: means every vehicle designed or used for carrying persons or property wholly on its own structure and for being drawn by a motor vehicle, including any such vehicle when formed by or operated as a combination of a semi-trailer and a vehicle of the dolly type, such as that used to transport agricultural produce or agricultural production materials between a local place of storage or supply and the farm when drawn or towed on a public street or highway at a speed greater than twenty-five (25) miles per hour and a vehicle designed and used exclusively to transport a boat between a place of storage and a marina, or in and around a marina when drawn or towed on a street or highway for a distance of more than ten (10) miles or at a speed of more than twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
    Truck: means every motor vehicle, except trailers and semi-trailers, designed and used to carry property. 
    Type A family day-care home: Child day-care center and type A family day-care home have the same meaning as in ORC § 5104.01. 
    Urban district: means the territory contiguous to and including any street or highway which is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling houses situated at intervals of less than one hundred (100) feet for a distance of a quarter of a mile or more, and the character of such territory is indicated by official traffic devices. 
    Vehicle: means every device, including a motorized bicycle and electronic scooter, in, upon, or by which any person or property may be transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except that "vehicle" does not include any motorized wheelchairs, electric personal assistive mobility devices, or any device used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks or any devices other than bicycles moved by human power. 
    Voice-operated or hands-free device: means a device that allows the user to vocally compose or send, or to listen to, a text-based communication without the use of either hand except to activate or deactivate a feature or function. 
    Wheelchair ramp: means a break in the curb of a public street, with a ramp extending away from the street, up to a public or private walkway. 
    Write, send, or read a text-based communication: means to manually write, send, or read a text-based communication using an electronic wireless communications device. This includes manually writing, sending, or reading communications referred to as text messages, instant messages, or electronic mail. 
(Ord. No. 92-2009; Ord. No. 59-2012; Ord. No. 72-2018 , § 4, 10-8-2018) 
CHAPTER 305. - TRAFFIC CONTROL REGULATION/DEVICES 

§ 305.01 - DUTY OF CITY MANAGER. 
It shall be the general duty of the city manager or designee with respect to the regulation of traffic, to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, to conduct engineering analyses of recurring accident locations and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigation of traffic conditions and to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of this city. 
( Ord. No. 8-2016, § 2, 2-22-2016 ) 
§ 305.02 - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES, AUTHORITY OF CITY MANAGER. 
(A)  The city manager or designee is authorized to place and maintain traffic control devices upon any street or highway within the jurisdiction of the City of Upper Arlington as necessary to make effective the provisions of this Traffic Code, or to regulate, guide, or warn traffic, and such additional traffic control devices as the city manager or designee may deem necessary for the proper control of traffic. 
(B)  The city manager or designee is hereby authorized and empowered to: 
(1)  Prohibit right turns against a steady red signal at any intersection as to which the city manager or designee shall have determined that such turns will be hazardous to pedestrians or to vehicular traffic. 
(2)  Designate any street or highway as a through street or highway and require that all vehicles stop or yield the right-of-way as may be required before entering the same. 
(3)  Designate any intersection as a stop intersection and require all vehicles to stop at one or more entrances to such intersection. 
(4)  Designate any intersection as a yield intersection and require all vehicles to yield the right-of-way as required. 
(5)  Designate any street as a one-way street and require that all vehicles thereon be moved in one specific direction. 
(6)  Designate and mark lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center line of the roadway. 
(7)  Erect signs directing slow-moving traffic to use a designated lane or allocating specified lanes to traffic moving in the same direction. 
(8)  Designate those portions of any street, where overtaking and passing other traffic or driving to the left of the center or center line of the roadway would be especially hazardous, by appropriate signs or markings on the street to indicate the beginning and end of such zones. Such zones may be marked by an auxiliary yellow line placed parallel and to the right of the normal center line or offset marked lane line. 
(9)  Place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections and require that a specific course of direction be traveled by vehicles proceeding in lanes by either permitting, prohibiting or requiring turns at such intersections. 
(10)  Install traffic control devices, signals and signs at any location to regulate traffic. 
(11)  Establish safety zones, crosswalks, zones of quiet and play streets. 
(12)  Close any street or portion thereof to vehicular traffic, which is in the process of construction, reconstruction or repair. 
(13)  Determine the location of any necessary bus stops and taxicab stands, and passenger or freight loading zones. 
(14)  Determine the location and limiting hours of truck loading zones. 
(15)  Designate dangerous railroad crossings and erect stop signs thereat. 
(16)  Erect "No U Turn" signs at any location to prohibit a vehicle from being turned so as to proceed in the opposite direction. 
(17)  Regulate or prohibit the stopping, standing and parking of vehicles on streets, alleys or public property by erecting signs plainly indicating the prohibitions, restrictions or time limitations. 
(18)  Designate individual parking spaces by markings, which may either be parallel or at a prescribed angle to the curb or edge of the roadway. 
(19)  Designate truck routes in the city. 
(20)  Designate bike only lanes or shared bike lanes, or otherwise regulate or prohibit the riding of bicycles on all or any portion of specific streets, highways, sidewalks or multipurpose paths. 
(C)  The city manager or designee shall exercise the authority delegated in this section upon the basis of an applicable engineering or traffic investigation and consideration of the following: 
(1)  The maximum safety and protection of vehicular and pedestrian traffic from physical injury or property damage; 
(2)  The existing and potential traffic movement, volume and conditions. 
(3)  The location and frequency of accidents, including studies of remedial measures. 
(4)  The recommendations of the police and fire chief. 
(5)  The acceleration of transportation of persons and property by vehicles so as to expedite travel and promote public safety. 
(6)  The convenience and welfare of the general public in parking, standing, loading and unloading, and the use of the streets as affecting business concerns and places of assembly. 
(7)  Economy in the expenditure of money. 
(D)  The traffic regulating powers of the city manager shall not be limited by the specific enumeration of subjects contained in this chapter. 
(E)  The city manager or designee shall file a copy of all designations, rules, and regulations adopted under the authority granted in this chapter with the city clerk. The city clerk shall promptly provide notice of such filing to city council and shall maintain a record of all such designations, rules, and regulations. The designations, rules, and regulations shall become effective after ninety (90) days unless city council takes action pursuant to C.O. § 305.05. 
(F)  Violation of such designations, rules, and regulations shall be a misdemeanor punishable as provided in C.O. § 315.99. 
( Ord. No. 8-2016, § 2, 2-22-2016 ) 
§ 305.03 - TEMPORARY RULES (CITY MANAGER AUTHORITY). 
(A)  The city manager or designee may make temporary rules regulating traffic or for testing traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. No such temporary rules regulating traffic shall remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. The city manager or designee may extend this time period for demonstrated good cause. 
(B)  The city manager or designee is authorized to establish temporary traffic patterns, which may be other than those prescribed by law or ordinance, to route traffic around street construction projects or other obstacles to traffic. Temporary routes shall be posted while in effect and shall be discontinued when traffic can be returned to normal patterns. 
(C)  The city manager or designee is authorized to make and enforce traffic rules and regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
( Ord. No. 8-2016, § 2, 2-22-2016 ) 
§ 305.04 - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES; CONFORMITY TO STATE MANUAL. 
All traffic control devices placed pursuant to the provisions of this Traffic Code shall conform to the "Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways" adopted by the Ohio Department of Transportation and good engineering practices. 
( Ord. No. 8-2016, § 2, 2-22-2016 ) 
§ 305.05 - RESERVATION OF POWER TO COUNCIL. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of C.O. §§ 305.01 to 305.04, inclusive, city council may override any decision of the city manager or designee made under such provisions, and may assume any of the powers delegated to the city manager, by an ordinance or resolution adopted by a vote of a majority of the council members. Upon the adoption of any such ordinance or resolution, the same may be changed only by an amending or repealing ordinance or resolution adopted by city council. 
( Ord. No. 8-2016, § 2, 2-22-2016 ) 
CHAPTER 307. - POLICE DIVISION; ARRESTS 

§ 307.01 - DUTY OF POLICE; ENFORCEMENT. 
It shall be the duty of the police division and all police officers to enforce all street traffic ordinances and all of the state laws applicable to street traffic. Officers of the division are authorized to direct all traffic in conformance with traffic laws or ordinances; provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police or fire divisions may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic code or ordinances. 
§ 307.02 - ARREST PROCEDURES. 
Except when authorized or directed under state law to immediately take a person arrested for a violation of any of the traffic laws before a magistrate, judge or mayor, any police officer, upon making an arrest for violation of the state traffic laws or traffic code of this city, shall take the violator's name, address, operator's license number and the registration number of the motor vehicle involved, and issue to him in writing on a form provided by the clerk of courts, a notice to answer to the charge against him within seven (7) days during hours and at a place specified in the notice. 
The officer shall thereupon, and upon giving by the violator of his written promise to answer as specified in the notice, release him from custody. The arresting officer shall send one (1) copy of such notice to the clerk of courts. Provided, however, that the magistrate, judge or mayor may require the giving of recognizance bail or surety bonds by non-residents of the city, and by other persons charged with violation of such provisions of the traffic code, as he may designate, as a prerequisite to release from custody. 
§ 307.03 - PARKING NOTICES. 
Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this city or state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing, on a form provided by the clerk of courts, for the driver to answer to the charge against him within seven (7) days during the hours and at a place specified in the notice. The officer shall send one (1) copy of such notice to the clerk of courts. 
If the owner or operator fails to appear, a summons shall be issued to the last known address of the owner or operator of the vehicle. If the owner or operator fails to appear, a five (5) day warning notice is to be sent informing the person that a warrant will be issued for failure to appear in court. 
§ 307.04 - POLICE JURISDICTION TO EXTEND TO CITY OWNED PROPERTY. 
Notwithstanding the usual definition of the word city and municipality found in this Code, and notwithstanding any particular provision of this Code, all police regulations within the Upper Arlington Codified Ordinances shall apply on all lands owned by the city and situated outside the corporate limits thereof, to the extent authorized by the statutes of this state. 
CHAPTER 309. - RECORDS AND REPORTS 

§ 309.01 - TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS. 
(A)  The police division shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic code or of the State Uniform Traffic Act of which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. This record shall accumulate until a five-year period is covered and from that time on the record shall be maintained complete for the most recent five-year period. 
(B)  All forms for records of violations and notices of violations shall be serially numbered. For each month and year a written record shall be kept available to the public showing the disposal of all such forms. 
(C)  All such records and reports shall be available for use and study by the city manager or designee. 
§ 309.02 - INVESTIGATIONS. 
(A)  It shall be the duty of the police division to investigate traffic accidents and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of laws or ordinances causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(B)  The police division shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. Accident reports or cards referring them shall be filed numerically by month/year. Such reports shall be available for the use and information of the city manager or designee. 
(C)  Whenever the accidents at any particular location become numerous, the police division shall cooperate with the city manager in conducting studies of such accidents and determining remedial measures. 
(D)  The police division shall receive and properly file all accident reports made to it. 
§ 309.03 - DRIVER FILE. 
The police division shall maintain a suitable record of all traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions and complaints, and the same shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the driver concerned. Such records shall accumulate until a five-year period is covered and thereafter such records shall be maintained complete for the most recent five-year period. 
§ 309.04 - ANNUAL SAFETY REPORT. 
The police division shall annually prepare a traffic report, containing information on traffic matters in this city, for the city manager, as follows: 
(A)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed or injured and other pertinent traffic accident data. 
(B)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the police. 
(C)  The plans and recommendations of the police division for future traffic safety activities. 
CHAPTER 311. - TRAFFIC SCHEDULES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8-2016, § 3, adopted February 22, 2016 , amended chapter 311 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former chapter 311, §§ 311.01-311.13, pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

§ 311.01 - FORMER TRAFFIC SCHEDULES. 
(A)  The city clerk shall maintain a permanent copy of the traffic schedules formerly contained in C.O. Chapter 311. 
(B)  The former traffic schedules shall be used for the prosecution of offenses occurring prior to January 1, 2016. 
( Ord. No. 8-2016, § 3, 2-22-2016 ) 
CHAPTER 313. - IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES 

§ 313.01 - IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES. 
(A)  Any law enforcement officer is authorized to remove or cause removal from the streets, highways, sidewalks, or public grounds or those areas of private property open to the public for vehicular traffic or parking: 
(1)  Any vehicle parked, left standing or abandoned thereon, in violation of any of the specific terms of this traffic code. 
(2)  Any vehicle that fails to comply with the provisions of this traffic code relative to equipment. 
(3)  Any vehicle for which two (2) or more citations for violations of this traffic code have been issued, if the owner or operator thereof has failed to respond to such citations. 
(4)  Any vehicle that has been reported stolen. 
(5)  Any vehicle which is wrecked or so disabled that it is not capable of being operated. 
(6)  Any vehicle that has been involved in an accident and the driver or operator has failed to stop after such accident. 
(7)  Any vehicle operated by a person while engaged in, or, connected with, the commission of a crime. 
(8)  Any vehicle operated by a person without an operator's license, or during a period of suspension or cancellation of such license. 
(9)  Any vehicle from which the driver or owner has been arrested, or any vehicle operated by a person who refused to obey the instruction of any law enforcement officer after such person has been placed under arrest. The law enforcement officer may have the vehicle towed for safekeeping or evidence. 
(10)  Any vehicle operated by any person who is arrested for reckless operation or operating a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, a drug of abuse, or a combination of them. 
(11)  Any vehicle operated by a person that is permitted to be seized under ORC ch. 4510 or 4511 or any substantially similar ordinance. 
(12)  Any vehicle operated by a person that requires seizure under ORC §§ 4510.14, 4510.16, 4511.195 or 4511.203 or any substantially similar ordinance. 
(13)  Any vehicle which, in the impounding authority's opinion, creates a condition which presents a risk of physical harm to persons or property including vehicles which, without authorization, release, discharge, or leak substances into or upon the environment. 
(14)  Any vehicle abandoned after an accident on public or private property away from the owner's residence. 
(15)  Any vehicle from which the driver or operator has been removed due to illness or injury. 
(Ord. No. 8-2014) 
§ 313.02 - OTHER PENALTIES TO APPLY. 
The removal and storage of a vehicle impounded, and the payment of the expense of removal and storage of a vehicle so impounded shall not release the owner, driver or other person in charge of such vehicle from penalties for violation of this traffic code or any other traffic ordinance or rule. 
§ 313.03 - OWNER'S RISK. 
The removal by a law enforcement officer of a vehicle for any of the reasons mentioned in this chapter, or ORC ch. 4503, 4510 or 4511, or any substantially similar municipal ordinance, shall be at the risk of the owner or person in charge thereof and there shall be no liability on the part of the city for any damage caused by such removal or cost associated with the impoundment. 
The storage of any vehicle when impounded by the city shall be at the risk of the driver or owner thereof, and the city shall not be liable for damage of any nature of the theft or destruction by fire of any vehicle so impounded. 
§ 313.04 - POUND CHARGES. 
The expense of removal, conveyance or towing of such vehicle and the expense of storage thereof when removed to any impounding place designated by the Upper Arlington City Manager or designee shall be borne by the owner, driver or other person in charge thereof and shall be paid before the vehicle is released from the pound. 
§ 313.05 - NOTICE TO OWNER: REDEMPTION. 
If, at the expiration of twenty-four (24) hours after any vehicle has been impounded, the owner, driver or other person in charge thereof, has not claimed the vehicle from the pound, it shall be the duty of the officer in charge of such pound to notify, in writing, the owner, driver or other person in charge of the same at their last known place of residence, informing the owner, driver or other person in charge of the nature and circumstances of the violation on account of which such vehicle has been impounded, and also the amount of charges for re-delivery, unless otherwise stated pursuant to ORC ch. 4510 or 4511, or any substantially similar municipal ordinance. 
When the owner, driver or other person in charge of the vehicle impounded presents themselves to the vehicle pound to claim the vehicle, satisfactory proof of right and title shall be furnished to the officer in charge of such pound. 
§ 313.06 - IMPOUNDING FEE AND STORAGE CHARGE.
