(b)  for sales made through the Internet or other remote sales methods, performing an age verification through an independent, third-party age verification service that compares information available from public records to the personal information entered or provided by the person during the ordering process, that establishes that the person is twenty-one (21) years of age or older. 
(3)  A violator of this section includes the person who distributes, sells, permits to be sold, or offers for sale any such product to a young adult as well as his or her employer and any person who controls the person who sells, permits to be sold, or offers for sale any such product to a young adult. 
(C)  No young adult shall knowingly furnish false information concerning that young adult's name, age, or other identification for the purpose of obtaining cigarettes, tobacco products, e-cigarettes, or liquid nicotine. 
(D)  A violation of this section shall be an unclassified misdemeanor. The fine for a first offense within a twelve-month period shall not exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). If the offender has previously been convicted of a violation of this section, or any substantially equivalent offense, within the previous twelve (12) months, the fine shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). For third and subsequent violations of this section or any equivalent offense within a twelve-month period, the fine shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(E)  Any cigarette, tobacco product, e-cigarette or liquid nicotine that is distributed, sold, permitted to be sold, or offered for sale in violation of this section is subject to seizure and forfeiture, and disposal, as provided in C.O. § 551.01. 
(F)  Compliance with the age verification procedures under C.O. § 531.08(B)(2) with respect to the sale of cigarettes, tobacco products, e-cigarettes, and liquid nicotine to minors shall not be a defense to a charge under this section. 
(G)  It shall not be a violation of this section to distribute, sell, permit to be sold, or offer for sale to any young adult in this city any product that has been approved as a tobacco cessation aid by the United States Food and Drug Administration. 
(H)  (1)  A seller or an agent or employee of a seller may not be found guilty of a charge of a violation of this section in which the age of the purchaser or other recipient of cigarettes, tobacco products, e-cigarettes, or liquid nicotine is an element of the alleged violation, if the seller, agent, or employee raises and proves as an affirmative defense that all of the following occurred: 
(a)  A person attempting to purchase or receive cigarettes , tobacco products, e-cigarettes, or liquid nicotine presented a driver's or commercial driver's license, or an identification card issued under sections 4507.50 to 4507.52 of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(b)  A transaction scan, as defined in ORC § 2927.021, of the driver's or commercial driver's license or identification card that the card holder presented indicated that the license or card was valid. 
(c)  The cigarettes, tobacco products, e-cigarettes, or liquid nicotine were sold, given away, or otherwise distributed to the card holder in reasonable reliance upon the identification presented and the completed transaction scan. 
(2)  In determining whether a seller or an agent or employee of a seller has proven the affirmative defense provided this section, the trier of fact in the action for the alleged violation of this section shall consider any written policy that the seller has adopted and implemented and that is intended to prevent violations of this section or a substantially equivalent offense. For purposes of division (H)(1)(c), the trier of fact shall consider that reasonable reliance upon the identification presented and the completed transaction scan may require a seller or an agent or employee of a seller to exercise reasonable diligence to determine, and that the use of a transaction scan device does not excuse a seller or an agent or employee of a seller from exercising reasonable diligence to determine, the following: 
(a)  Whether a person to whom the seller or agent or employee of a seller sells, gives away, or otherwise distributes cigarettes, tobacco products, e-cigarettes, or liquid nicotine is twenty-one (21) years of age or older; 
(b)  Whether the description and picture appearing on the driver's or commercial driver's license or identification card presented by a card holder is that of the card holder. 
(3)  In any criminal action in which the affirmative defense provided by division (H)(1) is raised, the registrar of motor vehicles or a deputy registrar who issued an identification card under ORC §§ 4507.50 to 4507.52 shall be permitted to submit certified copies of the records of that issuance in lieu of the testimony of the personnel of or contractors with the bureau of motor vehicles in the action. 
( Ord. No. 35-2015, § 1, 6-8-2015 ) 
CHAPTER 549. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

§ 549.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
As used in this chapter: 
    Alcohol: means ethyl alcohol, whether rectified or diluted with water or not, whatever its origin may be, and includes synthetic ethyl alcohol. Such term excludes denatured alcohol and wood alcohol. 
    Beer, malt liquor or malt beverages: includes all brewed or fermented malt products containing one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) or more of alcohol by weight, but not more than six percent (6%) of alcohol by weight. 
    Chauffeured limousine: means a vehicle registered under ORC § 4503.24. 
    Drug of abuse: has the same meaning as in ORC § 3719.011 [3791.01.1]. 
    Intoxicating liquor and liquor: includes all liquids and compounds, other than beer as defined in C.O. § 549.01, containing one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) or more of alcohol by volume which are fit for beverage purposes, from whatever source and by whatever process produced, by whatever name called, and whether the same are medicated, proprietary or patented. Such phrase includes wine, as defined in ORC § 4301.01 even if it contains less than four percent (4%) of alcohol by volume, mixed beverages, as defined in ORC § 4301.01 even if they contain less than four percent (4%) of alcohol by volume, alcohol and all solids and confections, which contain any alcohol. 
    Orchestral performance: means a concert comprised of a group of not fewer than forty (40) musicians playing various musical instruments. 
    Person: includes firms and corporations. 
    Underage person: means a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
§ 549.02 - SALES TO UNDERAGE PERSONS, PROHIBITIONS AND MISREPRESENTATIONS. 
(A)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no person shall sell intoxicating liquor or beer to a person under twenty-one (21) years of age, or buy intoxicating liquor or beer for, or furnish it to an underage person unless given by a physician in the regular line of his practice, or given for established religious purposes, or unless the underage person is accompanied by a parent, spouse who is not an underage person, or legal guardian. 
In proceedings before the Ohio Department of Liquor Control, no permit holder, his employee or agent charged with a violation of this section shall, for the same offense, be charged with a violation of ORC § 4301.22(A). (ORC § 4301.69) 
(B)  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no minor under twenty-one (21) years of age shall purchase intoxicating liquor or beer. 
(C)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall order, pay for, share the cost of, or attempt to purchase any intoxicating liquor or beer, or consume any intoxicating liquor or beer, either from a sealed or unsealed container or by the glass or by the drink, or possess any beer, or intoxicating liquor in any public or private place except as provided in C.O. § 549.02(A) hereof. 
(D)  No person shall knowingly furnish any false information as to the name, age or other identification for the purpose of obtaining, or with the intent to obtain, intoxicating liquor or beer for a person under twenty-one (21) years of age, by purchase or as a gift. 
(E)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall knowingly show or give false information concerning his name, age or other identification for the purpose of purchasing or otherwise obtaining intoxicating liquor or beer in any place in this city where intoxicating liquor or beer is sold under a permit issued by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control or sold by such department. 
(F)  No person being the parent, spouse who is not an underage person, or legal guardian of an underage person shall knowingly permit such underage person to violate any provisions of this chapter, except as provided in C.O. § 549.02(A) and (G) hereof. 
(G)  No person being the owner or occupant of any public or private place located within the city shall knowingly allow any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to remain in or on the place while in the possession of intoxicating liquor or beer or while consuming intoxicating liquor or beer, unless the intoxicating liquor or beer is given to the person possessing or consuming it by that person's parent, spouse who is not an underage person, or legal guardian and the parent, spouse who is not an underage person, or legal guardian is present at the time of the person's possession or consumption of the beer or intoxicating liquor. 
(H)  (1)  No person is required to permit the engagement of accommodations at any hotel, motel, inn, cabin, campground or other hostelry by an underage person or for an underage person if the person engaging the accommodations knows or has reason to know that the underage person is intoxicated or that the underage person possesses any beer or intoxicating liquor and is not accompanied by a parent, spouse who is not an underage person, or legal guardian who is or will be present at all times when the beer or intoxicating liquor is being consumed by the underage person. 
(2)  No underage person shall knowingly engage, or attempt to engage accommodations at any hotel, inn, cabin, or campground by presenting identification that falsely indicates that the underage person is twenty-one (21) years of age, or older for the purpose of violating this section. 
(I)  No person under twenty-one (21) years of age shall knowingly possess, control or consume any intoxicating liquor or beer in any public or private place unless given by a physician in the regular line of the physician's practice or given for established religious purposes or unless the underage person is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. 
(J)  No person shall engage or use accommodations at a hotel, inn, cabin, campground, restaurant, limousine, livery vehicle or charter bus service when the person knows or has reason to know either of the following: 
(1)  That beer or intoxicating liquor will be consumed by an underage person on the premises of the accommodations that the person engages or uses, unless the person engaging or using the accommodations is the spouse of the underage person and who is not an underage person, or is the parent or legal guardian of all of the underage persons, who consume beer or intoxication liquor on the premises and that person is on the premises at all times when beer or intoxicating liquor is being consumed by an underage person; 
(2)  That a drug of abuse will be consumed on the premises of the accommodations by any person, except a person who obtained the drug of abuse pursuant to a prescription issued by a licensed health professional authorized to prescribe drugs and has the drug of abuse in the original container in which it was dispensed to the person. 
(K)  Whoever violates C.O. §§ 549.02 (A), (B), (C), (D), (E), (F), (G), (H), (I) or (J) hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
§ 549.03 - SALES TO INTOXICATED PERSONS. 
(A)  No person shall sell intoxicating liquor or beer to any individual who habitually drinks intoxicating liquor or beer to excess. 
(B)  No person shall sell intoxicating liquor or beer to an intoxicated person. 
(C)  Whoever violates C.O. § 549.03 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. 
§ 549.04 - LIQUOR CONSUMPTION IN MOTOR VEHICLE. 
(A)  No person shall consume any intoxicating liquor or beer in a motor vehicle except as provided in C.O. § 549.07(D). 
(B)  Whoever violates C.O. § 549.04 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. 
( Ord. No. 88-2015, § 1, 1-25-2016 ) 
§ 549.05 - PERMIT REQUIRED. 
(A)  No person by himself or by his clerk, agent or employee shall manufacture, manufacture for sale, offer, keep or possess for sale, furnish or sell or solicit the purchase or sale of any intoxicating liquor or beer in this city or transport, import or cause to be transported or imported, any beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol in or into this city for delivery, use or sale, unless such person shall have fully complied with ORC chs. 4301 and 4303 or is the holder of a permit issued by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control and in force at the time. 
(B)  Whoever violates C.O. § 549.05 hereof, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
§ 549.06 - POSTING LIQUOR AGE WARNING SIGNS. 
(A)  Every place in the city where intoxicating liquor or beer is sold for beverage purposes, either under a permit issued by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control or by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control, shall display at all times, in a prominent place on the premises thereof, a printed card which shall be furnished by the department and which shall read substantially, as follows: 
WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER AGE ... If you are under twenty-one (21) years of age. Under the statutes of the State of Ohio, if you order, pay for, share the cost of, attempt to purchase or consume intoxicating liquor or beer or furnish false information as to name, age or other identification, you are subject to a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment up to six (6) months, or both. However, if you have attained the age of nineteen (19) years on or before July 31, 1987, you may purchase beer only. 
No person being the holder of a permit issued by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control shall fail to comply with this section. 
(B)  Whoever violates or fails to comply with C.O. § 549.06 hereof, shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. 
§ 549.07 - OPEN CONTAINER PROHIBITED. 
(A)  As used in this section, street and motor vehicle have the same meanings as in ORC § 4511.01. 
(B)  No person shall have in his possession an opened container of intoxicating liquor or beer in any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Except as provided in division (C)(1)(e) of this section, in an agency store. 
(2)  On the premises of the holder of any permit issued by the Ohio Department of Liquor Control. 
(3)  In any public place. 
(4)  While operating or being a passenger in or on a motor vehicle on any street or other public private property open to the public for purposes of vehicular travel or parking. 
(5)  While being in or on a stationary motor vehicle on any street or other public or private property open to the public for purposes of vehicular travel or parking. 
(C)  (1)  This section does not apply to: 
(a)  Intoxicating liquor or beer which has been lawfully purchased for consumption on the premises where bought of a holder of an A-1A, A-2, A-3a, D-1, D-2, D-3, D-3a, D-4, D-4a, D-5, D-5a, D-5b, D-5c, D-5d, D-5e, D-5f, D-5g, D-5h, D-5i, D-7, D-8, E, F, F-2, F-7, or F-8 permit; or 
(b)  Beer, wine, or mixed beverages served for consumption on the premises by the holder of an F-3 permit or wine served for consumption on the premises by the holder of an F-4 or F-6 permit; 
(c)  Intoxicating liquor or beer consumed on the premises of a convention facility as provided in ORC § 4303.201 [4303.20.1]; or 
(d)  Beer or intoxicating liquor to be consumed during tastings and samplings approved by rule of the liquor control commission; or 
(e)  Spirituous liquor to be consumed for purposes of a tasting sample, as defined in ORC § 4301.71; or 
(f)  Intoxicating liquor or beer consumed inside the Amelita Mirolo Barn and surrounding premises or within the enclosed area of Northam Park designated by the city manager in accordance with a city permit issued by the city manager pursuant to C.O. §131.05. 
(2)  (a)  A person may have in the person's possession an opened or unopened container of beer or intoxicating liquor at an outdoor location at which the person is attending an orchestral performance as defined in C.O. § 549.01 if the person with supervision and control over the performance grants permission for the possession and consumption of beer or intoxicating liquor in certain predesignated areas of that outdoor location. 
(b)  A person may have in the person's possession on an F-9 liquor permit premises an opened or unopened container of beer or intoxicating liquor that was not purchased from the holder of the F-9 permit if the person is attending an orchestral performance and the holder of the F-9 permit grants permission for the possession and consumption of beer or intoxicating liquor in certain predesignated areas of the premises during the period for which the F-9 permit is issued. 
(D)  An opened bottle of wine that was purchased from the holder of a permit that authorizes the sale of wine for consumption on the premises where sold is not an opened container for the purposes of this section if both of the following apply: 
(1)  The opened bottle of wine is securely resealed by the permit holder or an employee of the permit holder before the bottle is removed from the premises. The bottle shall be secured in such a manner that it is visibly apparent if the bottle has been subsequently opened or tampered with; and 
(2)  The opened bottle of wine that is resealed in accordance with division (D)(1) of this section is stored in the trunk of a motor vehicle or, if the motor vehicle does not have a trunk, behind the last upright seat or in an area not normally occupied by the driver or passengers and not easily accessible by the driver. 
(E)  This section does not apply to a person who pays all or a portion of the fee imposed for the use of a chauffeured limousine pursuant to a prearranged contract, or the guest of the person, when all of the following apply: 
(1)  The person or guest is a passenger in the limousine. 
(2)  The person or guest is located in the limousine, but is not occupying a seat in the front compartment of the limousine where the operator of the limousine is located. 
(3)  The limousine is located on any street, highway or other public or private property open to the public for purposes of vehicular travel or parking. 
(4)  The occupants are not underage persons in violation of C.O. § 549.02 or other sections of C.O. ch. 549. 
(F)  Whoever violates this section is guilty of possessing an open container, a misdemeanor of the third degree. 
(Ord. No. 68-2013) 
§ 549.08 - HOURS OF SALE OR CONSUMPTION GENERALLY. 
(A)  No beer or other malt beverages shall be sold by or be permitted to be consumed on weekdays upon the premises of a Class C-1, C-2, D-1, D-2 or D-4 permit holder between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. 
No wine, prepared highballs, cocktails or other mixed drinks, as defined in the Liquor Control Act, shall be sold or be permitted to be consumed on weekdays upon the premises of a Class A-2, C-2, D-2 or D-4 permit holder between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. 
No intoxicating liquor or beer shall be sold or be permitted to be consumed on weekdays on the premises of a Class D-3a or D-5 permit holder between the hours of 2:30 a.m. and 5:30 a.m., and no intoxicating liquor shall be sold or be permitted to be consumed on weekdays on the premises of a Class D-3 permit holder between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. 
No intoxicating liquor or beer shall be sold or be permitted to be consumed on weekdays on the premises of a Class D-4 permit holder between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:30 a.m. 
(B)  Whoever violates any of the provisions of C.O. § 549.08 hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. 
§ 549.09 - UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW OF INTERIOR. 
(A)  The premises of a retail permit holder shall be arranged so as to provide a clear and unobstructed view of the interior after the legal hours of sale provided for in the Liquor Control Act of the State of Ohio. 
(B)  Whoever violates C.O. § 549.09 hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. 
§ 549.10 - DISORDERLY PERSONS ON PREMISES. 
(A)  No person owning or operating a restaurant, hotel, club, nightclub or other place where beer, wine or spirituous liquor are permitted to be sold under the authority of the Liquor Control Act within the city, or other person representing such owner or operator, shall permit or allow any riotous, noisy or disorderly person to frequent such restaurant, hotel, club, nightclub or other such place, or resort thereto, or allow any boisterous, noisy or disorderly conduct therein or thereabouts at any time. 
(B)  Whoever violates C.O. § 549.10 hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. 
§ 549.11 - CONSUMPTION IN PARKS. 
(A)  No person shall consume or possess with intent to consume, any intoxicating liquor or beer in a city park. 
(B)  This section does not apply to intoxicating liquor or beer consumed or possessed in accordance with a city permit issued by the city manager pursuant to C.O. § 131.05. 
(C)  Whoever violates C.O. § 549.11 hereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. 
(Ord. No. 25-2011, 5-9-2011) 
§ 549.99 - PENALTIES. 
(A)  Misdemeanor penalties must be imposed upon a person under twenty-one (21) years of age who presents a false, fictitious or altered I.D. card, false or fictitious driver's license purportedly issued by any state, or legitimate, but altered driver's license when purchasing intoxicating liquor or beer. 
(B)  The following penalties shall be imposed upon any person in violation of C.O. § 549.02(E): 
(1)  A mandatory fine of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first offense. 
(2)  A mandatory fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a possible license suspension up to sixty (60) days for a second offense. 
(3)  A mandatory fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a mandatory ninety-day suspension, with community service for the third and subsequent offenses. 
CHAPTER 551. - DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY HELD BY THE CITY 

§ 551.01 - DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY HELD BY THE UPPER ARLINGTON POLICE DIVISION. 
(A)  Property that has been lost, abandoned, stolen or lawfully seized, or forfeited and that is in the custody of the police division shall be safely kept pending the time it is no longer needed as evidence, and shall be disposed of pursuant to this chapter, ORC § 2981.12 and the Property Management Procedure Manual of the police division. 
(B)  The police division shall make a reasonable effort as set forth under C.O. § 551.06 and ORC § 2981.04(D) to locate the persons entitled to possession of property in its custody, and to notify them when and where it may be claimed. If after a period of ninety (90) days the police division is unable to identify or locate the owner of property in its custody; or, once notified, the owner fails to claim such property within seven (7) days that property shall be considered unclaimed property and disposed of pursuant to this chapter. If the property described in section (A) is a firearm or dangerous ordnance, the police department shall not release it to the owner prior to receiving a court order mandating its return. This shall not apply to weapons voluntarily turned over to the police for safekeeping and are not related to a criminal or serious traffic matter. 
(C)  Unclaimed property in the custody of the Upper Arlington Police Division that was found and placed into the custody of the police division by a person not employed by the City of Upper Arlington may be returned to the finder after a period of ninety (90) days provided: 
(1)  The property is not a weapon, firearm or dangerous ordnance. 
(2)  The property is not drugs, drug paraphernalia, obscene material, beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol or any other dangerous or illegal material. 
(3)  The owner of the found property is unknown, cannot be located or fails to claim the property within ninety (90) days after a reasonable attempt to locate the owner is made by the police division. 
(4)  The person who found the property and turned it over to the police division signs an affidavit which shall include a hold harmless agreement that they are the finder of the property in question and that they did not obtain nor do the police have reason to believe that they obtained this property illegally, and that they have fully and truthfully informed the police division of all the circumstances surrounding the finding of this property. 
(Ord. No. 49-2010; Ord. No. 49-2018 , § 3, 6-25-2018) 
§ 551.02 - LOSS OF RIGHT TO PROPERTY. 
(A)  A person loses any right they may have to possession of property: 
(1)  That was the subject or was used in a conspiracy or attempt to commit, or in the commission of, an offense other than a traffic offense, and such person is a conspirator, accomplice or offender with respect to the offense. 
(2)  When a court determines that the property should be forfeited because when, in light of the nature of the property or the circumstances of such person, it is unlawful for him to acquire or possess it. 
§ 551.03 - DISPOSITION OF UNCLAIMED AND FORFEITED PROPERTY. 
(A)  Unclaimed and forfeited property in the custody of the police division, other than contraband that is subject to the provisions of ORC ch. 2981, other than property forfeited under ORC § 2925.42, other than property that has been lawfully seized in relation to a violation of ORC § 2923.32, other than a vehicle that is criminally forfeited under an order issued under ORC § 4503.233 or 4503.234 and that is to be disposed of under ORC § 4503.234, shall be disposed of on application to and order of any court of record that has territorial jurisdiction within the municipality. This shall be accomplished within a reasonable time after the property is no longer needed for evidence and/or any other reason the police may need to hold the property, and will be done, as follows: 
(1)  Drugs shall be disposed of pursuant to ORC § 3719.11 or shall be placed in the custody of the Secretary of the Treasury of the United States for disposal or use for medical or scientific purposes under applicable Federal law. 
(2)  Firearms and dangerous ordnance suitable for police work may be given to the police division for that purpose. Firearms suitable as museum pieces or collector's items may be donated for public display to a museum open to the general public provided there is a written agreement that the firearm or dangerous ordnance shall not to be sold. Other firearms and dangerous ordnance not suitable to police use shall be destroyed, or sent to the bureau of criminal identification and investigation for destruction, pursuant to ORC § 2981.12. 
(3)  Obscene materials shall be destroyed. 
(4)  Vehicles used in violation of ORC § 2925.13(A) or C.O. § 551.02 shall be seized and forfeited to the city as set forth in C.O. § 551.05(A)(1) and ORC § 2981.12(6). Such forfeiture shall not apply to common carriers or innocent owners, or shall it affect the rights of a holder of a valid lien. 
(5)  (a)  Money that is not part of any federal and/or state program for asset forfeiture, but is forfeited to the division of police because of its relationship as profits and/or proceeds of any criminal activity, shall be released to the law enforcement fund upon court order. Such money will be tracked separately from other federal and state funds. Forfeited money will be used according to ORC § 2981.13(B) and the police division's internal control policy. 
(b)  Money, which is found unclaimed or forfeited and not associated with any criminal activity, shall be released upon court order to the finance department for deposit into the general fund of the city. 
(6)  Vehicle and vehicle parts forfeited under ORC § 4549.61 to § 4549.63 may be given to the police division for use in the performance of its duties. Such parts may be incorporated into any other official city vehicle. Parts that do not bear vehicle identification numbers or derivatives thereof may be sold or disposed of as provided by rules of the director of public safety. Parts from which a vehicle identification number or derivative thereof has been removed, defaced, covered, altered or destroyed and that are not suitable for police work or incorporation into an official city vehicle shall be destroyed and/or sold as junk or scrap. 
(7)  Beer, intoxicating liquor or alcohol seized from a person who is not a holder of a permit issued under ORC chs. 4301 and 4303; or is an offender, and forfeited to the state under ORC § 4301.45 or § 4301.53, shall be sold by the division of liquor control, if the division determines that the beer, intoxicating liquor, or alcohol, is fit for sale, the proceeds of the sale shall be paid into the state treasury. Any such beer, intoxicating liquor, or alcohol that the division determined to be unfit for sale shall be destroyed. 
(8)  Other unclaimed or forfeited property may be sold at public auction or disposed of as the court considers proper in the circumstances or turned over to the city and converted to city ownership, pursuant to the ORC § 2981.12 provisions for property disposal. 
(9)  (a)  Computers, computer networks, computer systems and computer software, if suitable for police work, may be given to the police for that purpose. Other computers, computer networks, computer systems and computer software shall be disposed of pursuant to C.O. § 551.03(A)(8). Computer software and its application by the city will be governed by any copyright and/or license agreement set forth for the material. Software not properly licensed and/or owned by the city will be deleted or destroyed. 
(b)  As used in this section, computer, computer networks and computer systems have the same meaning as in ORC § 2913.01. 
(Ord. No. 49-2010; Ord. No. 49-2018 , § 4, 6-25-2018) 
§ 551.04 - METHOD OF DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY. 
(A)  The police division may dispose of certain property in its possession in accordance with its own policy and procedures provided that: 
(1)  The property is of little or no monetary value and would normally be considered as trash or rubbish. 
(2)  The property is a small sample or specimen collected as evidence and is no longer needed as evidence. 
(3)  The property is a firearm, dangerous ordnance, explosive or incendiary device, volatile fluid, chemical agent, biological or nuclear material or any other unsafe material that by its nature threatens the public safety and needs to be destroyed or disposed of in order to provide for the safety of the public or public safety officials or is required to be destroyed by court order. 
(Ord. No. 49-2018 , § 5, 6-25-2018) 
§ 551.05 - DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS. 
(A)  The proceeds from property disposed of pursuant to C.O. § 551.03 (A)(2), (A)(4), (A)(6), (A)(8), (A)(9) and C.O. § 551.07 shall be disbursed, as follows: 
(1)  Vehicles and other property obtained as the result of any criminal action may be given to the division of police for use in the performance of its duties. Such vehicles and other property not suitable for police use as determined by the chief of police, will be sold at auction pursuant to C.O. § 551.05(B) below. 
(B)  Funds from vehicles and other property disposed of at auction will be disbursed, as follows: 
(1)  Property in the possession of the law enforcement agency in relation to a delinquent child proceeding in juvenile court, ten percent (10%) of the proceeds from the property disposed of pursuant to this section shall be applied to one (1) or more alcohol and drug addiction treatment programs that are certified by the department of alcohol and drug addictions services under ORC § 3793.06 and that are specified by the court in its order issued under C.O. § 551.03. A juvenile court shall not specify an alcohol or drug addiction treatment program in the order unless the program is a certified alcohol and drug addiction treatment program and except as provided in this section, unless the program is located in the county in which the court that issues the order is located or in a contiguous county. If no certified alcohol and drug addiction program is located in any of these counties, the juvenile court may specify in the order a certified alcohol and drug addiction treatment program located anywhere within the State. The remaining ninety percent (90%) of the proceeds shall be applied as provided in C.O. §§ 551.05(B)(2) and (B)(3). 
If the property was in the possession of the law enforcement agency other than in relation to a delinquent child proceeding in a juvenile court, all of the proceeds from property disposed of pursuant to this section shall be applied as provided in C.O. §§ 551.05(B)(2) and (B)(3). 
(2)  Up to twenty-five percent (25%) of the net proceeds may, at the City Manager's discretion, be used for the funding of a citizens reward program referred to as Crime Stoppers, Inc., pursuant to C.O. § 223.14(B). 
(3)  Except as provided in C.O. § 511.03 and after compliance with C.O. §§ 551.05(B)(1) and (B)(2), all additional proceeds shall be placed in the city's general fund. 
(C)  This ordinance does not apply to the collection, storage or disposal of abandoned junk motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 49-2010) 
§ 551.06 - NOTIFICATION OF OWNER OF HELD PROPERTY. 
(A)  For the purpose of this ordinance, a reasonable effort by the police division to locate the persons entitled to possession of property within the division's custody may include one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  A telephone call to the last known phone number of the suspected owner of the property whereby actual voice contact with the person entitled to the property was made, or an electronic communication sent to a known email address of the suspected owner. If no phone service is available, no contact was gained and/or the ability to only leave a voice message with an answering machine or service was possible, or, in the case of an electronic communication, the communication was returned as undeliverable, then (A)(2) below will be required. 
(2)  A certified letter mailed to the last known address of the suspected owner of the property with return receipt requested. 
(3)  A brief investigation or inquiry by employees of the police division for the purpose of locating or identifying the owner of the property. 
(B)  With respect to forfeited property, reasonable diligent inquiries, shall be made by the police division to locate the persons with a property interest. 
(Ord. No. 49-2010; Ord. No. 49-2018 , § 6, 6-25-2018) 
§ 551.07 - SALE OF HELD PROPERTY. 
(A)  Property, other than a firearm or dangerous ordnance, unclaimed for the period of ninety (90) days, shall be sold by the chief of police of the city or licensed auctioneer at public auction, after giving due notice thereof by advertisement, published once a week for three (3) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The proceeds shall be disbursed according to C.O. § 551.05. 
(Ord. No. 49-2018 , § 7, 6-25-2018) 
§ 551.08 - OTHER PROPERTY-STORAGE. 
(A)  Other stolen or other property, disposal of which is not provided in the preceding sections, recovered by members of the police force or other city employees, shall be deposited with the police division. Each such article shall be entered in a property receipt book kept for that purpose, with the name of the owner, if ascertained, the person from whom taken, the place where found, with general circumstances, the date of its receipt, and the name of the officer receiving it. 
(B)  A copy of the property receipt shall be given to the arrested party from whom taken, and in case it is not claimed by some person within ninety (90) days after arrest and seizure it shall be returned to the person from whom taken, with reasonable proof of ownership (which could include, but not be limited to: store receipts, canceled checks, and/or a charge card statement), and to no other person, either attorney, agent, factor or clerk, except by special order of the city manager. Should the property be unclaimed and/or reasonable proof of ownership is not substantiated after ninety (90) days notice to provide for its release, the property may be disposed of according to C.O. § 551.07. 
§ 551.09 - OTHER PROPERTY-DISPOSAL. 
(A)  If, within ninety (90) days, the money or property recovered under C.O. § 551.08 is claimed by any other person, it shall be retained by the custodian thereof until after the discharge or conviction of the person from whom it was taken and so long as it is required as evidence in any case in court. If such claimant establishes to the satisfaction of the court that he/she is the rightful owner, the money or property shall be restored to him/her, otherwise it shall be returned to the accused person according to C.O. § 551.08(B), after all liens and claims in favor of the city have first been discharged and satisfied. 
§ 551.10 - EXPENSES OF STORAGE AND SALE, NOTICE. 
(A)  Upon the sale of any unclaimed or impounded property as provided in this chapter, if any such unclaimed or impounded property was ordered removed to a place of storage or stored, or both, any expenses or charges for such removal or storage, or both, and costs of sale, provided the same are approved by the city manager shall first be paid from the proceeds of such sale. Notice shall be given by registered mail, thirty (30) days before the date of such sale, to the owner and mortgagee or other lien holder, at their last known address. 
§ 551.11 - COLLECTION, STORAGE, DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES-PUBLIC PROPERTY. 
(A)  When a vehicle has been impounded pursuant to C.O. § 371.13, the chief of police shall immediately cause a search to be made of the records of the bureau of motor vehicles to ascertain the owner and any lien holder of a motor vehicle ordered into storage; and, if known, shall send notice to the owner or lien holder at his last known address by certified mail with return receipt requested, that the motor vehicle will be declared a nuisance and disposed of if not claimed within ten (10) days of the date of mailing of the notice. The owner or lien holder of the motor vehicle may reclaim it upon payment of any expenses or charges incurred in its removal and storage, and presentation of proof of ownership, which may be evidenced by a certificate of title to the motor vehicle. 
(B)  If the owner or lien holder makes no claim to the motor vehicle within ten (10) days of the date of mailing of the notice, and if the vehicle is to be disposed of at public auction as provided in C.O. § 551.14, the vehicle will be disposed of and the procedures established herein shall apply. 
§ 551.12 - COLLECTION, STORAGE, DISPOSAL OF ABANDONED JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES-PRIVATE PROPERTY. 
(A)  The owner of a motor vehicle removed pursuant to C.O. § 371.15, may reclaim it upon payment of any expenses or charges incurred in its removal in an amount not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) and storage in an amount not to exceed eight dollars ($8.00) per twenty-four-hour period, and upon presentation of proof of ownership, which may be evidenced by a certificate of title to the motor vehicle. If the motor vehicle remains unclaimed by the owner for thirty (30) days, the procedures established by C.O. § 551.13 shall apply. 
§ 551.13 - IMPOUNDED AND ABANDONED VEHICLES-DISPOSAL. 
(A)  Upon the failure of the owners to reclaim vehicles described in C.O. §§ 551.11 and 551.12, the chief of police shall file with the clerk of courts of the county in which the place of storage is located an affidavit showing compliance with the requirements of these sections: 
(1)  Upon presentation of the affidavit, the clerk of courts shall without charge issue a certificate of title, free and clear of all liens and encumbrances, to the chief of police. 
(2)  If the vehicle is to be disposed of to a motor vehicle salvage dealer or other facility as provided in ORC § 4513.62 or § 4513.63, the chief of police shall execute in triplicate an affidavit as prescribed by the registrar of motor vehicles, describing the motor vehicle and the manner in which it was disposed of, and that all requirements of this section have been complied with. The chief of police shall retain the original of the affidavit for his records, and shall furnish two (2) copies to the owner of the motor vehicle salvage dealer or other facility. Upon presentation of a copy of the affidavit by the motor vehicle salvage dealer or other facility, the clerk of courts shall issue to such owner a certificate of title, free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. 
Whenever the motor vehicle salvage dealer or other facility receives an affidavit for the disposal of a motor vehicle as provided in this section, such owner shall not be required to obtain an Ohio certificate of title to the motor vehicle in his own name, if, within ten (10) days of the receipt of the affidavit, the vehicle is dismantled or destroyed and both copies of the affidavit are delivered to the clerk of courts. 
§ 551.14 - UNCLAIMED VEHICLES-DISPOSAL. 
(A)  Unclaimed motor vehicles ordered into storage and held under this chapter, shall be disposed of at the order of the chief of police to a motor vehicle salvage dealer or scrap metal processing facility as defined in ORC § 4737.05, or to any other facility owned by or under contract with the city, for the disposal of such motor vehicles, or shall be sold by the chief of police, or licensed auctioneer at public auction, after giving notice thereof by advertisement, published once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Any monies accruing from the disposition of an unclaimed motor vehicle that are in excess of the expenses resulting from the removal and storage of the vehicle shall be credited to the city's general fund. 
(B)  For those unclaimed motor vehicles that do not meet the definition of abandoned junk motor vehicles, they shall be disposed of pursuant to ORC § 2981.12 or U.A.C.O. Chapter 551. 
(Ord. No. 49-2010) 
§ 551.15 - JUNK MOTOR VEHICLES-DISPOSAL. 
(A)  The chief of police shall order any junk motor vehicle found in violation of C.O. §§ 537.09, 537.10 and 537.11, to be photographed by a law enforcement officer. The officer shall record the make of motor vehicle, the serial number when available, and shall also detail the damage or missing equipment to substantiate the value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less. The chief of police shall thereupon immediately dispose of the junk motor vehicle to a junk yard or scrap metal processing facility as defined in ORC § 4737.05, or to any other facility owned by or under contract with the city for the disposal of such motor vehicles. The records and photographs relating to the junk motor vehicle shall be retained by the chief of police after the disposition of such vehicle for a period of at least two (2) years. Such officer shall execute, in quadruplicate, an affidavit as prescribed by the registrar of motor vehicles, describing the motor vehicle and the manner in which it was disposed of, and that all requirements of this section have been complied with and he shall sign and file the same with the Clerk of Courts of Franklin County. Any monies arising from the disposal of a junk motor vehicle shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 49-2010) 
CHAPTER 552. - INCARCERATION FEES 

§ 552.01 - REIMBURSEMENT. 
Any person who is convicted of an offense, other than a minor misdemeanor, and sentenced to confinement in the Franklin County Jail or the City Workhouse, may be required to reimburse the City of Upper Arlington for its expenses incurred by reason of the offenders' confinement, including, but not limited to, the expenses relating to the provision of food, clothing and shelter. Such reimbursement shall include expenses for pre-conviction confinement when credit for such confinement is credited against the term of imprisonment (in accordance with ORC §§ 307.93, 341.14, 341.18, 341.23, 753.02, 753.04, 753.16, 2301.56, 2929.22.3 and 2947.19). 
§ 552.02 - AMOUNT OF REIMBURSEMENT. 
The amount of the reimbursement required shall be determined by the court after a hearing held pursuant to ORC § 2929.15. The amount of reimbursement ordered by the court shall not exceed the actual costs of the confinement for each day of confinement. 
The court shall consider all factors that affect the offenders financial ability to make reimbursement to the city. Reimbursement may be made either in a lump sum or under a payment plan. 
When the municipal court or mayor's court makes a reimbursement determination pursuant to ORC § 2929.15, a judgment entry and order of reimbursement for expenses of confinement shall be filed and entered that sets forth the total amount of reimbursement due to the city, and the reimbursement schedules and methods. 
§ 552.03 - EXCEPTIONS. 
This ordinance shall not apply to offenders that the court finds to be indigent. 
§ 552.04 - DEPOSITORY. 
Funds that are reimbursed to the city pursuant to this ordinance shall be paid into the general fund of the city treasury. 
§ 552.05 - FAILURE TO PAY. 
If an offender does not pay to the city the reimbursement ordered by the court pursuant to this chapter, the city attorney may collect that claim or institute an appropriate civil action in the name of the city in the Franklin County Common Pleas Court to recover from the convict the reimbursement for the expenses of confinement as determined by the court. If an action is filed, it shall be brought not later than one (1) year after the person is released from incarceration. If it is deemed in the best interests of the city, the city attorney is authorized to compromise and settle such claim in an amount less than the total reimbursement due to the city. 
Part 7 - BUSINESS REGULATION CODE 
CHAPTER 711. - ELECTRICIANS 

§ 711.01 - REGISTRATION FEE, EXPIRATION. 
No person shall engage in the business of installing, maintaining, or repairing electric wiring for light, heat or power within the city unless such person has been registered for such work by this city. At the time of registering, the registrant shall indicate the name of the company for whom he will be applying for permits. Such registration shall be issued provided the applicant possesses a valid and unexpired License as defined in ORC § 4740.01(A) and (D) issued by the State of Ohio. The fee for this registration shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. Such registration shall expire on the 31st of December next ensuing after the date thereof. 
§ 711.02 - REQUIREMENT OF INSURANCE. 
A person desiring to engage in the business of installing, maintaining, or repairing electric wiring for light, heat or power within the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 2, 11-7-2016) 
§ 711.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
CHAPTER 717. - PLUMBERS 

§ 717.01 - REGISTRATION REQUIRED. 
No person shall hereafter follow, engage in or work at the trade or occupation of plumbing in the city, either as a master plumber or journeyman plumber, until he, or the person by whom he is employed shall have first secured a registration in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
§ 717.02 - REGISTRATION FEE, EXPIRATION. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or work at the trade of plumber in the city, either as master or journeyman plumber, unless such person has obtained a plumbing registration from the community development department. Such registration shall be issued provided the applicant possesses a valid and unexpired license as defined in ORC § 4740.01(A) and (E) issued by the State of Ohio. A master plumber's registration shall not be issued until the provisions of C.O. § 717.03 have been complied with. Such registration shall expire on the 31st day of December next ensuing after the date thereof. 
The fees shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 717.03 - REQUIREMENT OF BOND FOR MASTER PLUMBER. 
A master plumber desiring to engage in the plumbing trade in this city shall furnish, prior to the issuance of the registration hereinabove provided for, a bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Ohio in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned to reimburse the City of Upper Arlington for all damage caused by any act or omission of said plumber, his agents or employees, to any property which the city may own or for which it may be responsible, and to hold said city harmless from all claims for damages on account of the negligence or misfeasance of said plumber, his agents or employees, and from all cost or expense growing out of the defense of such claims. Said bond is to be in force from the date of its acceptance and the issuance of registration by the community development department, to the end of the year covered by said registration, and must be renewed annually on the re-issuance of the registration. The bond shall be on a form prescribed by the director. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ; Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 3, 11-7-2016) 
§ 717.04 - REQUIREMENT OF INSURANCE. 
A person desiring to engage in the business of installing, maintaining, or repairing electric wiring for light, heat or power within the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 4, 11-7-2016) 
§ 717.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
CHAPTER 723. - SEWER CONTRACTORS 

§ 723.01 - REGISTRATION REQUIRED: BOND AND FEE. 
Any person, before constructing, repairing or laying any private sanitary sewer line which connects with any public sanitary sewer line owned by the city, shall apply for a registration to the community development department, which application shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with good and sufficient surety to the satisfaction of the community development department, that the registrant shall indemnify, save, defend and hold harmless the city from and against all claims, actions and suits, whether groundless or otherwise, and from and against all liability, losses, damages, costs, charges, counsel fees and other expenses of every nature and character arising from or growing out of the construction, repairing or laying of the same. The bond shall be on a form prescribed by the director. 
The community development department shall charge a registration fee the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02 and the registration shall be valid until the first (1st) day of January of the year following the year of issuance unless canceled for cause or the failure to maintain good and sufficient bond. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ; Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 5, 11-7-2016) 
§ 723.02 - ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION. 
The community development department shall not issue any registration until satisfied that applicant is ready, able and willing to perform such work in a good and workman-like manner and in accordance with the usual and customary standards of sewer construction; and the community development department shall cancel such registration if registrant fails to perform such work in a good and workman-like manner and in accordance with the usual and customary standards of sewer construction or if registrant fails to maintain good and sufficient bond. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 723.03 - REQUIREMENT OF INSURANCE. 
A person desiring to engage in the business of constructing, repairing or laying any private sanitary sewer line which connects with any public sanitary sewer line within the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 6, 11-7-2016) 
§ 723.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
CHAPTER 729. - SIDEWALK AND DRIVEWAY CONTRACTORS 

§ 729.01 - REGISTRATION REQUIRED; FEE. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of constructing or repairing sidewalks or driveways within the limits of any public street in the city, unless such person shall have registered with the community development department and shall have paid the annual fee the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02 for such registration. 
Repair work shall include resurfacing or oiling of blacktop. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 729.02 - APPLICATION; BOND. 
Such applicant for registration shall satisfy the city manager as to his ability to properly and safely install and repair such sidewalks and driveways. Each application shall be accompanied by a bond in the in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with good and sufficient surety to the satisfaction of the city manager, conditioned that such person will pay any and all damages caused by or growing out of such construction or repair work to any property of the city and shall indemnify and save harmless the city from all liability, loss, damages and expenses of every nature growing out of such construction or repair work. The bond shall be on a form prescribed by the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 7, 11-7-2016) 
§ 729.03 - SUSPENSION OF REGISTRATION. 
Registration of any registrant may be suspended or canceled by the city manager for any violation of the ordinances of this city governing such construction or repairs, or for fraud or inferior workmanship, or for failure to maintain a good and sufficient bond. 
§ 729.04 - REQUIREMENT OF INSURANCE. 
A person desiring to engage in the business of installing, maintaining, or repairing sidewalks and driveways within the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 8, 11-7-2016) 
§ 729.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
CHAPTER 730. - TENT, CANOPY, AND MEMBRANE STRUCTURE RENTALS AND CONSTRUCTION 

§ 730.01 - REGISTRATION REQUIRED; FEE. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of renting or constructing tents, canopies, or membrane structures within the city unless such person has registered with the city, in a manner determined by the city manager or designee, and paid the annual fee specified in C.O. ch. 401 for such registration. 
(Ord. No. 63-2016 , § 6, 11-28-2016) 
§ 730.02 - FIRE CODE PERMIT REQUIRED. 
Annual registration with the city under C.O. § 730.01 shall not absolve a person engaged in the business of renting or constructing tents, canopies, or membrane structures within the city from securing the permits required by C.O. § 1701.02. 
§ 730.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates C.O. § 730.01 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
CHAPTER 735. - HOUSE MOVERS 

§ 735.01 - LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; BOND. 
No person, except a licensed house mover, shall move any building over, upon or across any street or alley or from one location to another within the limits of this city. Every person desiring to engage in such business shall annually obtain a license therefor from the city manager, for which a fee, paid in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02, shall be charged, which license shall be in effect until the end of the calendar year on which issued, unless revoked for cause. No such license shall be issued until the party applying therefor shall have given bond in the penal sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), with good and sufficient sureties to the approval of the city manager, conditioned that such party will pay all damages to the property of the city or of other persons, caused by or in any way growing out of, the moving of any building in this city, or the occupancy of any street or alley by such building or the equipment used in connection with such operations, and will pay all damages for injury to or death of any person or persons arising from such moving or occupancy, will indemnify and save harmless this city from all liability, loss, damages and expenses of every nature growing out of such moving or occupancy, and will in all respects strictly comply with the conditions of such license and the conditions of any permit which may be issued as hereinafter provided. The bond shall be on a form prescribed by the director. 
Nothing contained in this section shall apply to the moving of any building, the width of which is not more than eight (8) feet and which is not more than ninety-nine (99) square feet in floor area. 
Each such license issued by the city manager shall be revoked by him for fraudulent use thereof or continued violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 9, 11-7-2016) 
§ 735.02 - MOVING PERMIT AND FEES. 
No person shall move any building or structure without applying for and obtaining a permit from the city manager for such purpose and shall at the time such permit is issued, pay a fee in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02, and shall pay an additional fee in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02 for each day or portion thereof, beyond the first day, during which such building or structure occupies a public street or way in this city. 
§ 735.03 - ROUTE TO BE FOLLOWED. 
The city manager shall, when any building or structure is proposed to be moved over or along any street or public way in the city, designate the streets or other public places to be used in the moving of such building or structure, together with the time which such building or structure may remain upon the street or other public place, and it shall be unlawful for any person to take a different route than the one designated in such permit, or to allow a building or structure to remain in the streets or public places a longer time than so designated. 
§ 735.04 - CONFLICT WITH OTHER LAWS. 
No permit shall be granted for the moving of any building or structure to a location where it would be in violation of any of the ordinances of the city relating to the erection, location or occupancy of buildings or structures. 
§ 735.05 - WARNING LIGHTS AT NIGHT. 
No building or structure shall be permitted to be in any street or alley, or part thereof, from thirty (30) minutes before sunset to thirty (30) minutes after sunrise, unless the licensee moving such building shall adequately warn all persons using such street or alley of the obstruction so existing in such highway by the proper placing of an adequate number of red lights in such position as will reasonably serve such purpose. 
§ 735.06 - REQUIREMENT OF INSURANCE. 
A person desiring to engage in the business of moving any building over, upon or across any street or alley or from one location to another within the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 10, 11-7-2016) 
§ 735.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each and every day's violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
CHAPTER 741. - HEATING, VENTILATING, AIR-CONDITIONING AND REFRIGERATION CONTRACTORS 

§ 741.01 - REGISTRATION FEE, EXPIRATION. 
(A)  There shall be four (4) separate registrations: warm-air heating, steam and hot-water heating, ventilating and air-conditioning and refrigeration. A contractor performing any said types of work shall be required to have a registration and pay the fee for such type. Ventilating systems may be installed by either a warm-air or air-conditioning contractor. Conversion burners may be installed by either a warm-air or steam or hot-water contractor, registered under this section. 
(B)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install, erect, alter, repair, reset or replace as contractor or as person in charge of such operation, any warm-air, steam or hot-water heating plant, plants or parts thereof, or winter or summer air-conditioning or ventilating system, refrigeration and/or cooling systems, or parts thereof as defined in this chapter, within the corporate limits of the city, unless such person is the holder of a registration then in force, issued by this city, giving such person the right to perform or supervise such work, or unless such person has then in his employ, a holder of such registration then in force, charged with supervising such work. Such registration shall be issued provided the applicant possesses a valid and unexpired license as defined in ORC § 4740.01(A), (B) and (C) issued by the State of Ohio. The occupying owner of a dwelling unit may, with the assistance of any member of his immediate family, personally carry on in such unit any work governed by this chapter without such registration(s), provided that such owner shall take out a permit therefore. 
§ 741.02 - FEES FOR REGISTRATION AND RENEWAL. 
Any applicant having complied with the provisions of C.O. § 741.01 shall be issued necessary registrations to supervise and perform any installations and work in the branch or branches of the industry for which such applicant shall have met the requirements of C.O. § 741.01 upon payment of a fee the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02, for each registration required, to the community development department. 
Such registrations shall expire on the thirty-first (31st) day of December next ensuing after the date thereof. 
Any applicant who shall not have renewed his registration within a period of one (1) year after the expiration date thereof shall be issued a new registration only after full compliance with the provision of C.O. § 741.01. The registration shall state whether it is for warm-air heating, ventilation and air-conditioning or steam and hot-water heating. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 741.03 - REQUIREMENT OF INSURANCE. 
A person desiring to install, erect, alter, repair, reset or replace as contractor or as person in charge of such operation, any warm-air, steam or hot-water heating plant, plants or parts thereof, or winter or summer air-conditioning or ventilating system, refrigeration and/or cooling systems within the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 11, 11-7-2016) 
§ 741.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
CHAPTER 745. - DEMOLITION CONTRACTORS 

§ 745.01 - REGISTRATION REQUIRED; FEE. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of demolition of buildings and/or structures in the city unless said person shall have registered with the community development department for said work by this city. 
At the time of registering, the registrant shall indicate the name of the company for whom he will be applying for permits. The fee for this registration shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. Such registration shall expire on the 31 st of December next ensuing after the date thereof. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 745.02 - BOND. 
A demolition contractor desiring to engage in the business of demolition of buildings and/or structures in the city shall furnish, prior to the issuance of the registration hereinabove provided for, a license bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Ohio in the penal sum of not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), conditioned to reimburse the City of Upper Arlington for all damage caused by any act or omission of said demolition contractor, his agents or employees, to any property which the city may own or for which it may be responsible, and to hold said city harmless from all claims for damages on account of the negligence or misfeasance of said demolition contractor, his agents or employees, and from all cost or expense growing out of the defense of such claims. Said license bond is to be in force from the date of its acceptance and the issuance of registration by the community development department, to the end of the year covered by said registration, and must be renewed annually on the re-issuance of the registration. The bond shall be on a form prescribed by the director. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ; Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 12, 11-7-2016) 
§ 745.03 - INSURANCE. 
A demolition contractor desiring to engage in the business of demolition of buildings and/or structures in the city shall maintain contractor's liability insurance, including without limitation, completed operations coverage, in an amount providing for the payment of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one (1) person injured, and up to three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person in one (1) accident, resulting from doing the work authorized by the registration and up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage in the course of doing the work authorized by the registration. The city shall be included as an additional insured. The insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue policies of insurance in the State of Ohio. The applicant shall provide proof of this insurance acceptable to the director. 
(Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 13, 11-7-2016) 
§ 745.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of an unclassified misdemeanor, subject to a fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
CHAPTER 747. - GENERAL CONTRACTORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Enacted through Passage of Ordinance No. 149-2002. 

§ 747.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall be defined as follows: 
    General contractor: means an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, or other entity which builds, constructs, remodels, alters, or otherwise improves any land or building or portion thereof and coordinates other contractors or subcontractors working on the same project. 
    Owner/Resident: means an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, or other entity that is listed as the owner of record with the Franklin County Auditor. 
§ 747.02 - REGISTRATION REQUIRED. 
(A)  No person or entity shall engage in the business of building, constructing, remodeling, alteration of or otherwise improving any land or building or portion thereof in the city unless the person or entity has a valid general contractor registration certificate issued by the city. 
(B)  No person shall permit another person or entity to act as a general contractor in the city unless the person or entity has a valid general contractor registration certificate issued by the city. 
(C)  No person or entity shall act as or claim to be a general contractor in the city, unless that person or entity has a valid general contractor registration certificate issued by the city. 
(D)  No owner/resident shall engage in any work as a general contractor on their property that requires a building permit, unless such owner/resident currently resides at the property or intends to reside at the property upon completion of the project and has submitted a signed owners certificate provided by the community development department stating that: 
(1)  They are the owner/resident of the property; 
(2)  They currently reside at the property or intend to reside at the property upon completion of the project; 
(3)  They will be performing the permitted work; and 
(4)  They will comply with all codes and ordinances. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 747.03 - REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS. 
(A)  A general contractor seeking to register shall submit the following to the community development department: 
(1)  A completed application for registration on a form prescribed by the chief building official; 
(2)  The contractor's certificate of liability insurance demonstrating a minimum combined bodily injury and property damage coverage in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) naming the City of Upper Arlington as the certificate holder. Liability insurance coverage shall be maintained in full force throughout the term of the registration. A copy of any policy changes including renewals shall be forwarded to the building division at least twenty (20) days prior to such changes or renewals taking effect; 
(3)  A license bond executed by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Ohio in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), which bond shall provide that the licensee shall fully indemnify and hold harmless the City of Upper Arlington for all claims for damages on account of the negligence, misfeasance, or failure of such licensee to comply with the terms of any ordinance of the city and with the terms and laws of the State of Ohio. The bond shall be on a form prescribed by the director. Such bond shall be in force throughout the term of the registration and shall be renewed annually prior to renewal of such license; and 
(4)  The registration fee established by city council and set forth in C.O. § 401.02, community development department-master list of fees. 
(B)  Upon submission of the items required above, the chief building official or his designee shall issue a registration certificate. Such registration shall expire on the 31 st of December next ensuing after the date issued. 
(C)  The chief building official may deny an application for registration if: 
(1)  The general contractor fails to submit any of the items required above; 
(2)  The general contractor fails to comply with the applicable requirements of C.O. ch. 13, the State of Ohio building codes, or the city's construction specifications; or 
The general contractor provides false information for permit or registration application; or the general contractor has any outstanding violations of any other ordinances in the City of Upper Arlington; or 
(3)  The general contractor has had a prior registration certificate revoked within the past three (3) years. 
(D)  An owner/resident may engage in work as a general contractor on their own property without obtaining a general contractor registration certificate if: 
(1)  They currently reside at the property or intend to reside at the property upon completion of the project; and 
(2)  They fully comply with the requirements of C.O. § 747.02(D). 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ; Ord. No. 58-2016 , § 14, 11-7-2016) 
§ 747.04 - ASSIGNMENT, TRANSFER, USE BY THIRD PERSONS. 
A registered general contractor shall not assign, transfer or allow any other person to use its registration certificate for any purpose. 
§ 747.05 - SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION. 
(A)  The chief building official may immediately suspend or revoke a registration certificate or deny renewal of a registration certificate if: 
(1)  The general contractor fails to comply with the requirements of C.O. ch. 13, the State of Ohio building codes, or the city's construction specifications; 
(2)  The general contractor fails to maintain the required three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) liability insurance coverage pursuant to C.O. § 747.03(A)(2); 
(3)  The general contractor fails to maintain and renew the required five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) license bond pursuant to C.O. § 747.03(A)(3); or 
(4)  The general contractor is issued one (1) or more "Stop Work" orders for code violations that remain unresolved during any calendar year. 
(B)  An order of the chief building official suspending or revoking a general contractor's registration certificate shall be effective upon written notice served upon the general contractor. 
§ 747.06 - APPEALS. 
If the chief building official denies a general contractor's application for registration, suspends or revokes a general contractor's registration certificate, or denies renewal of a registration certificate, the general contractor shall have the right to appeal to the Upper Arlington Board of Building Standards. The contractor shall submit a notice of appeal to the board of building standards within ten (10) days from receipt of the order of the chief building official. The general contractor must also pay the required fees for such appeal pursuant to C.O. § 401.02, community development department-master list of fees. Notwithstanding C.O. § 1306.07, the decision of the board of building standards shall be final. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 747.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each and every day's violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the above penalty, the city may seek injunctive relief or any other remedy provided by law. 
CHAPTER 761. - OUTDOOR ENTERTAINMENT 

§ 761.01 - LICENSE REQUIRED. 
No person shall present or exhibit, or participate in presenting or exhibiting, any circus, menagerie, carnival, fair, free show or similar form of outdoor entertainment whether under a tent or otherwise, without first obtaining a license therefor from the city manager. 
§ 761.02 - FEE. 
The license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each and every day, or part thereof, the circus or other entertainment is exhibited or performed. 
§ 761.03 - CONSENT OF OWNERS OR TENANTS. 
If there are one (1) or more buildings used for residence purposes within a distance of four hundred (400) feet from the lot or parcel of ground on which such circus or other entertainment is to be given, the application for license shall be accompanied by a written consent signed by the majority of the tenants or owners occupying the buildings used for residence purposes within such distance. 
§ 761.04 - PUBLIC GROUNDS RESTRICTED. 
The license shall not give any right to use or occupy any public street or other public land in connection with a circus or other entertainment and no street or other public land shall be so used or occupied for such purpose without permission therefor given in advance by action of council. 
§ 761.99 - PENALTY.
