Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
CHAPTER 767. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 

§ 767.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Canvasser: means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been requested or invited by the occupant thereof, who seeks to disseminate any verbal or written message, including ideas, thoughts or messages regarding any cause, issue, or religion; any person circulating petitions for signatures; or any political candidate, by means of traveling from place-to-place without acting as a solicitor, and whose actions do not violate any local, state or federal law. Canvasser includes a person who requests a voluntary donation to a non-profit organization as part of the verbal or written message. Nothing in this definition exempts a canvasser from the requirements of any other chapter of the Codified Ordinances, including any section imposing criminal liability. 
    Charitable: Includes the words patriotic, philanthropic, social service, welfare, benevolent, educational, civic, fraternal, veteran's medical and social research. 
    Peddler: means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been requested or invited by the occupant thereof, carrying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature and offering the same for sale. This definition also includes any person who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as part of a scheme to evade the provisions of this chapter. 
    Person: means any person, firm, corporation, association, club, society or other organization. 
    Premises: as used within the context of C.O. ch. 767, shall be defined as the area of an estate, including land and/or buildings and its appurtenances thereon, used for residential purposes. 
    Religious or religion: Shall not include the word charitable, but shall be given their commonly accepted definitions. 
    Solicitor: means any person who goes upon the premises of any private residence in the city, not having been requested or invited by the occupant thereof, for taking or soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature for future delivery, or for services to be performed in the future. This definition also includes any person who requests, either directly or indirectly, money or financial assistance on a plea or representation that it will be used for a specific purpose, except for canvassers requesting a voluntary donation to a non-profit organization as part of their verbal or written message. 
(Ord. No. 25-2018 , §§ 1, 2, 4-9-2018) 
§ 767.02 - REGISTRATION AND PERMIT REQUIRED. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a peddler or solicitor without first registering for a permit, pursuant to C.O. § 767.03; paying a registration fee, pursuant to C.O. § 767.04; and obtaining a permit, pursuant to C.O. § 767.05. Each person engaged in such business shall be required to register, pay the registration fee, and obtain a permit regardless of whether other employees or agents of the same entity have registered. 
Canvassers shall be exempt from registration, shall be exempt from paying a registration fee, and shall be exempt from obtaining a permit. 
§ 767.03 - REGISTRATION PROCESS. 
Any person seeking to engage in the business of a peddler or solicitor in the City of Upper Arlington shall register for a permit with the city by completing an application form provided by the city manager. Said application shall be submitted to the city manager or his/her designee no later than thirty (30) days prior to the commencement of business. 
The application form shall require the following documentation, and any other information deemed necessary by the city manager or his/her designee. If the applicant is an organization, each and every individual who seeks to peddle or solicit on behalf of the organization shall complete an application and provide the following documentation: 
(1)  Name of the applicant or organization; 
(2)  A brief physical description of the applicant, including age, weight and height; 
(3)  The applicant's or organization's social security number or federal identification number; 
(4)  The name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed or for whom he is soliciting, if any, and the length of the applicant's service with such employer or person; 
(5)  All places of residence of the applicant and all employment during the preceding year; 
(6)  The nature and character of the goods to be sold or services to be furnished or the purpose for which funds are being peddled or solicited by the applicant or organization; 
(7)  The names of other municipalities in which the applicant or organization has conducted peddling or solicitation activities; 
(8)  Verification that the applicant or organization has complied with the requirements pertaining to charitable solicitations, if applicable; 
(9)  If the applicant or organization is a not-for-profit organization, applicant must provide a copy of a currently valid ruling or determination letter recognizing the tax-exempt status of the organization pursuant to Internal Revenue Code § 501(C)(3); 
(10)  Applicant shall make available and permit the city to copy his/her current, valid drivers license or other current, valid government-issued identification that contains a picture of the applicant; 
(11)  Disclosure of any prior or current criminal record; 
(12)  Period of time for which permit is requested; 
(13)  Signatures of the peddler or solicitor and/or official of the organization. 
§ 767.04 - REGISTRATION FEE. 
Upon filing the registration application with the city manager, the person shall pay a fee sufficient to cover the cost to the city of processing the application. The amount of the fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), plus any additional costs related to processing the application, such as a background check. 
§ 767.05 - ISSUANCE OF PERMIT. 
Upon an investigation and determination by the city manager or his/her designee, a permit shall be issued subject to the following conditions: 
(A)  All of the statements made in the application are true; 
(B)  The applicant or organization proposes to engage in a lawful commercial or professional enterprise; 
(C)  Neither the applicant or organization nor enterprise upon which the applicant or organization proposes to engage constitutes a clear and present danger to the residents of the municipality; 
(D)  The applicant or organization has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise; 
(E)  The business of the peddler or solicitor will not be a fraud upon the public; 
(F)  The applicant or organization has not been convicted of any felony and/or crime involving moral turpitude (e.g., theft, passing bad checks, misuse of a credit card, unauthorized use of property or vehicle, identity theft, etc.); 
(G)  The applicant and/or organization possesses a positive overall quality, public esteem or character as seen or judged by people in general and does not offend the sensibilities of people in general; 
(H)  Neither the applicant nor the organization has engaged in a disruptive, threatening, or discourteous manner or behavior; 
(I)  The city shall conduct an independent record check of all applicants, at the expense of the applicant. The city manager shall have the authority to exempt an applicant from the record check based on information known to the city, such as prior history, locally established connections, community ties, scholastic endeavors, non-profit history, or similar information. 
§ 767.06 - FRAUD PROHIBITED; REVOCATION OF PERMIT. 
(A)  No person shall directly or indirectly make or perpetrate any misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation or peddling for any purpose in the city or in any application filed under C.O. ch. 767. 
(B)  No person having entered into an agreement to conduct any peddling or soliciting on behalf of any person or organization shall fail to remit or pay to the party entitled thereto the proceeds of such peddling or solicitation in accordance with the terms of the agreement; nor shall the city be a party or held liable to any such agreement. 
(C)  The city manager or his/her designee may revoke at any time any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter for violation of any provision of this chapter, or for good cause, which may include, but is not limited to, disruptive or discourteous behavior during the peddling or solicitation process, harassment of residents, or claims of damage by residents. 
§ 767.07 - PERMIT EXPIRATION. 
All permits issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire sixty (60) days from date of issuance, unless an earlier expiration date is noted on the permit. 
§ 767.08 - PERMIT EXHIBITION. 
Every person receiving a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall at all times wear the permit conspicuously attached on their outer clothing. 
§ 767.09 - PERMIT TRANSFER PROHIBITED. 
It is unlawful for any person other than the original permit holder to use or exhibit any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
§ 767.10 - HOURS RESTRICTED. 
It is unlawful for any person, while conducting the business of a peddler, solicitor or canvasser to enter upon the premises of any private residence between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
§ 767.11 - POSTED PREMISES. 
It is unlawful for any person, while conducting the business of a peddler, solicitor or canvasser in the city, to enter upon the premises of any private residence where the owner, occupant, or person legally in charge of the premises has posted, at the entry to the premises, or at the entry to the principal building on the premises, a sign bearing the words No Peddlers, No Solicitors, No Canvassers, No Trespassing or words of similar import. 
§ 767.12 - CHARITABLE, NON-PROFIT AND RELIGIOUS SOLICITATIONS. 
Any person who solicits for charitable, non-profit or religious purposes shall complete a registration application with the city manager. No fee shall be required. 
Each non-profit applicant or organization that does not meet the definition of "charitable" shall provide with his/her registration application a copy of a currently valid ruling or determination letter recognizing the tax-exempt status of the organization pursuant to the Internal Revenue Code § 501(C)(3). 
§ 767.99 - PENALTY. 
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. The penalty upon conviction of such person shall be imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days and/or a fine not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
CHAPTER 771. - STREET SOLICITATION 

§ 771.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
As used in this chapter, the following words are defined as hereafter set forth: 
    Charitable organization: shall means any organization that has received from the Internal Revenue Service a currently valid ruling or determination letter recognizing the tax-exempt status of the organization pursuant to the Internal Revenue Code § 501(C)(3). 
    Contribution: the gift, sale for less than market value or purchase for more than market value of alms, food, clothing, money or property, to include donations under the guise of a loan of money or property or the rental thereof for any charitable use or purpose. 
    Solicit and solicitation: the request, either directly or indirectly, for money or financial assistance on the plea or representation that such money or financial assistance will be used for a charitable purpose. Without limiting the generality of the above, the words solicit and solicitation shall include the following methods of securing money or financial assistance on the plea or representation that it will be used for a charitable purpose: 
(A)  Any oral or written request. 
(B)  The distribution or circulation of any handbills, written advertisement or publication. 
A solicitation, as defined herein, shall be deemed completed when made, whether or not the person making the same receives any contribution or makes any sale. 
§ 771.02 - STREET SOLICITATION. 
Any organization seeking to solicit contributions on a street, highway or roadway for charitable purposes shall apply for a permit with the City of Upper Arlington on an application form provided by the city manager for the purpose of said solicitation. Said application shall be submitted not later than thirty (30) days prior to said event and a permit shall be issued by the city manager subject to the following conditions: 
(A)  Street, highway or roadway solicitation shall be conducted only by charitable organizations. Charitable organizations seeking to solicit shall submit a currently valid ruling or determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service recognizing the tax-exempt status of the organization pursuant to the Internal Revenue Code § 501(C)(3). Said Internal Revenue Service ruling or determination must be attached to the application. 
(B)  A permit under this section shall not be issued to an organization for more than one (1) day each calendar year. 
(C)  The city manager may limit the locations of said solicitation if such solicitation may cause excessive traffic congestion or hazard or conflicts with a previously issued parade permit or scheduled event. 
(D)  All street, highway or roadway solicitors shall wear light-colored clothing and must display identification which delineates the organization conducting the solicitation. 
(E)  All street or highway solicitations shall be conducted only when traffic has stopped for a red light. 
(F)  Solicitations shall not occur during adverse weather conditions that limit a motorist's visibility, or would otherwise be cause for excessive traffic congestion, constitute a traffic safety hazard, or impede emergency vehicle access. The chief of police or his designee shall be responsible for determining if such conditions may be caused or exist and may order the cancellation or cessation of said solicitations. 
(G)  Street, highway or roadway solicitations shall occur during daylight hours for a period not greater than eight (8) hours in any calendar day and shall not begin prior to one (1) hour after sunrise nor shall they extend beyond 5:00 p.m. or one (1) hour before sunset, whichever occurs first. In addition, no solicitations shall occur at the following times: Sundays or Holidays, Monday through Friday 7:30 a.m.-8:30 a.m.; 11:30 a.m.-1:30 p.m.; 4:30 p.m.-6:30 p.m. 
(H)  No person under the age of eighteen (18) shall conduct any street, highway or roadway solicitation. 
(I)  Any organization seeking a permit for street, highway or roadway solicitation shall provide the City of Upper Arlington with a current certificate of insurance of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) that insures the organization for any and all claims that may arise as a result of soliciting contributions in the street, highway or roadway and which insurance policy contains a clause that names the City of Upper Arlington and its officers, agents or employees as additional named insured under such policy. 
(J)  The person responsible for said organization shall execute a signed release on behalf of all solicitors exempting the City of Upper Arlington and its officers, agents or employees from any and all liability and agreeing to indemnify, hold harmless, and defend any and all claims against said city for personal or bodily injury, or property damage which may occur as a result of said street, highway or roadway solicitations in the City of Upper Arlington. 
§ 771.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter or any condition of a permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined as prescribed by C.O. ch. 501. 
CHAPTER 773. - TAXICABS 

§ 773.01 - LICENSE REQUIRED. 
No taxicab shall be kept for hire and regularly operated in the city, unless a valid license has been issued to the owner and the operator thereof and is in force by the City of Columbus in accordance with Columbus City Codes §§ 587, 589 and 591. The city manager may waive any or all of these regulations for a taxi company that proposes to operate exclusively within the geographical boundaries of the City of Upper Arlington. 
The term taxicab shall not be held to include motor buses or automobiles leased or rented for private use without the services of a chauffeur or driver. 
(Ord. No. 17-2010) 
§ 773.02 - AFFIRMATIVE DEFENSE. 
It shall be an affirmative defense under C.O. § 773.01 that the owners, drivers or operators of any taxicabs kept for hire and regularly operated held a valid license in any Ohio municipality, provided the license meets the same or substantially similar requirements and regulations as set forth in City of Columbus Codes §§ 587, 589 and 591. 
(Ord. No. 17-2010) 
§ 773.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor and fined not more than one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. No. 17-2010) 
CHAPTER 775. - PUBLIC MASS TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS 

§ 775.01 - UNAUTHORIZED PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION SERVICE. 
No person shall engage in the operation of a public mass transportation system within this city, by means of motor vehicles or otherwise, whether such operation consists of one (1) or more routes, without the approval of the council, acting by ordinance, which ordinance may provide for the determination of fares, routes, schedules, type of equipment and other conditions of service. 
§ 775.02 - EXCEPTED OPERATIONS. 
This chapter shall not apply to any of the following: 
(A)  School buses, while operated for the transportation of school children and other authorized personnel to and from school or school sponsored activities. 
(B)  Buses operated by or on behalf of churches for transportation to or from church services or other church sponsored activities. 
(C)  Limited transportation activities similar to those described in C.O. § 775.02(A) and (B), in which transportation is not offered or furnished to the general public. 
(D)  Any motor transportation company as defined in ORC ch. 4921, whose route or routes provided by its certificate of convenience and necessity extend into or through this city, to the extent that the operations of such company within this city are authorized by and under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio. 
(E)  Chartered motor bus service. 
§ 775.03 - UNAUTHORIZED SERVICE BY CERTIFICATED CARRIERS. 
No motor transportation company, as defined in ORC ch. 4921, shall carry passengers whose complete ride is within this city, or whose ride is to or from this city and a contiguous city or cities, unless authorized to do so pursuant to ordinance or resolution of the council. 
§ 775.04 - EXCEPTION AS TO EMERGENCY SERVICE. 
The provisions of C.O. §§ 775.01 and 775.03 shall not apply to a public mass transportation operation authorized by the city manager authorization heretofore or hereafter given him by the council. 
§ 775.05 - AUTHORITY OF CITY MANAGER IN EMERGENCIES. 
The city manager shall have authority, in the event of a breakdown or threatened breakdown of public transportation service in this city, to make temporary arrangements to provide such service within this city and between this city and contiguous cities, to continue for such period of time as he deems necessary, unless sooner terminated by action of the council. 
§ 775.06 - APPLICATION OF C.O. §§ 775.01, 775.03 AND 775.99. 
The provisions of C.O. §§ 775.01, 775.03 and 775.99 shall apply to all persons, firms and corporations participating in the activities proscribed or regulated by said sections, whether as principals, agents, employees or otherwise, including operators or drivers of vehicles used in such activities. 
§ 775.99 - PENALTIES. 
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisoned not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
CHAPTER 776. - PROPANE GAS INSTALLATIONS 

§ 776.01 - ADOPTION OF STANDARDS. 
The provisions of National Fire Protection Association, entitled NFPA Standard 58-92-Standard for the Storage and Handling of Liquified Petroleum Gases, are hereby adopted and shall govern such installations in this city, and the use, servicing, maintenance and removal thereof, except as otherwise provided herein or by statute or lawful regulation adopted pursuant to statute. 
§ 776.02 - REGULATION AND APPROVAL BY THE CITY MANAGER. 
The city manager is authorized to regulate and approve site locations for installations in all non-residence districts, and also in residence districts in cases where the capacity of the tank or tanks proposed to be installed on a residence site is more than one thousand (1,000) gallons. Such approval may be conditioned upon reasonable requirements for landscaping or otherwise minimizing unsightly conditions incident to such installations. 
§ 776.03 - FENCING. 
A chain link fence, eight (8) feet in height, shall surround every tank or group of tanks having a capacity of more than one thousand (1,000) gallons. Barbed wire shall not be used in connection with such fence. Such a fence may be required for tanks having a capacity of less than one thousand (1,000) gallons in non-residential districts, if the city manager deems the same necessary in the interest of public safety. 
§ 776.04 - RESTRICTIONS AS TO EXISTING BUILDINGS. 
Propane gas installations shall not be made for the purpose of serving any existing building which can be served by natural gas, unless such installation is required by reason of an addition to such building for which natural gas is unavailable. 
§ 776.05 - DISCONTINUANCE OF USE. 
The use of liquified petroleum gas tanks shall be discontinued within six (6) months from the time when natural gas pipe line service becomes available to any property being served by such tanks. 
§ 776.06 - REMOVAL OF TANKS AND ACCESSORIES. 
Storage tanks and their accessory equipment, including fences, shall be removed within three (3) months after discontinuance of the use thereof, unless an extension of time is authorized by the city manager because of special circumstances which would work a hardship on the owner of the premises involved. 
§ 776.99 - PENALTIES. 
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than six (6) months, or both. 
CHAPTER 777. - CABLE SYSTEMS AND VIDEO SERVICE 

§ 777.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cable service: means (1) the one-way transmission to subscribers of video programming or other programming service and (2) subscriber interaction, if any, which is required for the selection or use of such video programming or other programming service. 
    Cable system: means a facility, consisting of a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal generation, reception, and control equipment that is designed to provide cable service which includes video programming and which is provided to multiple subscribers within a community, but such term does not include (1) a facility that serves only to retransmit the television signals of one (1) or more television broadcast stations; (2) a facility that serves only subscribers without using any public right-of-way; (3) a facility of a common carrier which is subject, in whole or in part, to the provisions of Title II [47 U.S.C. § 201 et seq.] of the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, except that such facility shall be considered a cable system (other than for purposes of 47 U.S.C. § 541(c)) to the extent such facility is used in the transmission of video programming directly to subscribers; or (4) any facilities of any electric utility used solely for operating its electric utility system. 
    Gross revenues: means all cash, credit, property of any kind or nature, or other consideration received by an operator arising from or attributable to the sale or exchange of cable services by the operator within the city or in any way derived from the operation of its system for the provision of such services, including, but not limited to, monthly fees charged to subscribers for basic services; monthly fees charged to subscribers for any optional service; monthly fees charged to subscribers for any tier optional service; monthly fees charged to subscribers for any tier of service other than basic service; pay television fees; installation, disconnection and reconnection and late payment fees; leased channel fees; fees, payments or other consideration received from programmers (exclusive of payments in support of marketing); convertor rentals or sales; and the sale, exchange or cablecast of any programming developed on or for community service channels or institutional users. Traditional advertising revenues and revenues from home shopping channels and like services in which goods or services are purchased by subscribers utilizing the system which are not delivered to or on behalf of the subscribers via the system shall not be included in gross revenues; provided, however, that infomercials and rental or lease payments for programming or channel time and like revenues are not classified as advertising revenue. This sum shall be the basis for computing the fee imposed pursuant to C.O. § 777.10 hereof. This sum shall not include any taxes on services furnished by an operator which are imposed upon any subscriber or user by the state, county, city or other governmental unit and collected by the operator on behalf of said governmental unit. Other than adjustments of subscriber refunds and uncollectibles, there shall be no other deductions from this sum unless specified herein. Gross revenues shall also include revenues received by an operator's affiliates, subsidiaries, parent, or any person in which an operator has a financial interest, arising from or attributable to the sale or exchange of cable services within the city, where such revenue was diverted by the operator in such a manner as to lower gross revenues and therefore paid for services permit fees hereunder. 
    Operator: means any person, persons, partnership, firm, company, corporation or association operating a cable system and holding a permit granted by an ordinance of council to operate same within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Transmission and distribution, carriage and/or utilization and origination: refer to methods, techniques and procedures in the operation of a cable system as authorized by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), either by virtue of enabling rules and regulations or in the absence of prohibiting rules and regulations. 
§ 777.02 - TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION OF SIGNALS. 
The transmission and distribution of electronic signals may be made at the option of the operator, as follows; and, in addition to being as authorized by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) shall be in accordance with applicable law. 
(A)  Through coaxial cable, fiber optic and/or other digital or analog conductors installed in underground conduit owned and maintained by the operator, or attached to poles or installed in underground conduit of electric or telephone utility companies now in existence or hereafter lawfully installed and in use by one of said utilities as transmission or distribution lines. No cable, wire or other conductor and no other equipment, fixture or apparatus used or designed for use in any cable system shall be erected or installed above the surface of the ground, except as herein specifically permitted. Notwithstanding the above, the operator may request permission from the city manager to install poles, in situations where poles are reasonably required for the operation of the cable system. In such situations, the city manager shall not unreasonably withhold permission to place the poles. 
Notwithstanding the authorization for the use by the operator of electric or telephone utility poles, the operator shall discontinue the use of said poles at such time as they are no longer being used by the electric and telephone companies, it being the intent hereof that if said utility companies substitute underground transmission or distribution lines for any material portion of their overhead lines, the operator shall provide underground conduits or make other arrangement for such portions of its lines, in order that the poles and attached conductors may be removed. 
(1)  The operator shall grant to the city, free of expense, joint use of all its underground conduit, for any proper municipal purposes, insofar as it may be done without interfering with the operator's own use thereof. For purposes of this section, proper municipal purposes shall not include the operation of a municipally owned cable system or the resale or assignment of operator's conduit space by the city to third parties. 
(a)  If the city makes any use of conduit owned and maintained by the operator, the city shall hold the operator harmless from any and all actions, causes of action, or damages caused by the city's use thereof. 
(b)  Any construction and utilization by the city, as regards conduit of the operator, shall conform to the same requirements set forth for the operator in the general areas of safety, quality, maintenance and RF (radio frequency) interference. 
(2)  The city shall grant to the operator, free of expense, joint use of all its underground conduit, for any proper cable system purposes, insofar as it may be done without interfering with the city's own use thereof. 
(a)  If the operator makes any use of conduit owned and maintained by the city, the operator shall hold the city harmless from any and all actions, causes of action, or damages caused by the operator's use thereof. 
(b)  Any construction and utilization by the operator, as regards conduit of the city, shall conform to the requirements set forth in this ordinance in the general areas of safety, quality, maintenance and RF (Radio frequency) interference. 
(3)  The right of construction, including easements, is not implied, except in locations where the city has the authority to grant such rights and easements or except as permitted by Federal law. In such locations, the city manager may authorize such construction, if it will not conflict with other public uses thereof. All other rights of construction, including easements, shall be the responsibility of the operator. 
(4)  No construction either on poles or of underground conduit shall begin without prior written approval of the city manager; provided, however, the city manager shall issue all necessary work authorizations for the construction of the cable system upon passage of an ordinance of council authorizing a permit to operator pursuant to this chapter. 
(5)  All trimming of trees necessitated by the operator's installations, whether on public or private property, shall be the responsibility of the operator and shall be accomplished by competent professional tree trimmers, approved by the city manager, in accordance with the requirements of C.O. ch. 907 of the streets and services code. 
(6)  Before commencing work within any easement area on private property (other than an easement obtained by the operator directly from the property owner), the operator shall give written notice to the owner of such property as to the proposed construction and/or installations to be made in such area. Such notice shall be given at least seven (7) days before commencement of any construction or installation. 
(B)  Through the air by means of radiowave transmission facilities of the operator, either totally or in part in combination with C.O. § 777.02(A). 
(C)  Through the air by means of radiowaves transmitted by some other common carrier source, including satellite, either totally or in part in combination with C.O. § 777.02(A) and (B). 
(D)  Through any combination of the alternatives for transmission and distributions of signals hereinabove set forth. 
§ 777.03 - CONDITIONS OF SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION, MAINTENANCE AND OPERATION. 
The operator shall comply with the following conditions, and the city shall be charged specifically with the duty of enforcing the provisions of this section. 
(A)  Construction and maintenance of the transmission and distribution system shall be in accordance with the National Electrical Code (also referred to as the Code of the Board of Underwriters), and such applicable ordinances and regulations of the State of Ohio and the City of Upper Arlington as may be presently in effect or may become effective in the future. 
(B)  The operator shall, at its cost and expense, install and maintain during the life of the permit granted by ordinance and/or cause to be installed and maintained adequate shielding, filtering and grounding as to prevent interference with television and radio reception of non-subscribers to the operator's service or services. 
(C)  All Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rules and regulations governing RF (radio frequency) interference presently in effect, and as may become effective in the future, will be observed. 
(D)  All installations of equipment shall be of a permanent nature and durable, installed in accordance with accepted good engineering practices; sufficient to comply with all existing State of Ohio and City of Upper Arlington rules, regulations and ordinances, so as not to interfere in any material manner with the right of the public or individual property owners; and shall not materially interfere with the use or enjoyment of public or private property adjacent thereto. The operator shall obtain advance written approval by the city manager. city manager approval of any installation of equipment in, on, or over any public street or other property owned by the city or in which the city holds easement rights, shall not be unreasonably withheld. Upon completion of such installation, the operator shall furnish the city manager with accurate maps and other supporting data showing the location of such installation. In the event that any such installation should thereafter interfere with a proposed public use of such property or easement, the operator shall, upon written request by the city manager, relocate such installation, at the operator's expense. 
(E)  In operating its system, the operator shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Technical standards set forth in the Federal Communications Commission Rules and Regulations, Part 76, Subpart K . 
(2)  The operator shall interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions insofar as possible shall be preceded by notice, and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the cable system. 
(3)  The operator will strive, insofar as practical and economically feasible, for the betterment of the cable system, taking advantage of all reasonable improvements as they become available to it. 
(F)  The operator shall maintain a payment center in Franklin County, Ohio, which will be open at least 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday and at least 9:00 a.m. to noon Saturdays, excluding legal holidays. The operator shall have either a local or a toll free telephone number and an adequate number of telephone lines to handle typical traffic, and will be so operated that complaints and requests for repairs and adjustments may be received and processed with a minimum of delay. 
(G)  The operator shall meet the customer service standards set forth in the Federal Communications Commission Rules and Regulations, Part 76, Subpart H, Section 76.309. 
(H)  The operator shall provide the city manager with the name of its chief management employee, so that complaints or comments made to any city office may be referred to that person for proper action. 
(I)  In the case of any emergency or disaster, the operator shall, upon request of the city manager or the official performing the duties of the city manager, make available, without charge, one (1) video and audio channel for use by the city during emergency or emergency access regulations or standards, the operator shall provide service consistent with such standards and be deemed in compliance. 
(J)  The operator shall install one (1) drop with standard service without initial or monthly charge to each and all public and private elementary and secondary schools located within the City of Upper Arlington. 
(1)  Any internal distribution system installed by a school must conform to all applicable federal, state and city rules, regulations and ordinances, and must be operated in such a manner as not to interfere with the operator's system. 
(K)  The operator shall install one (1) drop with standard service without initial or monthly charge, to the following locations within the city: 
(1)  Municipal services center; 
(2)  Fire House No. 1; 
(3)  Fire House No. 2; 
(4)  Fire House No. 3; 
(5)  Upper Arlington Public Library; 
(6)  Each recreation center operated by the city. 
(L)  The operator shall provide its standard monthly service, excluding premium services and pay per view, without charge to the municipal services center and each recreation center operated by the city. 
(1)  Installation and service will be subject only to the municipal services center and recreation center being contiguous to a main or lateral cable, or within range of radiowaves, if radiowaves are utilized by the operator for the transmission and each distribution of signals. 
(M)  The operator shall provide without charge complete monitoring facilities, including installation, necessary equipment and maintenance of said equipment, up to and including six (6) city offices, to be designated by the city manager. 
(1)  The monitoring equipment will permit sampling of all services offered by the operator. 
(2)  Monitoring facilities will be provided whether the city offices are located contiguous to main or lateral cables or not, and even if special construction is required for their activation. 
(N)  In lieu of complying with the provisions of C.O. § 777.03(J)-(M) hereof, the city may allow the operator to substitute alternative services, of substantially the same value. Said alternative services shall be described in the permit issued pursuant to C.O. ch. 777. 
(O)  Operator shall carry all government access programming designated by the city manager or his designee on a government access channel provided, free of charge, for the city's use. Government access programming shall be carried on the same channel number by each cable system. If operators are unable to agree on channel designation, the city manager shall mediate the issue between the operators. If mediation fails to resolve the issue then the city manager shall designate the channel number. 
§ 777.04 - CABLECASTING. 
The operator shall comply with the regulations set forth in 47 C.F.R. Part 1, Subpart G. 
§ 777.05 - INDEMNIFICATION, INSURANCE AND BONDS. 
(A)  The operator shall indemnify and save harmless the City of Upper Arlington and all agents, officers, employees and representatives thereof from all claims, demands, causes of action, copyright action, liability, judgments, costs and expenses or losses for injury or death to persons or damage to property owned by and Workers' Compensation claims against any parties indemnified herein, arising out of, caused by, or as a result of the operator's construction, erection, maintenance, use or presence of, or removal of any poles, wires, lines, cable, conduit, appurtenances thereto, or equipment of attachments thereto. 
(B)  The city shall give operator reasonably prompt written notice of any claim, demand, action or proceeding for which indemnification will be sought under this provision of the agreement and, if such claim, demand, action or proceeding is a third-party claim, demand, action or proceeding, franchisee will have the right at its expense to assume the defense of such claim, demand, action or proceeding, using counsel reasonably acceptable to the city. The city shall have the right to participate, at its own expense, with respect to any such third-party claim, demand, action or proceeding that operator so defends. In connection with any such third-party claim, demand, action or proceeding, operator and the city shall cooperate with each other and provide each other with access to relevant books and records in their possession. No such third-party claim, demand, action or proceeding shall be settled without the prior written consent of the city, which consent the city shall not unreasonably withhold or delay. 
(1)  The operator shall carry good and sufficient public liability and property damage insurance to fulfill the terms of C.O. § 777.05 (A), which insurance shall be in the amounts of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage in any one occurrence, or less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate in any single policy year; and not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) bodily injury or death of any one (1) person, with a minimum of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) as to any one (1) occurrence. Such policy shall be subject to the approval of the city attorney as to its form and extent of coverage (as distinguished from dollar amount of coverage). Such policy shall specifically insure against claims arising as the result of underground excavation. 
(2)  The City of Upper Arlington shall be named as an additional insured in any such policy (or policies). 
(3)  The policy (or policies) shall provide by endorsement that it may only be canceled or amended by the insurance company after sixty (60) days notice, in writing, to the city manager. 
(4)  Said policy (or policies) must be in force before the operator commences any construction or installations. 
(5)  The operator shall provide the city with a certificate of insurance. 
(6)  The policy shall provide that the naming of the city as an additional insured shall not exempt the insurer from liability to the city for damage to property owned by it or in which it has an interest. 
(7)  All contractors and subcontractors of the operator must comply with the insurance requirements of C.O. § 777.05(B)(1)-(6). 
(C)  Upon termination, non-renewal or revocation of its permit or upon cessation of operations by the operator, said operator is under obligation to remove all of its equipment and installations over and under city streets, at the request of council; over and under private property at the request of the property owners; and from the homes or business establishments of subscribers, at their request. This section is subject to the rules and regulations of the FCC regarding cable home wiring. 
(1)  The operator shall post bond in the sum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) guaranteeing the removal of all its equipment and installations, if its operation ceases, whatever the cause or reason, if requested to do so by the council, individual private property owners or subscribers. 
(2)  Such bonding as called for in C.O. § 777.05(B)(1), shall be subject to these requirements: 
(a)  Such bond shall be executed by the operator and one (1) or more sureties authorized to do business in the State of Ohio, and shall be approved by the city attorney as to form. 
(b)  Either the bond (or bonds) or certified copies must be on file with the city manager. 
(c)  The bond (or bonds) must provide by endorsement that it cannot be canceled or amended by the bonding company prior to ten (10) days notice to the city manager. 
(d)  Said bond (or bonds) must be effective before the operator commences any construction or installations. 
(D)  The operator shall maintain and, within thirty (30) days of the effective date of this ordinance, specifically agrees to maintain throughout the term hereof, a faithful performance bond running to the city, executed by a surety company authorized to do business as surety in the State of Ohio, in the penal sum of up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to ensure that the operator shall well and truly observe, fulfill and perform each term and condition of this chapter, and that, in case of any breach of this chapter, the amount of all damages and penalties proximately resulting from the failure of the company to well and faithfully observe and perform any provision of this chapter shall be recoverable by the city from said bond. 
(1)  Such bond shall be executed by the operator and one (1) or more sureties authorized to do business in the State of Ohio, and shall be approved by the city attorney as to form. 
(2)  Either the bond (or bonds) or certified copies must be on file with the city manager. 
(3)  The bond (or bonds) must provide by endorsement that it cannot be canceled or amended by the bonding company prior to thirty (30) days notice to the city manager. 
(E)  The city manager, in his discretion, may waive the requirements of C.O. § 777.05(C) and (D). 
§ 777.06 - RATES FOR SERVICES TO SUBSCRIBERS. 
(A)  The city will follow the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Rate Regulations in its regulation of the service rates and charges of any cable television system operating in the city, notwithstanding any different or inconsistent provisions in C.O. ch. 777. In connection with such regulation, the city will ensure a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties. The city manager, or his or her designee, is authorized to execute on behalf of the city and file with the FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC Rate Regulations in order to enable the city to regulate service rates and charges; provided, however, this advance notice requirement shall not apply to bona fide promotional pricing or sales efforts by operator. 
(B)  The operator shall file a schedule of all of its rates with the city manager no less than thirty (30) days in advance of the effective date of such rates or the commencement of a new service, or of a change in established rates and upon notification to subscribers of such rates or rate changes; provided, however, this advance notice requirement shall not apply to bona fide promotional pricing or sales efforts by operator. 
(C)  Optional services of a non-continuous nature, such as individual movies, sports events, educational programs, etc., may have variable rates and are exempt from filing requirements. 
(D)  No operator shall charge subscriber's rates in excess of the filed rates for any service requiring filing rates. 
(E)  A current, up-to-date copy of all the operator's rates, rules, regulations and policies having to do with subscriber service will be kept in its public file in the city. No rule, regulation or policy shall be contrary to provisions of the ordinance. 
§ 777.07 - SPECIAL PROVISIONS. 
Taking into account certain additional services which, to be successful, necessarily would have to cross corporate lines of many Greater Columbus municipalities, and considering these services to be in the public interest, and not wanting to curtail their development, the following services are specifically exempted from licensing requirements and excluded from fee payments to the city, so long as said services are offered by an operator holding a permit under ordinance. 
(A)  Services created primarily for area hotels and motels, and utilized as a promotional-informational vehicle for Greater Columbus, reaching only guests in participating hotels and motels. 
(B)  Services created for special and/or occasional closed-circuit presentations, not for the viewing and/or listening of the general public. 
(1)  This particular exclusion/exemption is not applicable to any regular, continuing service or services which the operator may offer. 
(C)  The exemptions and exclusions detailed herein shall apply to both originations by the operator and to signals merely re-transmitted and/or distributed by the operator. 
§ 777.08 - PERMITS TO OPERATE CABLE SYSTEMS IN THE CITY. 
(A)  No operator shall offer service to subscribers by means of a cable system within the city unless he holds a permit granted by ordinance of council, and authorizing such a system within the city, and in, under and over the streets, highways and other public grounds of the city. 
(B)  All permits granted by ordinance pursuant to this section shall be non-exclusive and non-assignable without the prior consent of the city; and council reserves the right to issue as many such permits as it deems advisable in the public interest. 
(C)  The permit shall take effect and will be in force from and after the earliest period allowed by law, and upon the filing by the operator with the city manager of its acceptance, in writing, of each and all of the terms and provisions of this ordinance; provided, however, if the operator shall refuse to file such written acceptance within thirty (30) days after passage of the ordinance by council, then the ordinance granting its permit shall be null and void. Nothing in this section shall preclude operator from commencing construction of its cable system during such thirty-day period at its own risk. 
(D)  If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of C.O. ch. 777 is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, or in conflict with rules and regulations of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), then such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision of this ordinance, and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(E)  Any permit granted pursuant to this ordinance may be revoked by a simple majority vote of the council upon the recommendation of the city manager, for violation of material provisions of said ordinance, by giving the operator ninety (90) days notice in writing of intention to revoke such permit unless such violation is corrected during the period of notice. In the event a violation of a material provision of this ordinance cannot be reasonably cured within ninety (90) days, then operator may request an extension of the time to cure and the city manager shall not unreasonably withhold consent to such an extension. The operator shall have an opportunity for a public hearing prior to any vote to revoke the permit. 
(F)  The term of each permit shall be ten (10) years, except that the granting of an initial permit may be for a longer period. 
§ 777.09 - CONDITION OF SERVICE. 
(A)  All service(s), offered by the operator, shall be made available to all applicants whose residences are contiguous to a main or lateral cable or within range of radiowaves, if radiowaves are utilized for transmission and distribution. All service, offered by the operator may be made available, subject to operator's reasonable business judgment, to all applicants whose establishments are contiguous to a main or lateral cable, or within range of radiowaves, if radiowaves are used for transmission and distribution. 
(B)  Service to multiple-unit buildings (including apartment houses and office buildings) will be subject to the permission of the owner or manager of each building. 
(C)  Except for bona fide promotional programs, the operator shall not discriminate within groups of similar subscribers relative to rates, charges, service, service facilities, repairs, maintenance, rules or regulations. 
§ 777.10 - PERMIT FEES AND PAYMENT THEREOF. 
(A)  The operator for the privilege of holding a permit to operate a cable system in the City of Upper Arlington entitling operator to install its distribution and transmission facilities in, under and over the streets, highways and other public grounds of the city, subject to the overall provisions of this ordinance, which have been conceived for the protection of the city and its citizens, shall make payments to the city as follows: 
(1)  Each year the operator shall pay to the city five percent (5%) of the gross revenue of the cable system, except that the permit may allow a lower payment, if the five percent (5%) of gross revenue payment would create a disparate payment rate between similarly situated operators. 
(B)  All payments to the city under this ordinance shall be made semi-annually with the operator having the option to use a calendar or fiscal year as the operating year. The operator shall not change the accounting period initially selected unless the change is first approved in writing by the finance director. 
(1)  The mid-year payment of the franchise fee may be on the basis of unaudited total gross revenue information and shall be due and payable within forty-five (45) days of the end of the sixth month of the operating year. 
(2)  The year-end payment of the franchise fee shall be due and payable within ninety (90) days after the close of the operator's operating year. At the time of this payment, operator shall submit to the finance director complete revenue information in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and that as a whole fairly and accurately presents the revenues of the operator for the year. The revenue information shall be attested to by the system manager of the operator. The city manager may require the operator to submit revenue information in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles audited and certified by an independent certified accountant in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards, and that as a whole fairly and accurately presents the revenues of the operator for the year. The calculation of the franchise fee shall be clearly shown as part of this certified statement in a form approved by the city manager. 
(C)  All payments to the city shall be by check, made payable to the City of Upper Arlington, and either hand-delivered or sent by mail to the finance director. 
(D)  City council, the city manager, or their authorized representative, shall have the right to reasonable inspection of the books and records, financial or otherwise, maps, plans, and other similar materials of the operator at a time and place convenient to the city's representatives. Further, the operator shall provide upon request of the city manager a written report documenting the number of subscribers (but not the subscribers' identities) and the types of services provided to subscribers as specified by the manager. To the extent allowable by law, information designated proprietary by operator shall be treated as such and be held confidential and shall not be considered public records. Such report shall be submitted no later than the fifteenth (15th) day of the following month. With respect to any inspection conducted by the city pursuant to this subsection, the city shall be responsible for its own expenses. 
(1)  These payments shall be known as the annual franchise fee and shall be credited to the general fund, City of Upper Arlington. 
(2)  The operator shall pay a minimum fee of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) annually for the period of its permit. 
(a)  The minimum fee shall be credited to the required franchise fee payable annually to the city. 
§ 777.11 - BASIS OF SERVICE. 
The service to be offered by the operator shall be on a solely voluntary basis on the part of the subscriber, who, if his residence or commercial establishment is contiguous to main or lateral cables or within range of radiowaves if radiowaves are utilized for transmission and distribution, may subscribe to the aforementioned service at will. Under no circumstances will the operator require a subscriber to pay for service longer than the service is desired. 
§ 777.12 - DELAYS. 
Provisions of this section notwithstanding, delays in the performance of the operator's obligations under the ordinance which are caused by equipment shortages, a state of war or national emergency, acts of God, or any circumstances beyond the control of the operator, as determined by the council, shall not be construed to be in violation of the requirements set forth herein, and reasonable extensions of time shall be granted therefor. 
§ 777.13 - SCOPE OF ORDINANCE. 
(A)  This is an enabling ordinance authorizing the operation of cable system(s) in the City of Upper Arlington, but it does not take the place of any franchise, license or permit which may be additionally required by law of the operator, either currently or at some later date; provided, however, that during the term of any franchise granted pursuant to this chapter, the city shall not unreasonably deny operator any such franchise, license or permit. 
(B)  It shall be the responsibility of the operator to obtain any and all such franchises, licenses or permits necessary to the operation and conduct of its business activities. 
(C)  Failure of the operator to obtain and conform to the provisions of any and all such franchises, licenses or permits, and to make prescribed payments if required as a condition of their issuance, shall be considered in violation of this ordinance, and subject to the penalties set forth in C.O. §§ 777.08(E) and 777.99. 
§ 777.14 - RECOVERY OF FRANCHISE COSTS. 
Operator, within sixty (60) days after receipt from the city of the permit issued pursuant to this ordinance, shall reimburse the city for reasonable costs and out of pocket expenses incurred by the city in connection with the granting of the franchise permit. The amount of said costs and expenses shall be set forth in the franchise permit. 
§ 777.15 - PRIVACY. 
The operator shall strictly observe the privacy and property rights of subscribers in accordance with applicable law. The subscribers' rights of privacy shall be protected at all times by the operator. Individual subscriber preferences, viewing habits, beliefs, philosophy, creeds, religions or political beliefs shall not be revealed to any person, firm, agency, governmental unit, police department or investigating agency unless upon the authority of a court of law or upon prior voluntary valid written authorization of the subscriber, which shall not in any event be required as a condition of receiving service. 
(A)  A subscriber may at any time revoke any authorization previously made, by delivering to the operator in writing a substantial indication of his intent to so revoke. Any such revocation shall be effective on receipt by the operator. 
(B)  The operator shall not, without the specific authorization of the subscriber(s) involved, sell, or otherwise make available to any person or group of persons lists of the names and addresses of its subscribers, which identifies the viewing habits of any individual subscriber, except as the same is necessary for the construction, marketing and maintenance of the operator's facilities and services hereunder and the concomitant billing of subscribers for said services, or as the same may be necessary to give leased access channel users sufficient and pertinent information to make full use of said leased access channel. 
(C)  Neither the operator, nor the city, nor the council shall tap and/or monitor or arrange for the tapping and/or monitoring or permit, either expressly or impliedly, any other person to tap and/or monitor any cable, line, signal input device, or subscriber outlet or receiver for any purpose whatsoever, without the express permission of the subscriber. Notwithstanding the preceding sentences, the operator shall be entitled to conduct systemwide or individually addressed sweeps for the purpose of verifying system integrity, controlling return-path transmission, or billing for pay services. 
(D)  Liability for obscenity, defamation, or invasion of privacy on any access channels shall rest with the person or group of persons utilizing said access channels. 
(E)  The operator shall make available to subscribers a device by which the subscriber can prohibit viewing of a particular cable service during periods selected by that subscriber. 
§ 777.16 - VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER. 
(A)  Definition. For purposes of this section, "video service" and "video service provider" shall have the same meanings as in ORC § 1332.21. 
(B)  Video service provider fee. 
(1)  All video service providers shall use a percentage of five percent (5%) in calculating the video service provider fee pursuant to ORC § 1332.32. 
(2)  All video service providers shall include advertising revenue in computing gross revenue pursuant to ORC § 1332.32. 
(3)  All video service providers offering video service in the City of Upper Arlington shall pay the video service provider fee calculated in accordance with this section and ORC § 1332.32 to the City of Upper Arlington. 
§ 777.99 - PENALTY. 
(A)  In addition to the provisions of C.O. § 777.08(E) having to do with revocation of permits, this penalty shall apply: 
Whoever violates any provision of C.O. ch. 777 of the City of Upper Arlington after being given notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure the violation, may be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense of each successive day continued. 
The operator recognizes the right of the city to provide, by ordinance, for a civil penalty which may be assessed against it in an amount not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) per day and/or abatement or rebate of subscriber fees to affected subscribers for each violation. Such penalties may be assessed for: 
(1)  Failure to provide data and reports as required by this ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to provide services required under this ordinance which failure affects the system as a whole or a substantial segment of subscribers. 
(3)  Failure to comply with the terms of the ordinance. 
(4)  Persistent or repeated failure to provide services to or make timely repairs or to correct billing errors for individual subscribers. 
(5)  Prior to the imposition of any penalty authorized by this section, the operator shall be given written notice setting forth the specific violation or violations and a reasonable period of time to cure the specified violation or violations. 
CHAPTER 779. - PRIVATE HAULERS OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE 

§ 779.01 - PERMIT REQUIRED. 
No person shall engage in the collection, transportation or disposal of garbage, refuse or materials intended for municipally sponsored recycling programs in this city unless they or their employer are the holder of a permit issued in accordance with the provisions of Regulation 711 of the Franklin County Board of Health. 
§ 779.02 - VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS. 
(A)  Vehicles to be operated for the collection and transportation of solid wastes within the City of Upper Arlington shall have either packer type bodies or dump truck bodies fitted with tight covers to prevent the escape of any portion of the load being transported, and must be operated and maintained so that the contents will not spill or leak from said vehicle. No pushcart propelled by manpower shall be used for the collection or disposal of garbage or refuse. 
§ 779.03 - ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS. 
The city manager is authorized to promulgate reasonable regulations for the administration of this ordinance. 
§ 779.04 - DISPOSAL OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE. 
Garbage and refuse shall be disposed of only at a site and in the manner authorized by the governmental agency having jurisdiction thereof. 
§ 779.05 - IDENTIFICATION OF VEHICLE. 
It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle for the collection, transportation or disposal of garbage, refuse or materials intended for municipally sponsored recycling programs within the City of Upper Arlington, unless such vehicle is displaying the current Franklin County Board of Health Refuse Hauler Permit sticker prominently exhibited on the driver's door pillar or as reasonably close to this location as possible. Failure to display the permit sticker as indicated shall constitute an unlicensed vehicle subject to the penalties set forth in C.O. § 779.99. 
§ 779.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a minor misdemeanor for the first offense. The second conviction or bond forfeiture for the same violation within a thirty-six-month period shall be deemed a fourth degree misdemeanor. 
CHAPTER 780. - EXPLOSIVES 

§ 780.01 - RECORDS OF EXPLOSIVES. 
(A)  Every person, corporation or partnership engaged in any occupation involving the storage or sale of any explosive, as defined in ORC § 3743.01, except those explosives used solely in signaling devices which have been designated as such by the state fire marshal, shall maintain and keep a record of the following information: 
(1)  Amounts and types of such explosives on hand at the effective date of this chapter, and at least annually thereafter. 
(2)  Purchases and receipts of such explosives. 
(3)  Amounts and types of such explosives used and the uses made of the same. 
(4)  Amounts and types of such explosives otherwise disposed of, to whom delivered, and for what purpose. 
(5)  The name, address and age of each person by whom such explosives were delivered, and the signature of each person to whom such explosives were delivered. 
(B)  The record provided for in C.O. § 780.01(A) shall be preserved for a period of three (3) years and shall be available at all times to all law enforcement officials. 
§ 780.02 - REPORTS TO POLICE. 
Every person, corporation or partnership who keeps or stores explosives shall make an immediate report to the police division of this city of explosives which have been stolen or which are otherwise missing, and of the circumstances under which the same disappeared. 
§ 780.03 - SALES LIMITED TO PERMIT HOLDERS. 
No person, corporation or partnership engaged in any occupation involving the sale of explosives as defined in ORC § 3743.01 shall sell or otherwise dispose of explosives to any person unless that person exhibits a valid permit as provided for by C.O. § 780.04 hereof. In addition to the information required by C.O. § 780.01, the seller of explosives shall keep a record of the permit number and the name of the law enforcement office who issued such permit. 
§ 780.04 - PERMITS TO USE EXPLOSIVES, FEES. 
(A)  No person shall purchase, keep or use explosives for any illegal purpose, or otherwise than in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  Any person who proposes to purchase, keep or use explosives shall first secure a user's permit from the chief of the division of police of this city (hereinafter referred to as the police chief). The application for the permit shall state the name, address and age of the applicant and the location and purposes of the explosive's use, and shall be accompanied by an affidavit as provided by C.O. § 780.04(D). The police chief may issue either temporary or annual permits, each of which shall bear his name and title and a permit identification number. Temporary permits shall expire ten (10) days after the date of issue. Annual permits shall only be issued to persons whose business necessitates the frequent or repeated use of explosives. Annual permits shall expire one (1) year from their date of issue and may be renewed upon payment of the prescribed fee, resubmission of the affidavit prescribed by C.O. § 780.04(D), and a further investigation by the police chief verifying that the applicant still qualifies as a permit holder. 
(C)  The fee for a temporary permit shall be five dollars ($5.00). The fee for an annual permit shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). All moneys collected shall be deposited to the credit of the general fund of the city. 
(D)  Each applicant for a permit to buy, keep or use explosives shall file with his application his signed affidavit certifying that he is not a fugitive from justice, that he is not under indictment for any felony of violence involving moral turpitude, that he has never been convicted of such a felony, that he is not addicted to or illegally using any narcotic drug, barbiturate, amphetamine, hallucinogen or other dangerous drug, and that he is not an habitual drunkard or other adjudication of mental incompetence. 
(E)  The police chief shall conduct an investigation to verify the truth of the facts alleged in the affidavit provided for in C.O. § 780.04(D). If, upon investigation, he is satisfied that the applicant is qualified, he shall issue the permit. 
(F)  No person shall obtain or attempt to obtain a permit by falsification or misrepresentation of any of the facts in his application or affidavit. 
(G)  No person shall give a permit issued to him to another for use and no person shall use a permit issued to another. 
(H)  No permit shall be issued to a corporation or partnership. Provided, however, that an officer or bona fide regular employee of a corporation, or a member of a partnership, who holds such a permit, may purchase explosives thereunder for the corporation by whom he is employed or the partnership of which he is a member. 
§ 780.05 - NON-COMPLIANCE WITH THIS CHAPTER. 
No person who is not engaged in the business of dealing in or keeping explosives, operating in compliance with all provisions of law relating to such business, shall buy, sell or deal in explosives. No person other than such dealer or keeper of explosives shall, after the effective date of the provisions of this chapter, acquire or possess explosives, except as permitted by this chapter. Possession of such explosives after said effective date shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this prohibition. 
§ 780.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or both. 
CHAPTER 781. - OIL AND GAS WELLS 

§ 781.01 - OIL AND GAS WELL PROHIBITED. 
The drilling of wells for oil or gas and other activities incident to the production of oil and gas within this city are hereby prohibited. 
§ 781.99 - PENALTY. 
Whoever violates the provisions of C.O. § 781.01 shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
CHAPTER 783. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

§ 783.01 - DEFINITIONS. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm permit: means a permit issued by the chief of police or fire chief to any owner or other person in control of a building, property or part thereof, located in the city, to install and maintain an alarm system. 
    Alarm permit holder: means a person, organization, company or any other entity in control of a building, structure or facility, or any portion thereof, which is intended to be protected by an alarm system and has a permit issued to him by the chief of police or fire chief. 
    Alarm system: means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to signal audibly, visibly or electronically, to a location outside the structures protected by the system or to a monitoring station which in turn notifies the appropriate agency, the presence of fire, smoke, robbery, burglary, vandalism, intrusion or other activity requiring urgent attention to which the police division or the fire division is expected to respond, including interconnected alarm systems, as defined below, but shall not include alarms installed in motor vehicles. 
    Alarm system (interconnected): means an alarm system which directly or indirectly, automatically or manually, uses a telephone line, cable line and/or radio and microwave transmission, to transmit an alarm or message upon activation of the alarm system. 
    Alarm system (local): means an alarm system that when activated only sounds a horn, bell, buzzer, or other type of audible or visible alarm that is designed to be audible or visible beyond the premises being served, but which does not result in the transmission of a signal to any other location. 
    Appropriate chief: means the Upper Arlington Chief of Police or the Upper Arlington Fire Chief. 
    Automatic dialing device: means a device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and transmit by voice, message, or code signal an emergency message indicating a need for emergency response. 
    False alarm: means an alarm signal or message eliciting an urgent response by the police division or fire division when a situation requiring such response by the police or fire does not, in fact, exist. 
The following conditions shall not be considered a false alarm: 
(A)  An alarm which has been activated as a result of testing or repair shall not be considered a false alarm, if prior notification has been given the day of such repairs or test to the agency which the alarm would signal. 
(B)  Adverse weather or telephone or power outages or other catastrophic acts of God not reasonably subject to control by the alarm manufacturer, installer or alarm permit holder which cause an alarm signal are not considered false alarms. 
(C)  An alarm which has been activated shall not be considered as a false alarm, if the responding public safety division receives a request to cancel. Such request must be made to the same location as the request for service and must be received prior to the arrival of any units or equipment. 
§ 783.02 - ALARM PERMITS. 
(A)  Any residence or building or part thereof located within the City of Upper Arlington may be equipped with an alarm system for the purpose of detecting and signaling the presence of a fire or unauthorized intrusion. A permit for the installation of an alarm system may be required by the local Building and Fire Codes, for buildings other than single family residences. It shall be the responsibility of the owner and installer to secure said permits from the city's community development department. 
(B)  Applications for alarm user permits shall be made on forms provided by the chief of police. The application shall include the name, address and telephone number of the applicant and the name, address and telephone number of the property (including business phone number) and central station phone number of the applicant's alarm company, if any. 
The application shall also include notice that a permit holder who has been charged with a false alarm may appeal that finding pursuant to the appeals procedure set forth in C.O. § 783.08. 
Each application for an alarm user permit for an alarm system which pertains to a residence shall provide at least two (2) other names and telephone numbers of persons to contact in case of an emergency when the user is unavailable. Each application for an alarm user permit for an alarm system which pertains to a building, structure or facility other than a residence shall provide at least three (3) such names, unless such facility employs less than three (3) persons. An alarm monitoring company name may be substituted for one (1) of the required names, if a contractual arrangement exists between the user and the monitoring company. 
If an alarm user has more than one (1) alarm system protecting two (2) or more separate structures having different addresses, a separate permit shall be required for each system at each address. 
(C)  A one-time alarm permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) will be charged for a permit issued under the provisions of this ordinance. 
Permits are issued to a Resident or business for a specific location. Should the Resident or business move from the address indicated on the original permit, the alarm permit shall be void. 
(D)  No person shall install, operate or allow on the premises under his control the operation of an alarm system unless such person first obtains a valid alarm permit. This requirement shall be the responsibility of the owner unless the occupant of the property is different from the owner, in which case it shall be the responsibility of both. 
(E)  Each holder of an alarm user permit shall, within ten (10) days of any change of the information on the alarm user permit application, notify the chief of police in writing of any and all changes in the information on the application. 
(F)  Each application for an alarm permit shall contain an agreement to submit to the assessment of a service charge for false alarms. Failure to agree to this provision shall be cause to deny issuance of an alarm user permit, or if one (1) has been issued, shall be cause to revoke any such alarm user permit. 
(G)  The information contained in an alarm user permit application shall be securely maintained and restricted to inspection only by the chief of police, fire chief and their designated representatives. 
(H)  Any system installed shall be installed in accordance with local building and fire codes, as well as applicable standards. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 783.03 - AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICES. 
(A)  The city may subscribe to one (1) or more telephone lines for burglar alarms, or for fire alarm purposes, or for similar purposes; and when any line is designated as provided for above, persons may, upon proper application and compliance with applicable laws, be granted a permit to install a device or devices which automatically select the designated telephone line for the purpose of playing a recorded message or to otherwise report an intrusion or other emergency. The permit fee shall be established by the city manager, in such amount as to reimburse the city for the cost of any telephone lines dedicated to automatic dialing devices. Such fee shall be revised at the beginning of every fiscal year to reflect the most recent cost experience. 
(B)  No person shall use or cause to be used, any telephone device or telephone attachment that automatically selects any telephone line allocated by the telephone company to the city or any of its departments or divisions, except a telephone line which shall be specifically designated by the city manager for such purpose. Such designated telephone line or lines shall terminate at the Municipal Services Center Communications Center located at 3600 Tremont Road. 
(C)  All automatic dialing devices shall be reprogrammed to use the designated telephone line within ten (10) days of notification of designation by the city manager; additionally, the message format must be approved by the appropriate chief prior to interconnection. 
§ 783.04 - EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE AND INSPECTION OF ALARM SYSTEMS.
