(4)  Banners: Banner systems attached to light standards in parking lots and along public and private streets are encouraged, provided they meet all code requirements. 
§ 7.14 - LANDSCAPING. 
(A)  Purpose and intent: Landscaping shall be used to complement structures, buildings and spaces. Softening hard surfaces is important in areas adjacent to residential neighborhoods. See also Section 7.15, buffering and screening. 
(1)  Mixture of material: The design of planted areas shall provide for a mixture of material based on height, colors, textures, and other factors to create inviting and aesthetically pleasing views. The style of the plantings shall compliment the architectural style of adjacent and nearby buildings. 
(2)  Scale: Landscaping shall be in scale with adjacent structures and be of appropriate size at maturity to accomplish its intended purpose. Street trees shall not block storefronts and therefore could be located between awnings or at fire/common walls. 
(3)  Structure bases: Landscaping around the base of structures shall soften the edge of buildings where appropriate. Landscaping shall be accented at entrances to provide focus for the pedestrian. Where the foundation abuts a sidewalk or outdoor dining area, clusters of complimentary planters shall be used. 

(4)  Setbacks: The building and parking setback along a public street shall be landscaped per code. 
(5)  Off-street parking lots: Trees shall be located throughout off-street parking lots, in between parking rows, and not simply at the end of parking rows. Such trees shall be located in planters and bounded on at least three (3) sides by parking area paving. 
(6)  Native plant material: Wherever feasible, native plant material shall be used to reduce long-term maintenance demands and to ensure survivability. 
(7)  Irrigation: In locations that are stressful to plant material, drip irrigation shall be considered to ensure survivability. 
§ 7.15 - BUFFERING AND SCREENING. 
(A)  Purpose and intent: Incompatible uses shall be sufficiently buffered and screened to ensure that adverse land use impacts should be mitigated. In the design of a screen or buffer, setbacks shall be taken into account to ensure an appropriate design solution. Where walls are used as screening, they shall be designed to blend with the parcel's architecture. See also Section 7.14, landscaping. 
(1)  Trash dumpsters and donation bins/receptacles: When located adjacent to buildings, but no further away than fifteen (15) feet, trash dumpsters and donation bins/receptacles shall be screened with masonry walls that match the building. When located away from buildings further than fifteen (15) feet, trash dumpsters and donation bins/receptacles shall be screened in accordance with Section 6.07(H), with consideration given for masonry walls or other treatment that compliments the principal structure and with an entrance gate, but also screened with evergreen plant material on any side that faces a public right-of-way or residential use or zoning district. Screening shall exceed the height of the dumpster or donation bin/receptacle by one (1) foot and be no higher than six (6) feet. 

(2)  Loading docks: Loading docks shall be located adjacent to a building and screened with a masonry wing wall that matches the building. 
(3)  Roof-, side- and ground-mounted mechanicals: All outdoor equipment and mechanicals shall be screened from view. Screening of roof-mounted mechanicals shall be architecturally integrated with the adjacent structure in terms of materials, color, shape, and size. Ground-mounted mechanicals shall be screened with evergreen plant material. 
(4)  Residential refuse containers: All solid waste, recycling and yard waste containers shall either be stored inside a garage or accessory structure or be stored outside. Containers stored outside shall be located to the side or rear of the residence and be reasonably screened so as to not be visible from the street. The containers shall be screened by either a natural landscape barrier with a minimum 50 percent opacity or a fence with a minimum height of 42 inches. 
(Ord. No. 16-2017 , § 10, 4-10-2017; Ord. No. 54-2017 , § 23, 12-11-2017) 
§ 7.16 - MIXING USES. 
(A)  Purpose and intent: Uses shall be mixed within developments and/or within individual buildings to provide for a mixed-use environment. Typical uses include retail and personal services, offices, and residences. The goal is to create exciting, active and vital areas of the community where people can live, work, and shop within a quality, walkable environment. 
(1)  Horizontal integration: Uses shall be mixed horizontally through a development. This occurs by providing for buildings that have individual focuses (i.e. retail or housing), but that are adjacent within the same development. 
(2)  Vertical integration: Uses should be mixed vertically in a single building. This can occur by providing for retail uses on the first level, office or residential uses on the second level, and residential uses on third and higher levels. 
§ 7.17 - RESIDENTIAL DESIGN STANDARDS. 
(A)  Purpose and intent: The purpose of these standards is to encourage residential investment and infill redevelopment to maintain and expand the property values in Upper Arlington, while also protecting the character of the residential neighborhoods by ensuring that new development blends in and is compatible with existing and prominent neighborhood characteristics. These standards are in addition to all other standards and requirements of the Unified Development Ordinance. 
(B)  Applicability: The following standards apply to the design of new single-family homes, major additions that exceed fifty percent (50%) of the total existing square footage, second story additions, additions over 1,000 square feet, detached garages over four hundred (400) square feet in area, any proposed modification of a Contributing Structure whereby its historical significance is materially compromised, and newly created or modified parcels. 
(1)  Neighborhood compatibility: The proposed design shall be consistent and compatible with prominent characteristics existing in the neighborhood, with particular consideration and focus on the characteristics existing on the same block (both sides of the street within two intersecting streets) or cul-de-sac as the subject property. Such characteristics include: parcel or homesite width and configuration, architectural style and materials, heights and massing, front yard setbacks, roof pitch and shape, garage location, amount of impervious surface, and other defining features of the neighborhood and with an emphasis on the block. Review for compatibility shall be based on all characteristics. 

(2)  Elevations and floor plans: Houses with identical or similar building elevations and/or floor plans shall not be located on adjacent lots or directly across the street from each other. Hip roof forms, or similar roof forms or designs, and/or varied upper floor setbacks should be used to break-up overall massing, where appropriate. Where existing adjacent homes have lower massing profiles, roof forms and designs with lower profiles should be employed, and should be set back from existing wall planes. The height of new homes and proposed additions should be compatible with the other homes in the neighborhood, with particular consideration and focus on homes on the same block and with the totality of the other applicable design standards required under the Unified Development Ordinance. Number of stories, size of the lot, and proposed distance from neighboring homes may be considered in determining compatibility. 
(3)  Façade articulation: Building façades shall be articulated through the use of color, arrangement, or change in materials to emphasize the façade elements. The planes of the exterior walls may be varied in height, depth or direction. Design elements and detailing shall be continued completely around the structure; blank elevations are prohibited. Such design elements shall include window treatments, trim detailing, and exterior wall materials. 
(4)  Privacy: The location of the house on the lot, windows, orientation, building height, and location of on-site open spaces must be designed in such a manner as to preserve the privacy of existing adjacent homes and development. Second floor balconies proposed adjacent to an existing one-story single-family home shall be set back at least double the minimum side yard setback. 
(5)  Snout houses: The front elevation of new homes shall not be dominated by attached garages. Where possible the garages of new homes shall be side- or rear-loaded. 
(6)  Notification: The property owner shall provide written notice of the pending construction of a new single-family residence to all property owners within 100 feet of the subject property. Such notice shall be hand-delivered or sent by postal mail prior to the submittal of a Building Permit application. Proof of notification shall accompany the Building Permit application. 
(7)  The Director of Community Development (or designee) may request additional information in order to determine compliance with these standards, including but not limited to: Streetscape renderings with adjacent homes, field specific measurements or material samples. 
(8)  Third-party Architectural Review: Upon the submission of a Building Permit application, the Director of Community Development (or designee) may forward a copy of the proposed site plan and elevations to a third-party architectural design firm, to be assigned by the City Manager, for review. The third-party architectural design firm shall review the proposed plans and provide the Director of Community Development a recommendation as to compliance with these standards, which may include recommended changes to the plans so that compliance can be achieved. Such recommendations are not binding, but may be considered by the Director of Community Development in determining compliance with these standards. 
Any individual entitled to notice pursuant to subsection (B)(6), and any individual who submits a Building Permit application, may request that the Director of Community Development refer such proposal to the third-party architectural design firm for review and recommendations as to compliance with these standards. The Director of Community Development shall determine if such third-party architectural review is necessary. 
(9)  Director of Community Development Determination: Upon review of all materials submitted, including any additional information provided pursuant to subsection (B)(7), and including any recommendations (if any) from the third-party architectural design firm, as described in subsection (B)(8), the Director of Community Development shall determine compliance with these standards. 
(10)  Appeal to BZAP: If the Director of Community Development (or designee) determines that these standards are not met by the Building Permit application (or by preliminary review), the applicant may appeal such determination to the Board of Zoning and Planning (BZAP). If an appeal is filed, the applicant shall notify all property owners within 100 feet of the subject property of the time and place of the hearing at least 10 days prior to the hearing. The notice provided under this section is for informational purposes only. Receipt of the required notice under this section does not make the recipient an Aggrieved party and does not confer any right to participate in the appeal to BZAP or to appeal any decision of BZAP on such appeal. Only persons meeting the definition of "Aggrieved" in UDO Section 2.02 shall be considered Aggrieved. 
(11)  Street Trees: For all new homes, street trees shall be installed per Article 6.07, which requires one street tree to be planted (or retained) for each 25 feet of lot frontage. All existing on-site healthy trees shall be preserved to the fullest extent reasonable, unless directed otherwise by the City Forester. 
(Ord. No. 8-2012; Ord. No. 57-2013; Ord. No. 54-2017 , § 24, 12-11-2017; Ord. No. 10-2019 , § 2, 4-22-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 54-2017 , § 24, adopted Dec. 11, 2017, amended the title of § 7.17 to read as set out herein. The former § 7-17 title pertained to residential conservation. 
§ 7.18 - HISTORIC BUILDINGS AND DISTRICTS. 
(A)  Design requirements: Alterations to contributing structures that require a building permit and new construction that replaces such structures or any other new construction in the Upper Arlington Historic District should be consistent with the design criteria as described below as well as the adopted guidelines approved by the Board and City Council: 
(1)  Maintain distinctive original features and styles: Alterations to Contributing structures that require a building permit and new construction that replaces such structures or any other new construction in the Upper Arlington Historic District should maintain the original features and styles, allowing the distinctive character of the house to serve as an example of or be compatible with early twentieth century revival architecture in the historic district. These features include: details, columns, arched openings, windows, brick designs, porches, roof types, materials and design. These Revival styles include but are not limited to: American Colonial, English Country, English Tudor, Spanish, Italian, and French. 
(2)  Recognize historical architecture: Insensitive alterations and changes to the architecture and to the environment can destroy the special characteristics of the historic district. The window proportions and materials such as siding, doors and shutters help to establish the identity of the revival-style architecture. Replacement of these details with more contemporary features should be avoided. 
(3)  Recognize change: National Register designation does not mean a building or district should be frozen in time, but rather that any change should harmonize with the old and should respect the historic fabric of the district. When attempting to restore a house to a particular style, no attempt should be made to create a building that never existed and the arbitrary removal of later features should be avoided. 
(4)  Materials used: Materials used should be consistent with the historic fabric of the area and compatible with the neighborhood. 
(5)  Compatible contemporary alterations: Alterations should not destroy the architectural or historic fabric of the building and should be compatible with the neighborhood. Landscape materials should reflect the character of the neighborhood and front yard fencing should be avoided to maintain continual visual character along the streetscape. 
(6)  Avoid impairing the underlying structure: Additions should be built so that the original character and feeling of the building would survive if the additions were removed at any time in the future. Freestanding structures should be designed to observe height proportions of the building façade and openings including solid rhythms, spacing rhythms, setbacks and directionality of adjacent buildings, porches, and other projections. Additions should be similar in character to others in the neighborhood. Saving of mature trees is encouraged. 
(B)  These guidelines shall not be required for the following activities in the historic district, but the guidelines under Section 7.17 may still apply: 
(1)  Maintenance and/or repair activities. 
(2)  Alterations to contributing structures that do not require a building permit. 
(3)  Interior work on any building or structure that does not require a building permit. 
(4)  General landscape maintenance and/or planting of new organic material. 
(5)  Work required for temporary stabilization of a building or structure due to damage from natural events or an act of God. 
Part 13 - BUILDING CODE 
CHAPTER 1300. - ADMINISTRATION 

§ 1300.01 - COMPOSITION OF THE CODE. 
The Upper Arlington Building Code, Part 13 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Upper Arlington, Ohio is composed of: 
(A)  Administrative Regulations As Expressed in Chapter 1300 of Part 13 of the city's Codified Ordinances. These regulations apply to all construction, where not less restrictive than the applicable administrative regulations contained in either the Residential Code of Ohio for One-, Two- and Three-Family Dwellings, current Edition (the Ohio Residential Code or RCO) or the State Commercial Building Code, called the Ohio Building Code (OBC) current Edition. 
(B)  One-, Two- and Three-Family Residential Construction Regulations as expressed in Residential Code of Ohio, current edition. Residential Code of Ohio, as referenced in Part 13 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Upper Arlington, Ohio, means the Residential Code of Ohio for One, Two and Three Family Dwellings, current Edition including Appendix G, Swimming Pools, Spas and Hot tubs. 
All of the requirements of the Residential Code of Ohio for One, Two and Three Family Dwellings, current Edition including Appendix G, Swimming Pools, Spas and Hot Tubs and interim amendments promulgated by the Residential Code of Ohio, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, amended or replaced by this Code in Chapter 1301, are deemed to be incorporated herein by reference and made a part hereof, as if rewritten and set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling as pertains to one-, two- and three-family dwellings and accessory buildings. 
(C)  Building Construction Regulations, Except for One-, Two- and Three-Family Residential Construction, As Expressed in the OBC. OBC or Ohio Building Code as referenced in Part 13 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Upper Arlington, Ohio, means the regulations of the Board of Building Standards of the State of Ohio. 
Buildings defined by use and occupancy classification and types of construction in the OBC Chapters 3 and 6 respectively, of the Ohio Administrative Code, shall conform to the requirements of the Ohio Building Code (OBC) adopted by the State Board of Building Standards pursuant to statutory authority. These buildings shall also conform to the construction requirements expressed in C.O. Chapter 1302 of Part 13 of the city's Codified Ordinances, where the Ohio Building Code is silent. 
The OBC is deemed to be incorporated herein by reference and made a part hereof, as if rewritten and set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling as pertains to all construction. Detached One-, Two- and Three-family dwellings not constructed of industrialized units and those other buildings noted as exceptions to Section 101.2 of the OBC, are exempted from this provision except where specifically referenced by the OBC. 
§ 1300.02 - DEFINITIONS. 
The following definitions apply to C.O. ch. 1300-Administration. They shall also apply to C.O. chs. 1301 through 1306 where no definition is provided in these chapters: 
    Apartment, efficiency: means a dwelling unit in a multi-family building consisting of not more than one (1) habitable room, together with kitchen or kitchenette and sanitary facilities. 
    Apartment hotel: means an apartment house which furnishes services for the use of its tenants which are ordinarily furnished by hotels. 
    Apartment house: means a building containing two (2) or more apartments. 
    Approved plans: means plans approved under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Building department: means the building division of the community development department of this city. 
    Building inspector: means a member or contractual agent of a building department, usually a municipality, who inspects construction to determine compliance with all applicable building codes and the approved plans. 
    C.O: means Codified Ordinance of this city. 
    Conflict with this Code: means legislation, or a rule, or a condition which is at variance with this Code to the extent or in a manner that such legislation, rule or condition permits or constitutes a provision for safety or sanitation which would be or is less safe or sanitary than is required under this Code. 
    Conforming: means complying with the requirements of this Code. 
    Contractor: means any individual, firm, co-partnership, corporation, association or other organization, or any combination of any thereof, who or which by himself or itself, or by or through others, constructs, alters, repairs, adds to, subtracts from, reconstructs or remodels any building, structure or appurtenance thereto, or who or which undertakes or offers to undertake, or purports to have the capacity to undertake, or submits a bid to do so. The term contractor includes subcontractor and also specialty contractor whose operations as such are the performance of construction work requiring special skill and whose principal contracting business involves the use of specialized building trades or crafts. 
    Contractor, without limiting the inclusion of trades or crafts, includes but is not limited to a general contractor and those engaged in carpentry, electrical, heating and/or air conditioning, dry wall, excavating and/or earth moving, insulating, lathing and/or plastering, brick or stone masonry, painting and/or decorating, plumbing and/or sewer work, sign building and/or erecting, glazing, ornamental iron work and/or awnings, paving, asphalt, concrete and cement work, grading, roofing and/or siding, tile setting, house moving, sheet metal work, welders and structural steel workers. 
    Crawl space: means any space in a building equal to five (5) feet or less in height from the surface below to the bottom of the floor joist or ceiling joist above. 
    Credentials: means the badge of office, certificate, or letter issued by a governmental department to an employee for the identification of said employee in the performance of his duties. 
    Dry well: means an underground, vertical trench or hole filled with rocks and gravel. 
    Existing: means constructed, installed, or situated, or being constructed, installed, or situated prior to the effective date of this Code or parts of this Code. 
    French drain: means an underground, horizontal trench filled with gravel which includes perforated pipes that run horizontally through the aggregate. 
    Garage door: means any door which swings, slides, tilts or folds and is utilized by an automobile for gaining entry into a garage. 
    Garage service door: means an exterior door in a garage less than eight (8) feet in width. 
    General public: as applied to those who enter, use or occupy a building, means persons other than the owner of the building, a tenant in the building, and persons who are employed in the building. 
    Plans: include drawings, specifications and data submitted to the building inspector for approval. 
    Premises: means the lot and the buildings situated therein. 
    Private: as applied to part of a building, means that such part of the building is not normally subject to common uses by those who occupy or enter the building. 
    Public (as applied to an exit way, toilet room, or other part of a building): means that such exit way, toilet room or other part of the building is subject to common use by those who occupy or enter the building, except as required for the separation of the sexes. 
    Rain barrel: means a collection device that stores rainwater collected from rooftop gutters and downspouts. 
    Rain garden: means a small, vegetated depression that is used to capture and infiltrate stormwater runoff. 
    Revised Code: means the Ohio Revised Code. 
    Street: means the area included between the right-of-way lines of a public thoroughfare fifty (50) feet or more in width which provides a public means of access to abutting property, or any such right-of-way more than thirty (30) feet and less than fifty (50) feet in width provided it existed prior to December 18, 1961. 
    Value of work: means the fair market dollar value of the completed construction project for which a permit is secured. This value is to be determined by the applicant and approved by the chief building official. 
    Vegetated swale: means a broad, shallow channel with a dense stand of vegetation covering the side slopes and bottom. Swales can be natural or manmade, and are designed to trap particulate pollutants (suspended solids and trace metals), promote infiltration, and reduce the flow velocity of stormwater runoff. Swales are best suited for residential, industrial, and commercial areas with low flow and smaller populations. 
    Wall, exterior sloping: means a wall that is attached to a building but is not a structural wall and is not finished on both sides, as opposed to a slanting roof. 
(Ord. No. 119-2009; Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 1300.03 - COOPERATION OF OTHER OFFICIALS. 
The building inspector may request and shall receive so far as may be necessary, in the discharge of his duties, the assistance and cooperation of the city engineer in fixing grades; of the chief of police in enforcing orders; of the city attorney in prosecuting violations, and of other city officials. 
§ 1300.04 - PERSONAL NON-LIABILITY. 
Any suit brought against any officer or employee of this city because of any act performed by him in the enforcement of any provision of this Code shall be defended by the city attorney of the city until the final termination of the proceedings therein. The city shall save such officer or employee harmless from personal liability. 
§ 1300.05 - PLANS, WHAT IS REQUIRED. 
(A)  Building plans. Plans are required for any work requiring a permit as defined in Section 105 of the RCO. Two (2) sets of plans shall be submitted with the contents as required in Section 106 of the RCO and consisting of the following: 
(1)  Site plan or development plan drawn to scale, and completely dimensioned, illustrating: 
(a)  North orientation. 
(b)  All property boundaries and dimensions. 
(c)  All existing improvement(s) and locations. Include all building and miscellaneous structure cover, parking cover, swimming pool cover, and miscellaneous impervious cover including but not limited to driveways, tennis courts, walks, terraces, patios, decks, etc. 
(d)  All proposed improvements and locations. Include all building and miscellaneous structure cover, parking cover, swimming pool cover, and miscellaneous impervious cover including but not limited to driveways, tennis courts, walks, terraces, patios, decks, etc. 
(e)  All right-of-way locations. 
(f)  All existing and proposed setback dimensions. 
(g)  All existing easement locations and designated uses. 
(h)  All land and improvements between street curb, or edge of pavement, and property line(s). 
(i)  For building additions whose building footprint exceeds twenty percent (20%) of the existing building footprint, a grading plan with existing and proposed contour intervals for every two (2) feet of vertical grade change when existing land contours are to be altered more than twelve (12) inches at the corners of the new foundation walls. Include all existing and proposed first floor elevations, and existing and proposed spot grades at the corners of all new foundation walls. The controlling subdivision grading plan, if one exists, shall be consulted and referenced on the grading plan. 
(j)  For new home construction, a grading plan shall be submitted. The grading plan shall show existing and proposed contour intervals for every two (2) feet of vertical grade change and surface run-off arrows. Also include all proposed first floor elevations, existing and proposed spot grades at the corners of all foundation walls, driveways and pavement areas. The approved and controlling subdivision master grading plan shall be followed. Deviations from the approved grades shall be limited to no more than eight (8) inches and must be approved by the building inspector prior to implementation of the change. Any further deviations from the master grading plan shall require re-submittal by the engineer of record for the master grading plan for review and approval by the City of Upper Arlington Engineer. Grade changes recommended by the engineer of record must be coordinated with the grades on adjacent lots and properties, respecting existing and proposed building heights. 
(k)  Construction which does not increase the building footprint area or site pavement area, which does not increase the habitable area or height of a non-conforming use or structure, and which does not permanently enclose previously unenclosed building areas, shall be exempt from the provisions of (a) through (g) above. 
(2)  Foundation and footer drawings showing the dimension of walls, footers, columns, piers, chimneys and other pertinent information at a scale of not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch equals one (1) foot. 
(3)  Floor plans of all floors showing the use or occupancy, the size and dimensions of all parts of the building together with the size and direction of all structural members, at a scale of not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch equals one (1) foot. 
(4)  Elevations of all sections of the building showing heights above and below the finished grade of the lot or parcel of all portions of the building including floor and ceiling levels, roof ridges, chimneys, porches, stoops and other appurtenances at a scale of not less than one-eighth ( 1/8 ) inch equals one (1) foot. 
(5)  Sections. A section through the building and chimney showing construction details and any other section necessary at a scale of not less than one-half (1/2) inch equals one (1) foot. 
(6)  Tables and diagrams of live loads, trusses, beams and similar items shall, where necessary, be shown. 
(7)  For porches, detached garages, carports or similar small structures, a plot plan, floor plan and front and a side elevation and a section shall be sufficient; plans and elevations need not be drawn to scale, providing dimensions are shown. 
For small additions and alterations, the requirements hereof as to elevations may be reduced to a front and side, and the scale size of all requirements need not be complied with. 
(8)  Where due to the size of the building or parcel of ground, the minimum scale requirements herein provided would make the drawings too large, the scale size may be reduced with the consent of the building inspector. 
(B)  Plumbing plans. 
(1)  Isometric diagrams of all piping and fixtures which comprise the work covered under the permit application. 
(C)  Electrical/Mechanical plans. 
(1)  Plans and diagrams as may be required by the plan reviewer to more fully explain heating, ventilation and air conditioning duct and piping layouts, and lighting and power equipment layouts. 
(D)  Site utilities plans. 
(1)  Plans and details as required to fully describe all utility work which is a part of the permit application. 
(E)  Fire suppression plans. 
(1)  Plans, riser diagrams, hydraulic calculations, and location of water meter, check valve, pressure gauge, inspector's test/drain valve, inspector's test/drain, and relation of test/drain to plumbing return system, as required to fully describe the system and its required components which are a part of the permit application. 
(F)  Additional plans. Additional plans may be required by the plans examiner as required to more fully explain the permit application request. 
TABLE 1300.05 
TYPES OF WORK NOT REQUIRING PERMITS 
Type of Permit When Work Does Not Require A Permit Swimming Pool When there is maintenance work only. Pool alteration and electrical work is specifically excluded and must receive a permit. Sign No permit exceptions. Sewer Tap No permit exceptions. Water Tap (Columbus) No permit exceptions. Fence When there is maintenance work on an existing fence. Driveway* When work is outside of the street right-of-way. Sidewalk* When repairing or replacing existing sidewalk. Fire Suppression No permit exceptions. Antenna Tower/Satellite Dish No permit exceptions. *Homeowner's affidavit may be substituted in-lieu-of licensed contractor.  
§ 1300.06 - NONCONFORMING USE-NOTICE. 
If the building on which the work to be done is a nonconforming use under article 3 § 3.05 of the Unified Development Code of the Upper Arlington Codified Ordinances, then the applicant shall give written notice of the filing of the application to the owners of all property within one hundred (100) feet of any boundary of the subject property, which notice shall indicate the general nature of the work to be done. A written acknowledgment of notice or a consent to the construction signed by any of such owners shall take the place of the prescribed notice to such owners. 
The council may, by the affirmative vote of four (4) members, dispense with the requirements of publication and written notice in cases of minor work, which will have no adverse effect upon neighboring properties. 
A permit may not be issued until fifteen (15) days after proof of notice is filed. 
In the event there are objections to the issuance of the permit, the council shall hold a hearing on the matter. 
§ 1300.07 - PLANS, REQUIRED EVIDENCE OF RESPONSIBILITY. 
Such plans shall bear the identification of the person primarily responsible for their preparation and for the provisions for safety and sanitation shown therein. 
§ 1300.08 - PLANS, FEE FOR INSPECTION. 
The fee for the inspection of plans for which a permit is required under this Code shall be paid in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02 for each category listed below which applies to the permit requested. 
(A)  New buildings or structures: 
(1)  Basis of computation of area: Areas shall be based on floor surface excluding garage, carport, basement, crawl space and attic, measuring the outside dimensions at each floor level. 
(2)  Only the work shown on the approved plans shall be included in the permit. 
(B)  Detached garages, carports or other accessory buildings. The fee for commercial garages shall be computed in accordance with paragraph (A) hereof. 
(C)  Additions, alterations and repairs to existing buildings. 
(D)  Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is started or proceeded with, prior to obtaining a permit or approval from the building department the fees as calculated for said permit shall be doubled, but payment of such doubled fee shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the execution of the work or from any other penalties prescribed herein. 
§ 1300.09 - REINSPECTION FEES. 
In the event a reinspection is required, the building inspector shall assess a reinspection fee for each additional inspection trip when: 
(1)  The correction work is not completely corrected; or 
(2)  The address given is inaccurate or inaccessible. 
The reinspection fee required under the conditions itemized above shall be paid in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02 for each trip required to achieve code compliance. This reinspection fee shall be paid and a receipt posted on the job site before further building inspections are performed. When a contractor and/or owner owes reinspection fees at the time of application for another building permit, this permit shall be withheld until said fees have been paid. 
§ 1300.10 - PLANS, FEE FOR EXAMINATION. 
Plan examination fees for building code review described below shall be assessed according to the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. The city shall retain thirty-five percent (35%) of the commercial building permit application fee specified in C.O. § 401.02 to supplement the administrative time required for processing. 
Residential work for which a building permit is required by Code. 
Commercial work for which a building permit is required by Code. 
Commercial plans examined by a consultant under contract with the city shall comply with fees as noted in C.O. § 1300.11. 
§ 1300.11 - PLANS, FEE FOR CONTRACT EXAMINATION. 
Any application and plans examined by a plans examiner under contract with the city shall have all costs incurred during the plan review process made part of the overall permit fee. All fees shall be paid in full, prior to the issuance of a permit. Any fees incurred after such permit is issued shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building certificate of occupancy. 
Should any fees remain outstanding and occupancy occurs, the owner or contractor shall be deemed in violation of this Code and subject to the penal provisions thereof. 
§ 1300.12 - PLANS, APPROVAL OF. 
(A)  Upon request of the owner or applicant, the chief building official shall stamp or endorse additional sets of plans, which have been submitted to and approved by him/her. For each additional set of plans so stamped or endorsed, a fee in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02 shall be paid. 
(B)  All applications and plans shall be dated by the chief building official or his/her designee upon their receipt and shall be taken up in their regular order and no such plans shall be passed out of their order unless they are of a complex character, which require prolonged examination. 
(C)  Exception. If the chief building official finds that the plans are of a complex character which require prolonged examination, he/she may allow work to proceed prior to issuance of the permit for the construction of the foundation for a commercial building or a commercial structure but only to a height to receive the first tier of beams, girders or joists. 
(D)  Validity. The issuance of a permit or approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed as an approval of any violation of any of the provisions of this Code. The issuance of a permit based upon plans and specifications shall not prevent the building official from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in such plans and specifications or from preventing building operations being carried on there under when in violation of any ordinance of the city. 
§ 1300.13 - EXPIRATION. 
Building permits, if not paid for within sixty (60) days from the time of application, shall be voided and the plans destroyed. 
§ 1300.14 - PLANS, CONFORMITY TO. 
The construction, erection and alteration of a building and any addition thereto, and the equipment and maintenance thereof shall conform to the approved plans, except for minor deviations which do not involve a violation of this Code. 
§ 1300.15 - PERMIT, FORM OF. 
The form of the permit shall be prescribed by the chief building official and shall show the serial number of the permit, the address of the building or equipment under consideration, the name and address of the owner, the name of the person who issued the permit, and such other information as is necessary to facilitate the proper enforcement of this Code. 
§ 1300.16 - PERMIT POSTING. 
The permit shall be placed in a conspicuous location outside of the building and in the front part of the premises on which is, or will be located, the building or equipment to which the approved plans relate. The owner and the contractor shall, so far as possible, preserve and keep said permit posted until the completion of the work to which the approved plans related. Upon application by the owner or contractor, the chief building official or his designee shall issue a duplicate permit at a fee as prescribed in C.O. § 401.02 of the schedule of fees code to replace one that is lost or becomes missing by accident. 
§ 1300.17 - SPECIAL SUPERVISION WHERE REQUIRED. 
Where the work covered by approved plans involves construction or building service equipment which is hazardous or complex, or for other good reason requires special or expert supervision, the architect or professional engineer who signed such plans or affixed his seal thereto, or made the plans or computations for such work, shall supervise the work and be responsible for its conformity with the approved plans as they relate to safety and sanitation. Where said architect or professional engineer is not available, another architect, professional engineer, or other qualified person shall perform the required supervision. 
§ 1300.18 - LOT LINE MARKERS REQUIRED. 
Before any work is started in the construction of a building, all boundary lines shall be clearly marked at their intersections with permanent markers, not less than eighteen (18) inches in length, or with markers which are offset from permanent markers at a distance which is of record with the owner. 
§ 1300.19 - ELECTRICAL PERMITS. 
(A)  When electrical wiring changes are made to existing property requiring a permit and at the same time or in conjunction therewith new devices, such as, but not limited to, light fixtures and convenience outlets are installed in existing boxes, the application for the permit shall list such installations, which shall be included in the calculation of the permit fee and subject to the inspection provisions of this Code. 
§ 1300.20 - PERMIT FEES. 
The fee for an electrical permit for any work described below and for the required inspection shall be paid when the permit is issued. Such fee shall be in the amount specified by C.O. § 401.02. 
(A)  Wiring. Where wires are to be installations of conduit, surface raceway, armored cable, metallic tubing, under-floor raceways, including service race-way and equipment. 
(B)  Alterations. For additional outlets on installations where service equipment is not to be inspected. 
(C)  Fixtures. Pendant cords or Edison screw receptacles will be considered as fixtures and charged for as socket outlets. Approved lighting fixtures shall be considered as one (1) fixture. 
(D)  Footlights, border lights, cove or outline lighting when constructed and installed as fixtures are to be charged for on a socket basis under Item (C). 
When installed in conduit, electric metallic tubing, metal raceway or metallic armored cable, to be charged for under Item (A). 
(E)  Fees for the above shall be based on current consuming outlets. No charge shall be made for junction boxes or switches. 
(F)  Domestic heat regulating equipment, air conditioning venting or air circulation equipment, domestic oil, coal or gas burning equipment, appliances, water heaters, electric heating devices, battery charging outfits, door openers, transformers, etc., the fee shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. For each furnace using electric service for heating, the fee shall be the amount specified in the appliances provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
(G)  Electric signs and/or display lighting installations. The permit fee for each such sign or display lighting installation shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02, which shall include inspection of such device and its connections. 
(H)  Sound equipment in theaters and halls. 
(I)  Radio receiving installations, including antenna, ground connections and receptacles. 
(J)  Motors, generators, hot tubs, rectifiers, compressors, heat pumps. Motors of 1/4 horse power or less to be charged as light outlets. 
(K)  If more than one (1) inspection trip is necessary, a charge in the amount specified by C.O. § 401.02 will be made for each additional inspection trip. Reinspection fee to be paid and receipt posted on jobsite before future electrical inspections are performed. 
When a licensee and/or applicant owes reinspection fees at the time of application for another electrical permit, this permit shall be withheld until these fees have been paid. Also, further electrical inspections at an address with reinspection fees outstanding shall be deferred until these fees have been paid. 
(L)  Permanent or temporary service permit fee shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02 for service up to and including 250 AMP. For service in excess of 250 AMP, there shall be an additional charge per ampere assessed in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
§ 1300.21 - INSPECTION REQUIRED. 
Each permit holder shall cause to be inspected all electrical work done by him or his agent as required by the provisions of this ordinance. 
§ 1300.22 - UNSAFE WIRING. 
The building and/or electrical inspector is hereby empowered to cause to be disconnected, from the source of supply, any electrical wiring which, in his judgment, is unsafe. 
§ 1300.23 - PLUMBING PERMITS (ONE, TWO AND THREE-FAMILY ONLY, SEE OBC CHAPTER 4101:2-29 FOR ALL OTHER USES). 
Permits required: Except as permitted in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install, alter or repair any plumbing drain, vent sump, water closet, sink, lavatory or any other plumbing fixture within the city without first obtaining a permit from the building inspector to do such work, or for the owner or person having charge of any property within the city to cause or allow any such work to be done on such premises without a permit having been first obtained therefore. 
Permits may be obtained only by a master plumber or by an occupying owner performing work of plumbing in a single family dwelling building, except that the owner or lessee of any building, may obtain a permit for the removal and replacement of a fixture on the same fixture outlet, but not for the original installation of said fixture. The work of such removal or replacement shall be subject to all technical, inspection and penalty requirements of this Code. 
This section shall not apply or shall any permit be required in case of repairs not affecting sanitation, such as mending leaks in faucets, valves or water supply pipes, mending of broken fixtures, tanks, water heaters, releasing frozen pipes, or rodding and flushing of any house sewer or drain. 
Piping for manufacturing, scientific research and testing, other than soil or liquid piping, and all railroad installations are exempt from the permit and inspection requirements of this Chapter, but shall conform to the applicable section of the OBC. 
§ 1300.24 - FEE FOR PERMITS. 
The fee for plumbing permit and inspection, which shall be paid when the permit is issued, shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
§ 1300.25 - PLUMBING INSPECTIONS. 
Each permit holder shall cause to be inspected all plumbing work done by him or his agent. 
§ 1300.26 - FIRE SUPPRESSION SYSTEMS. 
No person shall install or make any substantial alterations or repairs to any fire suppression system in this city without first obtaining from the building inspector a permit to do such work. Application for a permit shall be made on a form prescribed by the building inspector, with such information as he may reasonably require. 
§ 1300.27 - FEE FOR PERMITS. 
The fee for such fire suppression system permits described below, which shall be paid when the permit is issued, shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
(A)  Automatic sprinkler plan review: The fee for sprinklers shall be based on the number of sprinklers, and shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
Standpipes using the same supply as the automatic sprinklers are included in the fee. 
For hydraulically designed systems, the fees are double the above schedule. 
(B)  Carbon dioxide suppression: The fee for carbon dioxide suppression systems shall be based on the number of pounds, and shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
(C)  Halogenated agent suppression: The fee for halogenated agent suppression systems shall be based on the number of pounds, and shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
(D)  Dry chemical suppression: The fee for dry chemical suppression systems shall be based on the number of pounds, and shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
(E)  Foam suppression: The fee for foam suppression systems shall be based on the number of gallons, and shall be assessed in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
(F)  Standpipe only without sprinklers: The fee for a standpipe only, without sprinklers, shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of C.O. § 401.02. 
§ 1300.28 - HVAC PERMIT. 
No person shall install or make any substantial alterations or repairs to any heating, ventilation, air conditioning or refrigeration system in this city without first obtaining from the building inspector a permit to do such work. Application for a permit shall be made on a form prescribed by the building inspector, with such information as he may reasonably require. 
§ 1300.29 - FEE FOR PERMIT. 
The fees for such permits for any work described in sections (A), (B), (C) and (D) below, which shall be paid when the permit is issued, shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
(A)  Heating. 
(1)  Permit fee and minimum permit fee for the installation and the required inspections of new heating systems using any and all heat generating devices and including all appurtenances, e.g., warm air outlets and returns, radiation baseboard convectors, electric grids and panels, etc., shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
(2)  Alterations or additions to existing refrigeration system or combination of systems. 
(3)  Unit heaters and infrared generators. 
(4)  Recessed heaters. 
(5)  Space heaters and floor heaters. 
(6)  Furnace and boiler replacement. 
(7)  Hot water heater replacement. 
(8)  Alterations and additions to any existing heating system or combination of heating system. 
(B)  Air conditioning and ventilation. 
(1)  Exhaust fans vented to outside. 
(2)  Range hoods vented. 
(3)  Mechanical ventilation system. 
(4)  Alterations and additions to any existing air distribution or ventilation system other than component parts of a heating system and combination of same. 
(C)  Refrigeration and heat pumps. Fees for each refrigeration and/or heat pump system (low, medium or high temperature) shall be based on the number of tons, and shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
(D)  Damper devices. 
(1)  Fees for each electrically actuated retrofit damper device for use with gas fired appliances shall be the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
(2)  Water towers. 
Fee included in refrigeration system as above. If installed as a component part of a new system fees shall be paid in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
§ 1300.30 - HOUSE SEWER PERMIT. 
No person shall connect a house sewer to the sanitary sewer system of this city, without first obtaining a permit therefore from the building department and paying a tapping and inspection fee in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
In applicable cases where the City of Columbus requires a sanitary sewer capacity permit and fee, which permits and fees are administered by the City of Upper Arlington, the fee paid to the City of Columbus and an additional administrative fee to be paid to the City of Upper Arlington shall be assessed in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02. 
§ 1300.31 - INFORMATION REQUIRED. 
Such person shall, upon request of the building inspector or any representative of the board of health of the city health district, furnish such information as to the depth, manner of construction, use or intended use of such well and such other information pertinent thereto as may be requested. 
§ 1300.32 - RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNER. 
The owner of premises subject to the provisions of this building code shall be responsible for compliance with the standards set forth herein. He shall remain responsible therefore, regardless of the fact certain responsibilities may also be placed on operators or agents and regardless of any agreement between the owner and anyone else as to whom shall assume such responsibilities. The owner shall remain responsible for the elimination of any violation found on his premises, regardless of any agreement between owners and others. 
§ 1300.33 - CONFLICT OF INTEREST. 
No officer or employee of the building division shall be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance of a building or other structure, or in the making of plans or of specifications therefore, unless he is the owner of such building or structure. No such officer or employee shall engage in any work, which is inconsistent with his duties or with interests of the division. 
§ 1300.34 - PERMIT OR APPROVAL REVOCATION. 
The chief building official shall revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this building code in case there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to a material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based, or whenever any permit or approval has been issued in error and conditions are such that a permit or approval should not have been issued. 
§ 1300.35 - PENALTIES. 
Every person, firm, corporation or other entity being the holder of a building permit or who is required to obtain a building permit, every contractor, every owner, every occupant whether legally in possession, and every other person, firm, corporation or other entity having charge, control or supervision of any building or structure, construction, use or operation covered by this building code, part 13 of the Codified Ordinances, shall be responsible for compliance with its provisions. Any such person, firm, corporation, other entity, contractor, owner, occupant and any other person, firm, corporation or other entity who violates or participates in the violation of any of the provisions of the building code, part 13 of the Codified Ordinances, shall be fined not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). The continued violation of any provision hereof shall constitute a separate offense for each and every day said violation shall continue. 
CHAPTER 1301. - ELECTRICAL SERVICE 
The following provisions shall supplement the National Electric Code NFPA 70, as referenced in the Ohio Basic Building Code. 

§ 1301.01 - ELECTRICAL SERVICE EQUIPMENT. 
The minimum size of a permanently installed new electrical installation shall be one hundred fifty (150) amperes. Existing electrical service panels less than one hundred fifty (150) amperes may be replaced to equal the existing service capacity, but shall not be less than one hundred (100) amperes in any case. During electrical service upgrades, the existing service equipment shall be replaced with new, or previously unused, electrical service equipment, shall be replaced at the time the electrical service is upgraded and shall be done prior to energization by the electrical utility. 
Exception No. 1-Due to storm damage or other acts of nature, it shall be permissible to replace only the service mast or service cable riser, which extends upward from the meter base to the point of attachment. 
Exception No. 2-Where the existing service equipment is rated at one hundred fifty (150) amperes or more, it shall be permissible to relocate the overhead service drop conductors underground to create a service lateral. This service lateral may be created without replacement of existing service equipment, so long as the service-entrance conductors are not changed. 
Exception No. 3-Existing listed circuit breakers which were part of the (old) service equipment may be installed in the new service equipment so long as the listed circuit breakers are intended for use in the (new) listed service enclosure. 
The installation of a one hundred (100) ampere electrical service is permitted in any of the three (3) types of apartment units defined under definitions in C.O. § 1300.02. Prior to granting such permission, a load calculation defining the actual calculated load of each individual apartment unit shall be required. This load calculation shall be on file at the community development department prior to the start of any service installation. 
( Ord. No. 87-2015, § 5, 12-14-2015 ) 
§ 1301.02 - TEMPORARY ELECTRICAL SERVICES. 
The minimum size of a temporary electrical service shall be one hundred (100) amperes. All one hundred twenty five (125) volt, single-phase, fifteen (15) and twenty (20) ampere receptacle outlets served from this service shall have ground-fault circuit-interrupter protection. 
(A)  Individual grounded circuits of ample capacity shall be required to supply the following equipment: washer, dryer, dishwasher, disposal, water heater, air conditioner, food freezer, pump, electric heater (one thousand (1,000) watts or above), gas furnace, boiler, or any appliance having a one quarter (1/4) HP rating or more. 
(B)  All one hundred twenty-five (125) volt, single-phase, fifteen (15) and twenty (20) ampere receptacles installed to serve ranges and counter-top surfaces in a kitchen, bathroom or wet bar area whether commercial or residential shall have ground-fault circuit- interrupter protection for personnel. 
§ 1301.03 - CHANGE, DAMAGE OR INTERFERENCE AFTER APPROVAL PROHIBITED. 
Whenever any electrical wiring or other electrical equipment has been inspected and approved, no person shall thereafter change, damage or interfere with the same without authority of the electrical inspector. No person shall thereafter place any sheet metal, pipe, or other metal work within five (5) inches of any electrical conductor, or open wiring, or knob and tube wiring, without having written authorization by the electrical inspector. The electrical inspector will prescribe the protection required for such wiring systems after an on-site inspection. 
CHAPTER 1303. - ANTENNA TOWERS, ANTENNAS AND SATELLITE DISHES 

§ 1303.01 - BUILDING PERMITS. 
No person shall erect or install an antenna tower, antenna or satellite dish which is one (1) meter or more in diameter as defined in C.O. § 6.11 of the Unified Development Code, without first obtaining a building permit therefor. Application for such permit shall be submitted in such form as may be prescribed by the building inspector and shall include, as a minimum, the following documents and information: 
(A)  A location plan in sufficient detail to identify the location of the proposed tower, antennas or satellite dish, to be supported thereby, with reference to the applicant's lot lines, building setback and existing structures. 
(B)  Manufacturer's antenna tower, antenna or satellite dish specifications, if available. If such specifications are not available, the applicant shall furnish such information as may be reasonably required by the building inspector to enable a determination to be made as to the strength, stability and dimensions of such tower, antenna or satellite dish. 
(C)  Details of the proposed antenna tower or satellite dish foundation or support and details of guys or braces, if any, including the number, location and method of attachment of each proposed guy or brace. 
(D)  Method of grounding to afford adequate lightning protection. 
(E)  Sufficient information to establish that the structure will be capable of withstanding a wind load of thirty (30) pounds per square foot or eight-six (86) miles per hour (see E.I.A. Standard RS-222-A). That it will, in all respects, be designed and mounted in accordance with sound engineering practices, and that it will not be in violation of any provision of the Unified Development Code or other law, ordinance or lawful regulation. 
(F)  When the building inspector is satisfied that the proposed antenna, antenna tower, satellite dish and appurtenances conform to the applicable provisions of the Unified Development Code and the requirements of this chapter, he shall, upon payment by the applicant of fees in the amount specified in C.O. § 401.02, issue a building permit in the manner provided in C.O. §§ 1300.11 through 1300.14 of the Upper Arlington Building Code. 
§ 1303.02 - INSPECTIONS. 
Following the issuance of a permit, the building inspector shall cause to be made such inspections and investigations as are necessary to determine whether or not the work done and the installations made are in conformity with the application relating thereto, and with the provisions of this chapter. 
CHAPTER 1304. - DRIVEWAYS AND SIDEWALKS, GRADING AND DRAINING OF LOTS, AND NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS 

§ 1304.01 - ENTRANCE TO CONSTRUCTION SITE. 
Before proceeding with the construction, enlargement, alteration, repair or removal of any building or other structure, in which it is desired or may be necessary to drive across the curb, treelawn or sidewalk, the owner, contractor, or builder, who is undertaking the construction shall, whenever there is a curb and gutter, apply for a permit to cut such curb under C.O. § 901.08. The permit holder shall cut the curb for a sufficient width at the location of the contemplated permanent driveway so as to prevent damage to the remainder of the curb, and if there is no curbing, he shall install in the ditch paralleling the street, tile of sufficient size, but not less than ten (10) inches, to prevent the backing up of water in the ditch and shall cover the tile with crushed stone or gravel to the level of the existing road for a width sufficient to allow trucks carrying building supplies to pass over. Thereafter, no vehicle shall be driven across the curb, treelawn, sidewalk or ditch except by way of said curb cut and proposed driveway. Said person shall take such further action as may be necessary to prevent the formation of ruts, depressions or other obstacles or hazards to pedestrian travel along the treelawn or sidewalk. All of said work shall be done under the supervision and to the satisfaction of the Building Inspector, who shall have the authority to determine the width, depth and manner of cutting the curb or laying tile and the type of protection of the sidewalk and treelawn. 
Not later than two (2) weeks after commencement of construction, alteration or repair of any such building or other structure, the owner shall construct a driveway of gravel or crushed stone extending from the side of the road nearest the site a distance of forty (40) feet. When said structure is completed, said driveway shall be completed in compliance with C.O. § 1304.02 of the Upper Arlington Building Code. 
§ 1304.02 - DRIVEWAYS OVER CITY PROPERTY. 
All driveways shall conform to Plate 1304.06(A) [see end of Chapter] or Plate 1304.06(B) [see end of Chapter] and the following: 
(A)  Location: The driveway shall be so located that all portions thereof shall come within the limits of lot lines extended to the existing curb or pavement, unless the council by special resolution shall authorize a different location which resolution shall specify the location authorized. In case water hydrants, light standards, telephone poles or other existing structures conflict with the location decided upon, the building inspector may require such structure to be removed, provided that removal is practicable. The property owner shall deposit in advance with the owner of said structures a sum sufficient to cover the full cost of removal and relocation. 
(B)  Removal of curb: The minimum length removal of existing curb shall be sixteen (16) feet. In cutting the existing curb, care shall be taken so that the cut shall be vertical and at right angles to the line of curb. Five (5) feet shall be the minimum length of the block or blocks of curb left in place, otherwise a full block of existing curb shall be removed and replaced. Replaced work shall conform in all respects in character and kind to existing work. The minimum width of driveway, from the curb line to the lot line, shall be ten (10) feet. 
In lieu of curb removal, the concrete curb may be cut or sawn. An approved machine, such as manufactured by Kot Kurb of Canada, shall be used for all curb cuts. The sawed curb surface shall be sealed immediately with an approved concrete sealer, applied in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications. A diamond wheel grinder shall be used to finish all cut edges. The bottom of the saw cut shall be one (1) inch above the gutter line and all work shall conform to Plate 1304.06(C) [see end of Chapter]. 
(C)  Character of work: All driveways shall be paved with concrete or asphaltic concrete from the back of the curb line, (or, if there be no curb, from the street pavement) to the lot line. Concrete shall comply with the provisions of C.O. § 1304.03(G) and shall have a minimum depth of six (6) inches throughout. Asphaltic concrete shall be of a type and depth as to have sufficient stability to withstand the use to which the driveway may be put. Where concrete sidewalks are in place in front of the property, that portion of the driveway crossing the sidewalk section shall be constructed of concrete. To provide for expansion, a one-half (1/2) inch pre-molded expansion joint extending the full section width of the curb and gutter shall be placed at each side where the driveway joins the existing curb and also in the center of said curb and gutter section. All work shall be done in a first-class, workman-like manner and shall be subject to the approval of the building inspector who may order the removal of any work which does not comply herewith. 
(D)  Existing structures: Existing drain tile shall be left in first-class workable condition and if disturbed shall be properly replaced. If no drain tile exists, a drain tile shall be inserted. Where electric cable exists, a two-inch fiber duct shall be placed around the cable in such a manner as to leave the cable free to be pulled and replaced. If no electric cable exists and if the street is improved with curbs and gutters, a two-inch conduit, capped at each end shall nevertheless be inserted to care for future cables. Valve boxes, land monuments and any existing structures encountered shall be properly protected and cared for. 
(E)  Where the sidewalk is adjacent to the curb, the building inspector may make such adjustments to Plate 1304.06(A) or Plate 1304.06(B) [see end of Chapter] as are necessary to prevent damage to the street, curb or sidewalk and provide for as smooth an entrance as possible. 
Where replacement of driveway apron, sidewalk and/or curb, either separately or combined, would require modification or replacement of work in place which is in good condition, the building inspector may modify the requirements of subsection 1304.06(A) and/or Plate 1304.06(B) [see end of Chapter] to avoid unnecessary repair or replacement. 
(F)  Limitation on width and number: 
(1)  No driveway entering a state highway within this city (whether or not the premises served thereby are within the city limits), shall exceed thirty (30) feet in width, or shall there be more than one (1) driveway entering a state highway for each two hundred (200) feet of frontage of the premises on such highway, or more than one (1) such driveway for any one (1) lot or parcel of land fronting on such highway; provided that the council may waive the limitations of this paragraph, for good cause, in cases in which the public interest will not be prejudiced thereby. 
(2)  Not more than one (1) parallel street may be used as a means of access or construction of driveways in the case of through lots, as defined by Upper Arlington Unified Development Code § 2.02, where the rear of such through lot is contiguous to a thoroughfare or collector street as they are identified in the master plan and as amended from time to time. 
(G)  Location of driveway in relation to an intersection: The proximity of a new residential driveway to a street intersection shall conform to the corner detail shown in Plate 1304.06(D) [see end of Chapter]. The minimum distance from the intersection to the start of the driveway flare shall be thirty-two (32) feet. 
(Ord. No. 34-2011, 7-13-2011) 
§ 1304.03 - SIDEWALKS. 
Sidewalks within the confines of the right-of-way shall be of Portland cement concrete of monolithic construction or of other material approved in writing by the City Manager or his/her designee, and shall have a width of five feet (5) unless a different width shall be provided in the resolution of Council ordering sidewalk construction or unless a different width is appropriate, and shall be constructed as hereinafter set forth. Unless Council has specified the location of sidewalks in its legislation ordering their construction, the city manager may authorize the construction of sidewalks anywhere within the right-of-way (but not nearer the curb or roadway than two (2) feet unless it is his/her determination that such location will not detract from the utility or appearance of such sidewalks, or be objectionable in other respects. 
(A)  Thickness: All concrete walks shall have a minimum thickness of four (4) inches except as excepted in C.O. § 1304.03 (L), or within the limits of driveways, where the minimum thickness shall be six (6) inches. Non-concrete walks shall be built as specified by the city when approval is granted for construction. 
(B)  Grade: Wherever sidewalk meets existing curb, the sidewalk shall be one-half (1/2) inch above the curb. Where walks are parallel with the curb, the near edge of the walk shall be one-half (1/2) inch higher for each foot the sidewalk is distant from the curb, and this grade continued across the entire walk. In other words, the grass plot and sidewalk shall be graded with a rise of one-half (1/2) inch per foot from the curb to property line. The slope may be varied as directed by the city, if necessary, to conform to existing structures or grades. 
(C)  Expansion joints: Expansion joints one-quarter (1/4) inch thick of suitable asphaltic felt or joint material shall be provided in all instances where concrete sidewalk meets curb, or where joining existing walks or concrete structures, and at intervals of approximately sixteen (16) feet across the walk. 
(D)  Preparation of subgrade: The subgrade shall be brought to an even, compact surface, uniformly four (4) inches below the finished surface of the walk, six (6) inches below for driveways. Soft or spongy earth, vegetable or other perishable matter shall be removed and the space filled with gravel or broken stone and thoroughly compacted by ramming. Wherever a fill is necessary to support the sidewalk, material for the fill shall be spread in four-inch layers and each layer thoroughly rolled or rammed. A subgrade layer of four (4) inches of compacted gravel is recommended under all new or replacement concrete sidewalks. 
(E)  Structures encountered: The contractor shall adjust main line or hydrant valve boxes, water or gas service boxes and manholes in the area of the walks to conform to the finished grade. 
(F)  Forms: Forms for concrete sidewalk shall be of wood not less than two (2) inches nominal thickness or of steel of equal rigidity. Flexible strips may be used on curves. The forms shall be set true to line and grade and be securely stacked and held. 
(G)  Material: Portland cement concrete for sidewalks shall be Class C concrete as described under Item 499, Concrete, General in the State of Ohio, Department of Highways, Construction and Material Specifications, except that all coarse aggregate shall be No. 6 and of the quality as specified for super-structure concrete. In general, this shall contain a minimum of six and one-half (6.5) bags of cement for c.y. of concrete and have a maximum net water content of 5.75 gallons per bag of cement. Such adjustments shall be made in the materials, proportions and method of mixing as may be necessary to entrain four percent (4%) to seven percent (7%) air in the concrete. When placed, the slump of the concrete shall not exceed three (3) inches. The city may order two (2) test cylinders, six (6) inches by twelve (12) inches, made from each one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of sidewalk placed. If so ordered, the contractor shall make the test cylinders, cure them and transport them to an approved laboratory for testing. One (1) copy of the report of the cylinder test shall be promptly delivered to the city. The cost of making, curing, transporting and testing the cylinder shall be included in the price bid for the sidewalk. 
(H)  Placing and finishing: The subgrade shall be adequately moistened just before the concrete is placed. The concrete shall be deposited and compacted in a single layer. It shall be struck off with a template and smoothed with a float to produce a sandy texture. The edges shall be rounded to one-quarter (1/4) inch radius. The surface of the sidewalk shall be divided into blocks by the use of a grooving tool. The grooves shall be spaced equally at four-foot intervals to divide the walk into square blocks. Additional grooves shall be placed over roof drains, at changes in walk thickness and at other places directed by the city. A true expansion joint extending through the entire thickness shall be placed at every fourth joint or at intervals of approximately every sixteen (16) feet. 
(I)  Curing and protection: After finishing, the concrete shall be sealed by spraying thereon a membrane curing material in such a manner as to provide a continuous, uniform water-impermeable film without marring the surface of the concrete. A minimum of one (1) gallon of material shall be used per two hundred (200) square feet of surface treated. The curing material shall be of such a nature that it is distinctly visible for at least four (4) hours after application, but shall produce no permanent discoloration of the concrete. 
Sidewalks shall not be laid on frozen ground or at a time when freezing temperatures prevail. The contractor shall be prepared to protect all concrete placed at such times as freezing temperature may be encountered. 
(J)  Clean-up: As the walk is completed and forms removed, the contractor shall immediately backfill the excavation, remove all surplus material and leave the walk and sod strip entirely free from any objects or material that may endanger the public. 
(K)  Roof drain replacement: Existing roof drains passing through the sidewalk area shall be protected when they are at such a grade that the top of the pipe barrel is at least three (3) inches below the top of the sidewalk or finished grade of the sod strip. Drains having less than three-inch cover shall be lowered or replaced for such length as necessary to get cover and to meet the existing pipe grade in the lawn. 
Pipe used for replacement shall be four-inch nominal diameter standard strength vitrified clay pipe; D quality asbestos cement pipe; C quality rigid plastic pipe or standard strength cast iron soil pipe. In all cases the joints between sections shall be sealed by a method appropriate for the pipe being used. Where the replacement pipe is of different type from the existing pipe, the joint between the two shall be made watertight and mechanically secure. 
If the replacement pipe is carried through the curb, the opening shall be cleaned out and mortared up in a neat and workman-like manner after the replacement pipe is installed. 
(L)  Concrete may be reduced to three (3) inches thick over drains, utility lines, tree roots, or other obstacles outside the limits of driveways. No sidewalk shall be constructed of concrete less than three (3) inches thick in any location. 
§ 1304.04 - GRADING AND DRAINING OF LOTS. 
The requirements for the grading and draining of building lots shall be as follows: 
(A)  The foundation walls of every dwelling house, and every other building having a basement under any part thereof, shall be constructed to an elevation at least four (4) inches higher than the top of the abutting street, (measured at the mid-point of the lot frontage), plus a height equal to one-half (1/2) inch for each foot of distance from such building to the abutting street curb. The finished grade of the ground from the front of such building to the street shall slope toward the street at the rate of not less than one-half (1/2) inch to the foot, throughout all portions of said front yard. 
(B)  Where it is not practicable to grade the lot so as to provide natural run-off of surface water from the entire lot to a street, storm sewer or other approved outlet, a drainage line or lines of field tile, vitrified tile or other non-porous pipe of acceptable size shall be installed, with proper inlets to drain any part of the lot which would otherwise collect and impound water. The materials and method of installation of such lines shall be determined by the building inspector. Such drainage lines shall lead into the street, storm sewer or other outlet approved by the Building Inspector. 
(C)  The lot grading and drainage herein required shall not thereafter be changed by any owner, occupant or other person in control of the premises in such a way as to diminish or impede the run-off of water from such lot, away from any building, toward the street, storm sewer or other approved outlet. 
(D)  The building inspector shall have the power to modify the foregoing provisions and to make additional or substituted requirements on hillside lots, corner lots and in other individual cases where, because of unusual topographic or other problems, the above requirements would not produce the results sought, or where other grading or drainage treatment would produce equal or better results. 
(E)  Reserved. 
(F)  Reserved. 
(G)  Where curbs and gutters have not been installed in the abutting street the foundation and lot grades shall be predicated upon the proposed grade of the abutting street as established by the city engineer. 
(H)  All roof water from any building, including detached accessory garages, in this city shall be carried from downspouts to the street gutter, storm ditch or storm sewer through thin walled polyvinyl chloride pipe (PVC), corrugated ADS, or approved equivalent having a minimum diameter of four (4) inches, bedded in sand and laid to proper grade. 
(I)  Where the grade at the building is below the grade of street gutter, storm ditch or storm sewer the Building Inspector shall determine the method of drainage, but no such system shall be installed closer to a building than ten (10) feet, or closer to a basement than fifteen (15) feet, or in any side yard. 
(J)  Where roof gutters are not installed, a trench shall be constructed at a point under the drip line of the roof overhang having a minimum width of one (1) foot. The trench shall be graded to the street gutter, storm sewer or storm ditch and shall have three (3) inches of stone at the bottom upon which four-inch field tile shall be laid so as to drain as described above. The remainder of the ditch shall be filled with stone and at the discharge end of said trench the field tile shall be connected to thin walled polyvinyl chloride (PVC), corrugated ADS, or approved equivalent and carried to the final point of discharge as set forth in subsection (H) hereof. 
(K)  Green building standards may also be utilized to mitigate all or a portion of the site grading and drainage requirements as set forth in subsections (A) through (J). A stormwater management plan shall be developed and submitted to the chief building official for review and approval prior to implementation. This stormwater management plan shall be developed to minimize concentrated flows and to simulate flows in natural hydrology by the use of dry wells, french drains, rain barrels, rain gardens, vegetated swales and similar features. Once approved and implemented, the site grading and drainage shall not cause excessive erosion or water damage and shall not create a nuisance on public or private property. Additionally the approved site grading and drainage shall not thereafter be changed by any owner, occupant or other person in control of the premises in such a way as to diminish or impede the run-off.
